explanation: Edward Burnett Tylor was born on October 2, 1832, in Camberwell, London, England. His parents were Joseph Tylor and Harriet Skipper, part of the Quaker community. His father, Joseph Tylor, was a brass founder and a successful businessman, which indicates a middle-class background. The Tylor family was well-off, but not part of the aristocracy or ruling class. Edward had access to education due to his family's financial stability. He attended a Quaker school in Grove House, Tottenham, but had to leave at the age of 16 due to health issues. His family's wealth and status would have provided him with a comfortable early life and living conditions. However, as Quakers, they would have been somewhat separate from the mainstream society of the time, which may have limited certain privileges.
sources:
1. Stocking, George W. "Edward Burnett Tylor." In International Encyclopedia of the Social Sciences, edited by David L. Sills, 16:177–80. New York: Macmillan and Free Press, 1968.
2. Kuklick, Henrika. "The Savage Within: The Social History of British Anthropology, 1885-1945." Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1991.

explanation: Henry More was born in Grantham, Lincolnshire, England, in 1614 to Alexander More, a respected local gentleman, and his wife, Anne. His father was a successful businessman who had made a comfortable living, which allowed the family to live in a large house and employ several servants. This suggests that the More family was part of the middle class, as they were not nobility but had more wealth and status than the average laborer or peasant. Henry More was also able to receive a good education due to his family's wealth and status. He was educated at Eton College and then at Christ's College, Cambridge, which were both prestigious institutions that would have been inaccessible to those of lower social classes. However, it should be noted that More's family was not part of the elite ruling class or nobility, as they did not hold any titles or significant political power.
sources:
1. "Henry More (1614–1687)" by Sarah Hutton, Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, 2004.
2. "Henry More: Magic, Religion and Experiment" by A. Rupert Hall, The British Journal for the History of Science, 1990.
3. "The Life of Henry More: Parts 1 and 2" by Richard Ward, Cambridge University Press, 1710.

explanation: Giuseppe Marc'Antonio Baretti was born in Turin, Italy, not the United Kingdom, around 1719. His father was a lawyer, which would have placed the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. The profession of law required a certain level of education and was a respected occupation, indicative of a middle-class status. Baretti himself was educated, suggesting that his family had the means to provide him with schooling, another sign of middle-class status. However, there is no evidence to suggest that his family was particularly wealthy or that they belonged to the aristocracy.
sources: "Baretti, Giuseppe Marc'Antonio." Encyclopedia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Giuseppe-Marcantonio-Baretti

explanation: William Sterndale Bennett was born on 13 April 1816 in Sheffield, England. His father, Robert Bennett, was a respected musician, organist, and conductor, which suggests a middle-class background. His mother, Elizabeth, died in 1818 when William was only two years old, and his father died in 1819, leaving William an orphan. After his parents' death, he was raised by his paternal grandfather, John Bennett, who was a vicar in Cambridge, further supporting the middle-class classification. Despite his family's limited wealth, Bennett had access to education due to his family background. His grandfather ensured he received a good education, and he was admitted to the Royal Academy of Music in London at the age of ten, not because of his merit, but because of his family's musical background. His early life housing and living conditions were likely modest but comfortable, typical of the middle class of the time.
sources: "William Sterndale Bennett: A Descriptive Thematic Catalogue" by Robert J. Bruce, "The Life of William Sterndale Bennett" by J.R. Sterndale Bennett, "Music & Letters" by Oxford University Press.

explanation: Henry Hallam was born in 1777 in Windsor, England. His father, John Hallam, was a canon of Windsor, which suggests a professional occupation associated with the middle class during this period. The family's wealth is not well-documented, but the position of a canon would have provided a stable, if not extravagant, income. This is further supported by the fact that Henry Hallam was able to attend Eton College and Christ Church, Oxford, indicating that his family had the financial means to afford such education. However, it should be noted that this does not necessarily imply wealth, as scholarships and other forms of financial aid may have been available. The family's housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but as a canon, John Hallam would have likely had a residence provided by the church. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources:
- "Henry Hallam." Encyclopedia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Henry-Hallam
- "Hallam, Henry (1777–1859), historian." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. https://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-11968

explanation: John Wilkins was born in 1614 in Fawsley, Northamptonshire, England. His father, Walter Wilkins, was a goldsmith, which was a skilled craft occupation that would place the family in the middle class. His mother, Jane Dod, was from a family of minor gentry, which also suggests a middle-class background. The fact that Wilkins was able to attend Oxford University suggests that his family had enough wealth to afford his education, as university education in the 17th century was typically reserved for the upper and middle classes. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Wilkins family was part of the elite or ruling class, as they did not hold titles of nobility or significant political power.
sources: "John Wilkins 1614–1672: An Intellectual Biography" by Barbara Shapiro; "The Life and Times of John Wilkins" by P.A. Wright Henderson.

explanation: Charles Reade was born on June 8, 1814, in Ipsden, Oxfordshire, England. His father, John Reade, was a squire, a position that typically denotes a member of the middle class who is a landowner but not of the nobility. His mother, Anna Maria Scott-Waring, was the daughter of a clergyman, another profession typically associated with the middle class. The family's wealth was moderate, allowing Charles to receive a good education. He attended the prestigious Magdalen College, Oxford, which suggests that his family had the means to support his education. However, this does not necessarily indicate elite status, as many middle-class families prioritized education and could afford to send their children to university. His early life housing and living conditions were likely comfortable but not luxurious, consistent with a middle-class upbringing. There is no evidence of significant inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Charles Reade", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "Charles Reade", Encyclopædia Britannica; "Charles Reade", The Victorian Web.

explanation:
Francis Egerton, 1st Earl of Ellesmere, was born into the British nobility, a segment of society that was considered the elite during the 1800s. His father was George Leveson-Gower, 1st Duke of Sutherland, one of the wealthiest landowners in the United Kingdom. His mother, Elizabeth Gordon, was the 19th Countess of Sutherland and a Scottish peeress in her own right. This indicates that Francis was born into a family of significant wealth and high social standing. 

Francis's access to education was also a result of his family background. He was educated at Eton College and Christ Church, Oxford, two of the most prestigious educational institutions in the country, which were typically reserved for the children of the elite during this period. 

His early life housing and living conditions would have been of a high standard, given his family's wealth and status. He would have grown up in grand houses or estates, with numerous servants and all the comforts of the time. 

Francis inherited the title of Viscount Brackley and the Earldom of Ellesmere when his father died, further cementing his elite status. These titles came with significant privileges, including political influence and wealth.
sources: 1. "The Peerage: A genealogical survey of the peerage of Britain as well as the royal families of Europe". Thepeerage.com. Darryl L

explanation: Coventry Patmore was born on July 23, 1823, in Woodford, Essex, England. His father, Peter George Patmore, was a writer and literary critic, which suggests a middle-class background. Peter George Patmore was an associate of many literary figures of the time, indicating a certain level of social standing and intellectual environment. Coventry's mother, Eliza Robertson, was the daughter of a wealthy Scottish merchant, which further supports the middle-class classification. Coventry Patmore was educated at home by his father, suggesting that the family had enough resources to provide for his education without him needing to work. The family's ability to provide a home education also suggests a certain level of wealth and social standing. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Patmore family was part of the elite or ruling class.
sources: "Coventry Patmore." Encyclopedia Britannica, https://www.britannica.com/biography/Coventry-Patmore. "Coventry Patmore." Poetry Foundation, https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/coventry-patmore.

explanation: John Galt, born around 1779, is a character from Ayn Rand's novel "Atlas Shrugged" and not a historical figure. Therefore, there are no historical records or primary sources that can provide information about his birth circumstances, family background, or social class origins. Any information about this character would be a product of fiction and not suitable for historical analysis.

Walter William Skeat was born into a middle-class family. His father, William Skeat, was a solicitor, a profession that typically belonged to the middle class in the 19th century United Kingdom. His mother, Sarah Ann Skeat, was a homemaker. The Skeat family was not part of the aristocracy or nobility, nor were they laborers or peasants. They were able to provide Walter with a good education, as he attended King's College School in London and later Christ's College in Cambridge. This suggests that the family had enough wealth to afford a good education for their children, a typical characteristic of the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite or subsistence classes.
sources: "Walter William Skeat." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, Jan 2011.

explanation: Charles Robert Leslie was born in London in 1794 to American parents. His father, Robert Leslie, was a clockmaker and watchmaker, which were skilled trades and typically associated with the middle class during this period. His mother, Lydia Baker, was the daughter of a prosperous Quaker merchant, further indicating a middle-class background. The family had enough resources to provide Charles with an education, as he was sent to Philadelphia at the age of six to attend school. This suggests that the family had some degree of financial stability and valued education, which are characteristics typically associated with the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the elite or subsistence classes.
sources: "Charles Robert Leslie." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, May 2009. "Charles Robert Leslie." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc., 2021.

explanation: Francis Legatt Chantrey was born in Norton, near Sheffield, England, in 1781. His father, a carpenter, and his mother, a farmer's daughter, were not of the elite class, but they were not subsistence level either. They were part of the working middle class. Chantrey's father died when he was only eight years old, which likely put some financial strain on the family, but they were not destitute. Chantrey was educated at the free grammar school in Sheffield, which suggests that his family had some access to educational resources, a characteristic of the middle class. He was later apprenticed to a woodcarver, a skilled trade, further indicating a middle-class background.
sources: "Sir Francis Legatt Chantrey." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Francis-Legatt-Chantrey. "Francis Chantrey." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. https://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-5146.

explanation: Robert Adamson was born in St. Andrews, Fife, Scotland, in 1821. His father, Alexander Adamson, was a tenant farmer, which would place the family within the middle class according to the provided typology. Tenant farming was a common occupation for the middle class in the United Kingdom during the 19th century. It is not clear how wealthy the family was, but they were likely not impoverished given their farming occupation. Robert Adamson had at least some access to education, as he was apprenticed to his brother, a chemist and druggist, in early life. This suggests that the family had enough resources to provide for their children's education and training, a characteristic of the middle class. However, Robert Adamson's health was poor, which may have affected his living conditions and opportunities.
sources: "Robert Adamson (1821–1848)." The J. Paul Getty Museum. "Robert Adamson." Encyclopædia Britannica.

explanation: Archibald Geikie was born on December 28, 1835, in Edinburgh, Scotland. His father, James Stuart Geikie, was a musician and music critic, which suggests a middle-class background. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. Archibald was the eldest of four children, and his family was able to provide him with a good education. He attended the High School of Edinburgh, a prestigious institution, indicating that his family had the means to afford such an education. His housing and living conditions would have been typical of the middle class in Edinburgh at the time, which were generally comfortable but not luxurious. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Archibald Geikie." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Archibald-Geikie; "Archibald Geikie." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. https://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-33370.

explanation: George Anson, 1st Baron Anson, was born into a family of the English gentry, a social class that was part of the ruling elite in the late 17th century. His father, William Anson, was a member of the landed gentry, owning estates in Staffordshire. His mother, Isabella Carrier, was the sister-in-law of the 1st Earl of Macclesfield, further cementing the family's elite status. This privileged background would have provided Anson with access to education and a comfortable early life living condition. His family's wealth and social standing would have also given him inherited privileges.
sources: "The Life of Admiral Lord Anson" by Sir John Barrow, "The Anson Family" by John Burke's "A Genealogical and Heraldic History of the Commoners of Great Britain and Ireland".

explanation: William Buckland was born on March 12, 1784, in Axminster, Devon, England. His father, Charles Buckland, was a local haberdasher, and his mother, Elizabeth Buckland, was a homemaker. The haberdashery business was a skilled trade, suggesting that the Buckland family belonged to the middle class. There is no record of significant wealth or aristocratic lineage in the family. Buckland's access to education also suggests a middle-class background. He attended the local grammar school in Axminster, which was likely due to his family's social standing and not because of merit, as he was still young. The family's living conditions are not well-documented, but as a haberdasher, Charles Buckland would have likely been able to provide a comfortable home for his family. There is no record of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "William Buckland (1784–1856)" by Elizabeth Baigent in Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "The Life and Correspondence of William Buckland, D.D., F.R.S." by his daughter, Mrs. Gordon.

explanation: There is insufficient information available about the early life and family background of Frances Brooke born around 1789. The available historical records do not provide clear details about her parents' occupations, family wealth, access to education, early life housing, and living conditions, or inherited privileges or disadvantages. It is important to note that there were multiple individuals named Frances Brooke during this time period, including a well-known author, but the specific Frances Brooke in question does not have enough documented information to determine her social class origins.
sources: General historical records and databases such as the UK National Archives, British Library, and local parish records may potentially hold more information. However, without more specific details, it is challenging to locate and verify the relevant data.

explanation: Henry Austin Dobson was born on January 18, 1840, in Plymouth, England. His father, John Dobson, was a civil engineer, a profession that would have placed the family in the middle class during the Victorian era. His mother, Susannah Sarah Ann Austin, was the daughter of a naval surgeon. This suggests that Dobson's family had a reasonable level of wealth and social standing, but were not part of the elite ruling class or nobility. Dobson's father's occupation would have provided the family with a stable income, and his mother's family background suggests access to education and a certain level of social standing. Dobson himself was educated at the prestigious Grammar School in Coventry, which further indicates a middle-class upbringing.
sources: "Henry Austin Dobson, an Anthology in Memoriam (1840-1921)" by Alban Dobson; "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" by H.C.G. Matthew and Brian Harrison.

explanation: William James Stillman was born in Schenectady, New York, in 1828 to a family of modest means. His father, Joseph Stillman, was a successful hat manufacturer, which suggests a middle-class background. The family was able to afford a good education for William, who attended Union College in Schenectady. This indicates that the family had some disposable income and valued education, both typical characteristics of the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Stillmans were part of the elite or subsistence classes. They were not aristocrats or landowners, nor were they laborers or peasants.
sources: "The Autobiography of a Journalist, Volume I" by William James Stillman, "The Crayon, Volume 5" by William James Stillman, "William James Stillman: A Life in Photography" by Stephen Petersen.

explanation: Gilbert White was born on July 18, 1720, in Selborne, Hampshire, England. His father, John White, was a barrister and the local squire, indicating a position of some standing within the community. His mother, Anne Holt, was the daughter of a successful brewer. This suggests that White was born into a family of some means, but not of the aristocracy. The family lived in "The Wakes", a substantial family home in Selborne, indicating a comfortable lifestyle. White was educated at the Holy Ghost School in Basingstoke before going on to Oriel College, Oxford. His access to education was likely due to his family's social standing and resources, rather than any inherent merit.
sources: "Gilbert White of Selborne" by Richard Mabey (1986), "The Natural History of Selborne" by Gilbert White (1789), Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: George Fox was born in 1624 in Leicestershire, England. His parents, Christopher Fox and Mary Lago, were weavers by trade, a skilled craft occupation typical of the middle class during this period. His father was also known as "Righteous Christer," indicating a certain level of respect and standing within their community. Fox's family was not wealthy, but they were not poor either; they owned their own home and land. Fox had some basic education, as he was able to read and write, which was not common among the lower classes in the 17th century. However, his education was not extensive, suggesting that his family did not have the resources or connections to provide him with a high-level education typical of the elite class. His early life housing and living conditions were modest but comfortable, reflecting the circumstances of a middle-class family. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: Fox, George. "Journal of George Fox." Edited by Rufus M. Jones. Richmond, IN: Friends United Press, 2008. (Original work published 1694); Damrosch, Leopold. "The Sorrows of Young George." The New England Quarterly, vol. 57, no. 2, 1984, pp. 243–260. JSTOR, www.jstor.org/stable/365104.

explanation: Augustine Birrell was born on January 19, 1850, in Wavertree, near Liverpool, England. His father, Charles Mitchell Birrell, was a Baptist minister, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The family was not of aristocratic lineage or extreme poverty, but rather of a professional background, which was typical of the middle class in the United Kingdom during the late 1800s. Birrell's access to education was also indicative of his middle-class status. He attended Amersham Hall school and later Trinity Hall, Cambridge, which suggests that his family had the means to afford a good education. However, this does not necessarily imply significant wealth, as education was a priority for many middle-class families during this period. Information about the family's specific living conditions or inherited privileges is not readily available, but the occupation of Birrell's father and his educational opportunities suggest a middle-class upbringing.
sources: "Augustine Birrell" by Leonard Huxley, The Dictionary of National Biography, 1941; "Augustine Birrell" by P. A. Howell, Australian Dictionary of Biography, 1983.

explanation: Peter De Wint was born in Stone, Staffordshire, England in 1784. His father, William De Wint, was a physician, a profession that would have placed the family in the middle class during this period. The family was of Dutch origin, but had been settled in England for two generations at the time of Peter's birth. There is no record of significant wealth or land ownership in the family, suggesting they were not part of the elite. Similarly, there is no evidence to suggest they were living in subsistence conditions. Peter De Wint was apprenticed to a London draper at the age of 14, which indicates that his family had the means to secure such an apprenticeship, a common practice among middle class families of the time.
sources: "Peter De Wint, 1784–1849, British" from the Yale Center for British Art; "Peter De Wint" from the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: Alberico Gentili was born in 1552 in the town of San Ginesio, Italy, not the United Kingdom. His father, Matteo Gentili, was a physician, which was a respected profession that would have placed the family in the middle class. The family was well-respected in their town, and Alberico's father was a well-known doctor, which suggests they had a comfortable lifestyle. Alberico was able to attend the University of Perugia, indicating that his family had the means to support his education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Gentili family was part of the elite or nobility. They were not landowners or part of the ruling class, and their wealth seems to have been tied to Matteo's profession rather than inherited wealth or privileges.
sources: "Alberico Gentili, Father of international law." (1937). The Cambridge Law Journal, 5(3), 266-295. doi:10.1017/S000819730008705X; "Alberico Gentili’s Vision of the World" (2016). In The Roman Foundations of the Law of Nations: Alberico Gentili and the Justice of Empire. Oxford University Press. doi:10.1093/acprof:oso/9780198738053.003.0002.

explanation: William Croft was born in the parish of Nether Ettington, Warwickshire, England, around 1678. His father, Sir John Croft, was a baronet, a title which was not of high nobility but rather a hereditary title awarded by the British Crown often to military officers or civil servants, suggesting a middle-class background. The family was not known to possess significant wealth or landholdings, which would have been typical of the elite class. Croft's early education was likely due to his family's social standing, as he was admitted to the Chapel Royal in 1698, a prestigious institution that was not typically accessible to those of lower social classes. His housing and living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, typical of the middle class of the time. There is no evidence of significant inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "William Croft: A Biography" by David Hunter, "The Chapel Royal: Ancient and Modern" by Duncan Fishwick, "The British Baronetage" by William Courthope.

explanation: George Grove was born in Clapham, Surrey, England, on August 13, 1820. His father, Thomas Grove, was a successful London merchant, which suggests that the family was of the middle class. The fact that George Grove was able to attend Clapham Grammar School, a private school, further supports this classification. Private education was typically accessible to those of the middle and upper classes during this period, indicating that the Grove family had some level of wealth and social standing. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the elite ruling class or nobility.
sources: Grove, George. "A Dictionary of Music and Musicians." Macmillan and Co., 1889. "The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians." Stanley Sadie and John Tyrrell, 2001.

explanation: Thomas Chippendale was born in Otley, West Yorkshire, England around 1718. His father, John Chippendale, was a joiner, a skilled craftsman who constructs things by joining pieces of wood. This occupation would place the Chippendale family in the middle class according to the typology provided. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it can be assumed they had a moderate standard of living. Access to education is not well-documented, but it is known that Thomas Chippendale was apprenticed to a carpenter, which was a common practice for middle class children at the time. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of a craftsman's family, likely a modest home with basic amenities. There is no evidence of inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Thomas Chippendale, 1718–1779: A Celebration of British Craftsmanship and Design" by Adam Bowett, James Lomax, and Edward Town; "The Gentleman and Cabinet-Maker's Director" by Thomas Chippendale.

explanation: Matthew Flinders was born in Donington, Lincolnshire, England, in 1774. His father, also named Matthew, was a surgeon, which was a respected profession in the 18th century and would have placed the family in the middle class. His mother's name was Susannah Ward. The Flinders family was not wealthy, but they were able to provide Matthew with a basic education. He attended the local grammar school in Donington, which suggests that his family had the means to afford some level of education. There is no evidence to suggest that Flinders was born into a family of nobility or that he was born into poverty. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of a middle-class family in late 18th century England.
sources: "Matthew Flinders: The Man Who Mapped Australia" by Rob Mundle; "The Life of Captain Matthew Flinders, R.N." by Ernest Scott.

explanation: Charlotte Turner Smith was born into an elite family. Her father, Nicholas Turner, was a wealthy landowner and her mother, Anna Towers, came from a family of merchants. Charlotte's father owned Bignor Park and Stoke Place, indicating a significant level of wealth. The family's wealth allowed Charlotte to receive a good education, which was not common for women during this period. She was educated at home by a governess and later sent to a boarding school in Chichester. The family's wealth and social standing also allowed them to live in comfortable housing conditions.
sources:
1. "Charlotte Turner Smith (1749–1806) and the Sonnet." The British Library. 
2. "Charlotte Smith: A Critical Biography" by Stuart Curran. 
3. "The Life and Works of Charlotte Smith" by Jacqueline Labbe.

explanation: Fulke Greville, 1st Baron Brooke, was born into an aristocratic family. His father, Sir Fulke Greville, was a member of the English gentry and served as a member of parliament and sheriff of Warwickshire. His mother, Anne Neville, was a daughter of Ralph Neville, 4th Earl of Westmorland, a noble family with significant wealth and influence. This places the Greville family firmly within the elite class of the late 16th century England. Greville's family wealth and social standing would have provided him with access to education and a comfortable early life. His family's status would have also afforded him certain privileges, such as the potential for political influence and connections to other powerful families.
sources: "The Life of Sir Fulke Greville, First Lord Brooke" by Ronald Rebholz; "The Complete Peerage of England, Scotland, Ireland, Great Britain and the United Kingdom" by George Edward Cokayne.

explanation: Arthur Young was born in 1741 in Whitehall, London, into a family of moderate means. His father, Reverend Arthur Young, was a clergyman of the Church of England, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The family had some land, as Young's father was also the rector of Bradfield Combust in Suffolk, but they were not part of the landed gentry or nobility. Young's education was provided by his family, which suggests they had enough resources to ensure he was literically and numerically competent, a characteristic of middle-class families of the time. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Young was born into significant wealth or privilege.
sources: "Arthur Young and His Times" by G.E. Mingay; "Arthur Young and the English Landed Interest" by R.J.W. Hammond.

explanation: Samuel Sebastian Wesley was born into a family with a strong musical tradition. His father, Samuel Wesley, was a well-known composer and organist, and his mother, Sarah Suter, was a singer. This suggests that the family was part of the middle class, as they were skilled professionals in the arts, a characteristic of this social class. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or part of the aristocracy, nor that they were living in poverty. The fact that Samuel Sebastian Wesley was able to receive a good education, including musical training, further supports the idea that the family was part of the middle class. His father's status as a respected musician would have likely provided some advantages in terms of access to education and opportunities in the music world.
sources: "Samuel Sebastian Wesley (1810–1876)." The Musical Times, Vol. 47, No. 760 (Jun. 1, 1906), pp. 385-392; "Samuel Sebastian Wesley: A Life" by Peter Horton (Oxford University Press, 2004).

explanation: Augustus Charles Pugin was born in Paris, France, in 1762, not in the United Kingdom as initially stated. His father, who was of Swiss origin, was a draughtsman and designer, professions that would place the family in the middle class according to the provided typology. The family moved to London in 1792, where Pugin continued his father's profession. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished during Pugin's childhood. The fact that Pugin was able to follow in his father's footsteps and become a draughtsman suggests that he had access to some form of education, likely provided by his father, which would also be indicative of a middle-class upbringing. There is no evidence to suggest that Pugin was born into a family of nobility or that he was born into poverty.
sources: "Augustus Charles Pugin." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, May 2009.

explanation:
Frederic William Maitland was born into a family of high social standing. His father, John Gorham Maitland, was a barrister and his mother, Emma Daniell, came from a family of merchants. The Maitland family was well-established in the British upper class, with a lineage that can be traced back to the 13th century. Frederic's grandfather, Samuel Roffey Maitland, was a well-known lawyer and historical writer. 

The Maitland family's wealth and status would have provided Frederic with a comfortable upbringing and access to high-quality education. He attended Eton College, one of the most prestigious schools in England, which was typically reserved for the children of the elite. His family's wealth and social standing would have also afforded him a comfortable home and living conditions.

Inherited privileges would have included his family's wealth, social connections, and access to education. His family's status would have also protected him from many of the hardships faced by those in lower social classes.
sources:
1. "Frederic William Maitland, Downing Professor of the Laws of England: A Biographical Sketch" by H.A.L. Fisher (1910)
2. "The Collected Papers of Frederic William Maitland, Vol. 3" edited by H.A.L. Fisher (1911)
3. "The Life and Letters of Leslie Stephen" by Frederic William Maitland

explanation: William Kingdon Clifford was born on May 4, 1845, in Exeter, England. His father, William Clifford, was a prominent attorney in the city, which suggests a middle-class standing. Clifford's mother, Fanny, was also from a middle-class background. Clifford's family had enough resources to provide him with a good education. He attended a private day school in Exeter before moving on to King's College in London, and then Trinity College, Cambridge. This level of education was typically not accessible to those below the middle class in the mid-19th century. There is no evidence to suggest that Clifford's family was part of the elite aristocracy or that they were subsistence-level laborers. The family's ability to afford a good education for Clifford and his father's profession as a lawyer suggest a comfortable middle-class existence.

explanation: Abraham de Moivre was born in Vitry-le-François in Champagne, France, in 1667. His father, Daniel de Moivre, was a surgeon who wanted his son to follow in his footsteps. This suggests that the family was not of the elite class, as the profession of surgery was not typically associated with the nobility. However, they were also not subsistence-level, as the profession required a certain level of education and skill. The family was likely of the middle class, as they had enough resources to provide Abraham with a good education. He was initially educated at home before being sent to the Protestant Academy at Sedan, indicating that his family had the means to afford such an education. However, the revocation of the Edict of Nantes in 1685 forced the family to flee to London, suggesting that they did not have the political power or influence to protect themselves, further supporting the classification of middle class.
sources: "Abraham de Moivre: Setting the Stage for Classical Probability and Its Applications" by David R. Bellhouse; "The Doctrine of Chances: Probabilistic Aspects of Gambling" by Stewart N. Ethier.

explanation: Henry Home, later known as Lord Kames, was born in Kames, Berwickshire, Scotland around 1696. His father, George Home, was a small landowner, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The Homes were not wealthy aristocrats, but they were not subsistence laborers either. They owned land and had a certain level of social standing in their community. Henry Home's access to education was likely due to his family's middle-class status, as he studied law in Edinburgh, but there is no evidence to suggest that his family was wealthy enough to provide him with a high level of inherited privilege. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, typical of a middle-class family of the time.
sources: "Henry Home, Lord Kames," The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (Winter 2016 Edition), Edward N. Zalta (ed.), URL = <https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/win2016/entries/kames/>.

explanation: Gertrude Jekyll was born in London in 1843 to a family of middle-class standing. Her father, Edward Joseph Hill Jekyll, was a retired Captain from the Grenadier Guards, a prestigious regiment in the British Army, and her mother, Julia Hammersley, came from a family with a military background. The Jekyll family was not part of the aristocracy, but they were well-off and had a comfortable lifestyle. They lived in a large house in Bramley, Surrey, which suggests a certain level of wealth and social standing. Gertrude was the fifth of seven children, and she received a good education, which was not common for women at that time, indicating that her family had the means to provide for her education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Jekyll family was part of the elite ruling class or nobility.
sources: "Gertrude Jekyll: A Vision of Garden and Wood" by Judith B. Tankard and Michael R. Toomey; "Gertrude Jekyll at Munstead Wood" by Martin Wood; "Gertrude Jekyll: Her Art Restored at Upton Grey" by Rosamund Wallinger.

explanation: Sir Henry William Bunbury, 7th Baronet, was born into the Bunbury Baronetcy, a title in the Baronetage of England. His father, Sir William Bunbury, 5th Baronet, was a member of the British aristocracy, and his mother, Eleanor, was the daughter of Sir George Armytage, 2nd Baronet, another aristocratic family. This indicates that Henry Bunbury was born into the elite class of the late 18th century United Kingdom. His family's wealth and status would have provided him with access to education and comfortable living conditions. The Bunbury family owned the Stanney Hall estate in Cheshire, which would have been Henry's childhood home. As a member of the aristocracy, he would have inherited certain privileges, such as social connections and potential political influence.
sources: The Baronetage of England, Volume 1 by Rev. William Betham (1801); The History of the County Palatine and City of Chester by George Ormerod (1819).

explanation: Anne Isabella Thackeray Ritchie was born into an elite family. Her father, William Makepeace Thackeray, was a renowned novelist and a member of the upper-middle class, which would have provided her with a comfortable upbringing. Her mother, Isabella Gethin Shawe, was also from a well-off family. Thackeray's family had a history of involvement in the East India Company, which was a significant source of wealth and prestige during this period. Anne Isabella was educated by her father, indicating that she had access to a high level of education not typically available to those outside the elite class. The family lived in a large house in Kensington, further indicating their wealth and high social standing.
sources: "William Makepeace Thackeray: A Biography," Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "Anne Thackeray Ritchie: Journals and Letters," edited by Abigail Burnham Bloom and John Maynard.

explanation: Charles de Saint-Évremond, born Charles Marguetel de Saint-Denis, seigneur de Saint-Évremond, was born into a noble family in France, not the United Kingdom, around 1613. His father, Guillaume Marguetel, was a knight and lord of Saint-Évremond, indicating a high social standing. The title of "seigneur" or lord suggests that the family had significant wealth and land ownership. explanation: William Gilpin was born in 1724 in Cumberland, England. His father, Captain John Bernard Gilpin, was a soldier and a landowner, which suggests a middle-class background. The Gilpin family had a long history in Cumberland, owning lands and properties, which indicates a certain level of wealth and stability. However, they were not part of the nobility or ruling class, which rules out the elite classification. William Gilpin was educated at Queen's College, Oxford, which suggests his family had the means to provide him with a good education, a privilege typically associated with the middle class during this period. explanation: Joseph Nollekens was born in London in 1737 to a family of Flemish origin. His father, Joseph Francis Nollekens, was a painter from Antwerp who had moved to London. The elder Nollekens was a moderately successful artist, which suggests that the family was not impoverished but also not part of the elite. The fact that Joseph Nollekens was able to study art from a young age suggests that his family had enough resources to provide him with an education, a privilege not available to the subsistence class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or that they had any significant social standing. The family lived in Dean Street, Soho, which was a respectable but not particularly affluent area of London at the time.

individual_name: Willem van de Velde the Elder
explanation: Willem van de Velde the Elder was born in Leiden, in the Dutch Republic, around 1611. His father, Hans van de Velde, was a skipper, which suggests a middle-class background. The family was not of noble lineage or extreme wealth, but they were not impoverished either. The occupation of skipper would have provided a steady income and a comfortable living. It's also worth noting that Willem van de Velde the Elder was able to pursue an apprenticeship in art under Simon de Vlieger in Rotterdam, which indicates that his family had the means to support his education. However, there's no evidence to suggest that he was born into a family of significant wealth or high social standing.

explanation: Luigi Arditi was born in Crescentino, Piedmont, Italy, not the United Kingdom. His birth year is generally accepted as 1822. Arditi's father was a violinist and conductor, which suggests a middle-class background, as these professions required a certain level of skill and education. The family's wealth at the time of Arditi's birth and childhood is not well-documented, but given his father's profession, it is likely they were not impoverished. Arditi received a good education, studying music at the Conservatory of Milan, which suggests his family had the means to support his education. There is no evidence to suggest that Arditi was born into the elite class or that he experienced significant inherited privileges or disadvantages. explanation: Thomas Telford was born in Westerkirk, Scotland in 1757 to a family of shepherds. His father, John Telford, died shortly after his birth, leaving his mother, Janet Jackson, to raise him in poverty. Telford's early life was marked by hardship and he received little formal education. His mother was unable to afford schooling, so he was mostly self-taught. He began working as a shepherd and later apprenticed as a stonemason, which were common jobs for people of lower social classes during this period. His family lived in a small, rural cottage, indicative of their low social and economic status.
sources: "Thomas Telford, 1757–1834" by L.T.C. Rolt, "The Life of Thomas Telford; Civil Engineer with an Introductory History of Roads and Travelling in Great Britain" by Samuel Smiles.

explanation: William Daniell was born in 1769 in Kingston upon Thames, England. His father was a coffee house keeper, which would have placed the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the late 18th century United Kingdom. This occupation would have provided a stable income and a comfortable living, but not to the extent of the elite class. explanation: Thomas Carew was born into a wealthy and influential family. His father, Sir Matthew Carew, was a Master in Chancery, and his mother, Alice Ingpenny, was a wealthy heiress. This suggests that the family had significant wealth and social standing at the time of his birth. Furthermore, Carew was educated at Merton College, Oxford, which was a privilege typically reserved for the elite class during this period. explanation: Alice Meynell was born Alice Christiana Gertrude Thompson in Barnes, London, in 1847. explanation: Adelaide Anne Procter was born on October 30, 1825, in London, England. Her father, Bryan Waller Procter (who also went by the pen name Barry Cornwall), was a well-known poet and lawyer, and her mother, Anne Skepper Procter, was a homemaker. The Procter family was well-respected in literary circles, and they were friends with Charles Dickens, a famous author. This suggests that Adelaide was born into a middle-class family with a comfortable lifestyle. Her father's profession as a lawyer indicates a level of education and income that would typically be associated with the middle class during this period. Furthermore, Adelaide's own education, which included learning several languages and music, suggests that her family had the means to provide her with a good education, a privilege often associated with the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Procters were part of the elite or ruling class, nor were they struggling for subsistence.
sources: "Adelaide Anne Procter: A Biography" by Jean Ingelow, "The Letters of Charles Dickens" by Charles Dickens, "The Life of Bryan Waller Procter (Barry Cornwall)" by Charles Dickens Jr.

explanation: Samuel Cooper was born in London, England, around 1609. However, there is no record of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.

explanation: John Webber was born in London around 1752. His father, Abraham Wäber, was a sculptor from Switzerland who had moved to London. The profession of sculpting, especially in a city like London, would have required a certain level of skill and craftsmanship, suggesting that the family was not subsistence level. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite or nobility. sources: The Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004; The Royal Academy of Arts: A Complete Dictionary of Contributors and their work from its foundation in 1769 to 1904, Volume VIII, by Algernon Graves.

explanation: Humphry Repton was born in Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk, England in 1752. explanation: Ebenezer Howard was born in Fore Street, City of London in 1850. His father, Ebenezer Howard Sr., was a baker and confectioner by trade, which would place the family within the middle class according to the given typology. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They were able to provide a basic education for Howard, as he attended a local school until the age of 15. explanation: Francis Hayman was born in Exeter, Devon, England around 1708. His father was a clergyman, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. There is no evidence to suggest that Hayman's family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume they were of average means for their social class. explanation: George Hayter was born in London in 1792 to Charles Hayter, an artist and miniature painter who was appointed Painter of Miniatures and Portraits to Princess Charlotte. His mother, Martha Stevenson, was also an artist. This suggests that the family was of the middle class, as they were skilled artisans. There is no evidence to suggest that they were particularly wealthy or impoverished. George Hayter's access to education was likely due to his family background, as his father was able to provide him with an artistic education. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his parents' occupations, it is likely that they were comfortable but not luxurious. explanation: William Drummond of Hawthornden was born into a family of Scottish nobility. His father, Sir John Drummond, was a Gentleman Usher to King James VI of Scotland (later also James I of England), a position of considerable prestige and influence at the royal court. This indicates that the Drummond family was part of the ruling class. William's mother, Susannah Fowler, was the daughter of a wealthy merchant and alderman of London, further indicating their high social standing. The family's wealth and status would have provided William with a comfortable early life and access to education. He was educated at the Royal High School of Edinburgh, a privilege typically reserved for the elite. His family's home, Hawthornden Castle, was a significant property, indicating substantial wealth.
sources: "William Drummond of Hawthornden" by Masson, David (1873); "The Poems of William Drummond of Hawthornden" by William Drummond, L. E. Kastner (1913); "The Dictionary of National Biography" by Smith, George (1885-1900).

explanation: William De Morgan was born into a middle-class family. His father, Augustus De Morgan, was a mathematician and logician who held the position of the first professor of mathematics at the University College London. His mother, Sophia Elizabeth De Morgan, was a writer and spiritualist. The family was not of the aristocracy or nobility, but they were well-educated and had a comfortable lifestyle, which is indicative of a middle-class status. William De Morgan was able to attend University College School, indicating that his family had the means to provide him with a good education.

explanation: George Edmund Street was born in Woodford, Essex, England, on June 20, 1824. His father, Thomas Street, was a solicitor, a profession that would have placed the family firmly in the middle class during the 19th century. The family was not of aristocratic lineage, nor were they laborers or peasants. The profession of solicitor would have provided a comfortable income, allowing for a decent standard of living and access to education. sources: "George Edmund Street: A Victorian Architect in Berkshire" by Pevsner, N. (1966); "The Life and Work of George Edmund Street" by Arthur Edmund Street (1888).

explanation: Mary Russell Mitford was born on December 16, 1787, in Alresford, Hampshire, England. Her father, George Mitford, was a physician, which was a profession typically associated with the middle class during this period. Her mother, Mary Russell, was the daughter of a successful draper, which also suggests a middle-class background. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. George Mitford had a penchant for extravagant spending and gambling, which often strained the family's finances. Despite these financial difficulties, Mary received a good education, suggesting that the family had enough resources to prioritize her learning. This is further evidence of their middle-class status, as education was often a privilege of the upper and middle classes in the late 18th century.
sources: "Mary Russell Mitford", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "Mary Russell Mitford: The Tragedy of a Blue Stocking", by Marjorie B. Bailey.

explanation: Francis Danby was born in County Wexford, Ireland, in 1793. His father, James Danby, was a farmer and a mill owner, which suggests a middle-class background. The family was not part of the aristocracy, nor were they laborers or peasants. They owned land and a business, which were typical characteristics of the middle class during this period. Francis Danby's early education is not well-documented, but his artistic talent was recognized and nurtured from a young age, suggesting that his family had the resources to support his development in this area. The family's wealth, however, was significantly reduced due to a series of unfortunate events, including a fire that destroyed their mill. Despite this setback, the family's initial status and occupation place them within the middle class.

explanation: Alexander Bain was born in Watten, Caithness, Scotland, in June 1811. His parents were George Bain, a small crofter, and Margaret Taylor. His family was poor and he was the youngest of eight children. His father's occupation as a crofter, which involved small-scale food production for family use and possibly some trade, suggests that they belonged to the subsistence class. Bain's early education was limited to the parish school, and he had to work as a shepherd to contribute to the family income from a young age. His early life housing and living conditions were likely modest, given his family's limited means. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges.
sources: "Alexander Bain: A Life" by Kenneth L. Caneva, "The Life of Alexander Bain" by Alexander Sutherland.

explanation: John Smith was born in Willoughby, Lincolnshire, England around 1580. His father, George Smith, was a yeoman farmer and his mother, Alice Rickard Smith, was the daughter of a yeoman farmer. The term "yeoman" was used in England to denote a class of small landowners, a step below the gentry, who were free and could cultivate their own land. They were considered part of the middle class in the social structure of the time. Smith's family was not wealthy, but they were not poor either. They were able to provide him with an education, as he attended King Edward VI Grammar School in Louth from 1592-1595. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest, typical of a yeoman farmer's family.
sources: "John Smith (1580-1631)" by George C. Hill and George M. Hill, The Virginia Magazine of History and Biography, Vol. 77, No. 4 (Oct., 1969), pp. 387-388; "John Smith: English Explorer and Colonist" by Encyclopedia Britannica.

explanation: Rudolph Ackermann was born in Saxony, Germany, around 1764, before moving to the United Kingdom. His father was a coach builder, a skilled craft occupation that would have placed the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. The family would have had a moderate level of wealth, enough to provide for their needs and possibly some luxuries, but not to the extent of the elite class. As the son of a craftsman, Ackermann would have had access to education, likely learning his father's trade and possibly receiving a basic formal education. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable but not extravagant. There's no record of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Rudolph Ackermann" by J. G. Legrand in The Dictionary of National Biography; "Rudolph Ackermann, 1764-1834" by John Ford in The Book Collector.

explanation: John Lindley was born on February 5, 1799, in Catton, near Norwich, England. His father, George Lindley, was a nurseryman and pomologist, a profession that would classify him as a skilled craftsman, thus placing the family in the middle class. George Lindley was not wealthy, but he was able to provide for his family through his work. John Lindley's mother, Sarah Freestone, came from a family of farmers, which also places her in the middle class. Despite their modest means, the Lindley family valued education. George Lindley was a friend of Sir Joseph Banks, a famous botanist, and he was able to provide his son with some education in botany. This access to education, albeit limited, was due to the family's middle-class status and connections, not John Lindley's individual merit.
sources: "John Lindley 1799-1865: Gardener-Botanist and Pioneer Orchidologist" by William T. Stearn; "The Lindleys of Catton" by Joan M. Schwartz; "The Orchid Thief: A True Story of Beauty and Obsession" by Susan Orlean.

explanation: Charles Barry was born on 23 May 1795 in Westminster, London. His father, Walter Edward Barry, was a stationer and his mother, Sarah, was a housewife. The stationery business was a trade that required skill and knowledge, placing the Barry family in the middle class of the social structure. The family lived in a house on Bridge Street, which indicates a decent standard of living for the time. Barry was educated at a local private school until the age of 15, which suggests that his family had the means to afford a decent education for their children. However, there is no evidence of any inherited privileges or significant family wealth.
sources: "Charles Barry" by Alfred Barry, published in 1867; "The Life and Works of Sir Charles Barry, R.A., F.R.S." by Alfred Barry, published in 1867.

explanation: John Venn was born on August 4, 1834, in Hull, England, to Martha Sykes and Rev. Henry Venn. His father was a rector in the Church of England and his mother was the daughter of a wealthy merchant. This suggests that the Venn family was of the middle class, as they were neither aristocrats nor laborers. The fact that his father was a clergyman indicates a certain level of education and social standing, as does his mother's merchant family background. The family's wealth would have been modest but sufficient to provide a comfortable life and access to education. He later attended Highgate School and Gonville and Caius College, Cambridge, suggesting that his family had the means to afford a good education. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, reflecting the family's middle-class status. There is no evidence of inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "John Venn." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica, inc., February 26, 2021. "John Venn." Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy. Stanford University, August 4, 2004.

explanation: Allan Cunningham was born in Keir, Dumfriesshire, Scotland in 1784. His father was a land steward, a position that would have placed the family in the middle class. This occupation involved managing the day-to-day affairs of a large estate, which would have required a certain level of education and skill. The family was not wealthy, but they were not living in poverty either. explanation: Walter Besant was born in Portsmouth, England, in 1836. His father, William Besant, was a merchant and shipowner, which suggests a middle-class background. His mother, Sarah Besant, was the daughter of a wine merchant. The family's wealth and social standing would have been sufficient to provide Walter with a good education. He attended King's College, London, and later entered Christ's College, Cambridge. These educational opportunities suggest a middle-class upbringing, as they would have been beyond the reach of the subsistence class. sources: "Walter Besant", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "Walter Besant", Encyclopædia Britannica; "Walter Besant", The Cambridge History of English and American Literature.

explanation: Juliana Horatia Ewing was born on August 3, 1841, in Yorkshire, England. Her father, Alfred Gatty, was a vicar in the Church of England, a position that would have placed the family firmly within the middle class of the time. Her mother, Margaret Gatty, was a well-known children's author, which further supports their middle-class status. The family lived in Ecclesfield, where Alfred served as the vicar, and they would have had a comfortable, though not luxurious, lifestyle. Juliana and her siblings had access to education, likely through private tutors or small local schools, which was typical for middle-class children in the 19th century.
