sources: "Juliana Horatia Ewing and Her Books" by Horatia K. F. Gatty; "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" by H. C. G. Matthew and Brian Harrison.

explanation: Valentine Green was born in the town of Salford Priors, Warwickshire, England, around 1739. His father, Richard Green, was a farmer, which would have placed the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. Farming was a respectable occupation, and it was common for middle-class families to own or lease land for farming. There is no evidence to suggest that the Green family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they were of average means for their social class. Valentine Green was apprenticed to a local tailor at a young age, which suggests that his family had the resources to arrange this apprenticeship and that they valued skilled work. This further supports the classification of Green's family as middle class.
sources: "Valentine Green (1739–1813): A Biographical and Bibliographical Study" by Timothy Clayton, published in Print Quarterly, Vol. 7, No. 3 (September 1990), pp. 235-254.

explanation: The birth circumstances and family background of Thomas Dekker, an English Elizabethan dramatist and pamphleteer, are largely unknown. There is no definitive record of his parents' occupations, family wealth, access to education, early life housing and living conditions, or inherited privileges or disadvantages. The lack of these details makes it difficult to classify his social class at birth and during his childhood. It is known that he was born in London around 1572, but the specifics of his family and early life remain a mystery.
sources: The primary sources for information on Dekker are his own works, which do not provide clear evidence of his early life. Secondary sources, such as "Thomas Dekker: A Study" by Mary Leland Hunt, also do not provide definitive information on his birth circumstances and family background.

explanation: Robert Dodsley was born in 1703 in Mansfield, Nottinghamshire, England. His father, Robert Dodsley Sr., was a schoolmaster, but the family was not well-off. In fact, they were quite poor. Dodsley himself had little formal education, and he was apprenticed to a stocking weaver at a young age, indicating that his family was not able to provide him with a more prestigious or lucrative apprenticeship. His early life was marked by poverty and hardship, which suggests that his family belonged to the lower social class.
sources: "Robert Dodsley", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "Robert Dodsley: Poet, Publisher and Playwright", by Ralph A. Smith.

explanation: Frederick William Beechey was born into a family with a strong naval tradition. His father, Sir William Beechey, was a successful portrait painter who had many aristocratic patrons, indicating a degree of financial stability and social standing within the middle class. His mother, Anne Jessop, was also from a middle-class background. The Beechey family's access to education was likely due to their middle-class status, as Frederick and his brothers all pursued careers in the navy or the arts, suggesting they had access to the necessary training and education. Their housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, but not lavish, consistent with their middle-class status. There is no evidence of significant inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "The Life of Sir William Beechey, R.A." by William Roberts, "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" by H. C. G. Matthew and Brian Harrison.

explanation: Henry Briggs was born in Warleywood, Yorkshire, around 1561. His father, Thomas Briggs, was a substantial yeoman farmer, a position that would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the late 1500s in the United Kingdom. Yeoman farmers were typically landowners who farmed their own land and were considered part of the middle class, above laborers but below the gentry and nobility. They were often able to provide their children with some level of education, which is consistent with Briggs' early education at a grammar school in Halifax. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Briggs family was part of the elite or subsistence classes.
sources: "Henry Briggs (1561–1630): a pioneer of modern science" by J. A. Bennett, Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London (1981); "The Mathematical Practitioners of Tudor & Stuart England" by E. G. R. Taylor (1954).

explanation: Franciscus Junius was born in Heidelberg, Germany, in 1591, to a family of scholars and theologians. His father, Franciscus Junius the Elder, was a well-known Protestant theologian and professor at the University of Heidelberg. His mother, Johanna Lippius, was the daughter of a professor of theology. This suggests that the family was of a scholarly, middle-class background. They were not nobility or aristocrats, but they were also not laborers or peasants. The family's status would have provided Junius with access to education, but it's unlikely that they lived in opulence. The family's wealth and social standing would have been tied to the father's occupation as a professor, which would have provided a comfortable, but not extravagant, lifestyle.
sources: "Franciscus Junius F.F. and His Circle" by Rolf H. Bremmer Jr., "Franciscus Junius" by Anthony Grafton in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: Sir James Mackintosh was born in Aldourie, seven miles from Inverness, Scotland, in 1765. His father, Captain John Mackintosh, was a military officer, which suggests a middle-class status. The Mackintosh family was not part of the nobility, but they were not subsistence-level laborers either. James Mackintosh's access to education also indicates a middle-class upbringing. He was educated at home until the age of ten, after which he attended the grammar school in Aberdeen and later King's College, Aberdeen. This level of education was not typically accessible to subsistence-level families in the late 1700s. While we do not have specific details about the family's wealth or living conditions, the fact that Captain John Mackintosh could afford to send his son to school suggests a certain level of financial stability.
sources: "Sir James Mackintosh: Scottish Philosopher and Historian" by Encyclopaedia Britannica; "James Mackintosh" by Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: James Ferguson was born in 1710 in Rothiemay, Scotland, to a very poor family. His father was a day laborer and tenant farmer, which placed the family in the subsistence class. The family lived in a small, humble cottage, and they struggled to make ends meet. Ferguson's early education was minimal and informal, mostly taught by his father during the winter months when farm work was less demanding. There is no evidence of inherited privileges or advantages in his early life.
sources: "James Ferguson, 1710–1776" by Betty Hagglund, published by Ashgate Publishing, Ltd., 2007.

explanation: Mary Lamb was born in London in 1764 to John Lamb and Elizabeth Field. Her father, John Lamb, was a servant and a clerk. Her mother, Elizabeth Field, was a housekeeper. The family lived in humble circumstances, and their income was modest. Mary's early education was limited, likely due to her family's financial constraints. She was taught to read by her mother and may have had some basic schooling, but there is no evidence of a formal education. The family lived in a small house in the inner city, suggesting cramped and potentially unsanitary living conditions. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or advantages.
sources: "Mary Lamb", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "Charles Lamb and His Contemporaries" by Edmund Blunden; "The Works of Charles and Mary Lamb — Volume 2" by Charles Lamb and Mary Lamb.

explanation: George Colman the Elder was born in Florence, Italy, to Francis Colman, an Englishman who was a fellow of New College, Oxford, and later a resident in Florence. His father was a diplomat, serving as the British resident (essentially an ambassador) in Tuscany. This suggests that the family had a certain level of wealth and social standing, but they were not part of the nobility or ruling class. George Colman the Elder was educated at Westminster School in London, which was a privilege typically reserved for the middle and upper classes. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, but not opulent. There is no evidence to suggest that he inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "George Colman, the Elder." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/George-Colman-the-Elder

explanation: William Wycherley was born to a family of the gentry class, which was a social class in England during the 17th century that was below the nobility but above the commoners. His father, Daniel Wycherley, was a Shropshire landowner, which indicates a level of wealth and social standing that would place them in the middle class according to the provided typology. The family's wealth allowed William to receive a good education, as he was sent to France by his father to become a Catholic, and later attended Queen's College, Oxford, and the Inner Temple, which was a professional body that provided legal education. This access to education, which was likely due to his family's wealth and social standing, further supports the classification of his birth and childhood social class as middle class.
sources:
- "Wycherley, William (1641–1716), playwright" by Peter Dixon, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.
- "The Country Wife" by William Wycherley, Introduction by Peter Dixon, Oxford World's Classics.

explanation: Richard Payne Knight was born into a wealthy and influential family. His father, Thomas Knight, was a landowner and ironmaster, owning several ironworks and extensive lands in Shropshire and Herefordshire. This wealth and influence would have placed the Knight family firmly within the elite class of the late 18th century United Kingdom. Richard's early life would have been characterized by a high standard of living, with access to quality education and housing due to his family's wealth. He was educated at home by a private tutor, a privilege typically reserved for the elite class. His family's wealth and social standing would have also provided him with numerous inherited privileges.
sources:
- "Richard Payne Knight: The Twilight of Virtuosity" by Michael Clarke, Journal of the Warburg and Courtauld Institutes, Vol. 51 (1988), pp. 127-149.
- "The Knights of Downton Castle" by John Martin Robinson, Country Life, Vol. 189, No. 24 (1995), pp. 70-73.

explanation: Elizabeth Eastlake, born Elizabeth Rigby in 1809, was the daughter of Dr. Edward Rigby, a physician, and his second wife, Anne Palgrave. Her father's profession as a physician indicates that the family was not of the elite class, but rather of the middle class, as medicine was a respected profession but not associated with the aristocracy. The family was well-off enough to afford a good education for Elizabeth, who was well-read and multilingual, suggesting a certain level of wealth and access to resources. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the ruling class or nobility, nor that they were subsistence-level laborers or peasants. Therefore, the most accurate classification would be middle class.
sources: "Lady Eastlake," by Marion Lochhead, published by John Murray (1961); "Elizabeth Rigby, Lady Eastlake," by Julie Sheldon, published by Liverpool University Press (2009).

explanation: Francis Turner Palgrave was born into a middle-class family. His father, Sir Francis Palgrave, was a notable historian, antiquarian, and Deputy Keeper of the Public Record Office. This suggests that the family had a certain level of financial stability and social standing, typical of the middle class. His father's occupation also implies that Francis Turner Palgrave had access to education because of his family background. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Palgrave family was part of the elite or ruling class, nor were they subsistence-level laborers or peasants. Therefore, it is reasonable to classify Francis Turner Palgrave's birth and childhood social class as middle class.
sources: "Francis Turner Palgrave." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Francis-Turner-Palgrave. "Sir Francis Palgrave." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Francis-Palgrave.

explanation: John Gibson Lockhart was born in 1794 in Cambusnethan, Lanarkshire, Scotland. His father, Reverend John Lockhart, was a minister of the Church of Scotland, a position that would have placed the family in the middle class of the time. His mother, Elizabeth Gibson, was the daughter of a prosperous Glasgow merchant, which further supports the middle-class classification. The family would have had a comfortable living, but not the wealth or status of the elite class. Lockhart's access to education was also indicative of a middle-class upbringing. He was educated at the University of Glasgow and Balliol College, Oxford. This level of education was not typically available to those of the subsistence class, but was also not exclusive to the elite, as many middle-class families valued education and could afford to send their children to university.
sources: "John Gibson Lockhart: A Biographical Sketch" by Andrew Lang; "John Gibson Lockhart" by Philip Hobsbaum; "The Oxford Companion to English Literature" by Dinah Birch.

explanation: Algernon Freeman-Mitford, 1st Baron Redesdale, was born into a family of high social standing. His father, Henry Reveley Mitford, was a civil servant, serving as the Deputy Auditor of the Civil List. His mother, Georgiana Jemima Ashburnham, was the daughter of the 3rd Earl of Ashburnham, a member of the British peerage. This indicates that the family was part of the ruling class or nobility. The Mitford family was also known to have significant wealth, owning large estates in Northumberland. Algernon's access to education was also a result of his family's status; he was educated at Eton College, a prestigious school typically attended by the British elite. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, given his family's wealth and status. As a member of the British aristocracy, Algernon would have inherited certain privileges, such as social connections and opportunities for advancement.
sources:
1. "The Mitfords: Letters between Six Sisters" by Charlotte Mosley
2. "The Peerage, Baronetage, and Knightage of Great Britain and Ireland" by Charles Roger Dod
3. "Eton College Register, 1841-1850" by Eton College

explanation: Thomas Graham was born in Glasgow, Scotland in 1805. His father, James Graham, was a successful merchant, which places the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The family's wealth provided Thomas with access to education, as he was educated at home by private tutors before attending the University of Glasgow. This suggests that the family had enough resources to afford private education, a privilege not commonly accessible to lower classes at the time. The family's ability to support Thomas's education and the father's occupation as a merchant suggest a comfortable middle-class upbringing.
sources: "Thomas Graham." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Thomas-Graham-British-chemist.

explanation: George Francis Lyon was born into a middle-class family. His father, also named George Lyon, was a captain in the Royal Navy, which suggests a level of professional skill and status, typical of the middle class during this period. There is no evidence to suggest that the Lyon family was part of the elite aristocracy or nobility, nor that they were subsistence-level laborers or peasants. The fact that George Francis Lyon was able to join the Royal Navy as a volunteer in 1810 suggests that his family had some resources and connections, as this was not an opportunity typically available to those from lower social classes. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or that Lyon had access to an elite education because of his family background.
sources: "George Francis Lyon" by J.K. Laughton, Dictionary of National Biography, 1885-1900, Volume 34.

explanation: Elias Ashmole was born in Lichfield, Staffordshire, England in 1617. His father, Simon Ashmole, was a saddler, which was a skilled trade occupation. This would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. His mother, Anne Ashmole, came from a family of good social standing in Lichfield. Elias Ashmole was able to attend grammar school in Lichfield, suggesting that his family had the means to provide him with an education. However, his father died when Elias was relatively young, and the family may have faced financial difficulties as a result. Despite this, Elias was able to continue his education, suggesting that the family had some resources or support from the community.
sources: "Elias Ashmole: His Autobiographical and Historical Notes, His Correspondence, and Other Contemporary Sources Relating to His Life and Work" by Elias Ashmole, C.H. Josten (Editor).

explanation: Henry Walter Bates was born in Leicester, England in 1825. His father, Henry Bates, was a hosiery manufacturer, a profession that would have placed the family in the middle class during the 19th century. The hosiery industry was a significant part of Leicester's economy at the time, and it would have provided a comfortable living for the Bates family. Bates' mother, Sarah, was a housewife, which was typical for women of the middle class during this period. Bates was educated at local grammar schools, indicating that his family had the means to provide him with a basic education, another characteristic of the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Bates family was particularly wealthy or that they had any significant social standing beyond their local community. Bates' early life housing and living conditions would have been typical for a middle-class family in 19th-century England: comfortable but not luxurious.
sources: "The Naturalist on the River Amazons" by Henry Walter Bates; "Henry Walter Bates: Explorer-Naturalist" by F. Haber.

explanation: Allan Ramsay was born in Leadhills, Lanarkshire, Scotland, around 1686. His father, John Ramsay, was a lead miner and the superintendent of the mines at Leadhills, owned by the Earl of Hopetoun. This suggests that the family was not part of the elite or subsistence classes, but rather part of the middle class, as John Ramsay held a skilled occupation. Allan Ramsay's mother, Alice Bower, was the daughter of a mine agent. The family's wealth was likely modest but sufficient, given John Ramsay's position. Allan Ramsay received some formal education, as he attended the parish school of Crawford, indicating that his family had the means to provide him with an education. The family likely lived in housing provided by the Earl of Hopetoun, which would have been modest but adequate for a family of their social standing.
sources: "Allan Ramsay (1686–1758)" by Murray Pittock, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "The Life and Works of Allan Ramsay" by Oliphant Smeaton.

explanation: Isaac Oliver was born around 1556 in Rouen, France, to a Huguenot family. His father, Peter Oliver, was a skilled goldsmith, a profession that would have placed the family within the middle class according to the social structure of the time. The family moved to England to escape religious persecution in France, suggesting they had the means to do so. Isaac Oliver's access to education can be inferred from his later work as a miniaturist, a profession that required a high level of skill and training, likely provided by his father. However, there is no specific evidence of his early life housing and living conditions, or of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Isaac Oliver." The National Portrait Gallery, London; "Isaac Oliver." The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "Isaac Oliver." The Grove Dictionary of Art.

explanation: Nicholas Rowe was born into a family of considerable social standing. His father, John Rowe, was a barrister and serjeant-at-law, a prestigious legal position in the English legal system. His mother, Elizabeth, was the daughter of Jasper Edwards, a judge. This indicates that Rowe was born into a family of legal professionals, which would place them in the elite class of the late 17th century England. Rowe's family wealth and status would have provided him with access to education and comfortable living conditions. His father's position as a serjeant-at-law would have also granted the family certain privileges, such as a higher social standing and potential connections within the legal and political spheres.
sources: "The Works of Nicholas Rowe, Esq" by Nicholas Rowe, "The Oxford Companion to English Literature" by Margaret Drabble, "The Cambridge History of English and American Literature" by A.W. Ward and A.R. Waller.

explanation: Frederick Sandys was born in Norwich, England in 1829 to Anthony Sands, a minor landscape painter, and his wife Mary. The family later added a 'y' to their surname. His father's occupation as a painter suggests that the family belonged to the middle class, as they were not part of the aristocracy, but also not subsistence laborers. The fact that Frederick and his brothers were all able to pursue careers in the arts suggests that the family had some level of financial stability and access to education, further supporting their middle-class status. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were particularly wealthy or had any inherited privileges.
sources: "Frederick Sandys: A Catalogue Raisonné" by Betty Elzea, "The Dictionary of British Artists 1880-1940" by J. Johnson and A. Greutzner.

explanation: George Cattermole was born in Dickleburgh, Norfolk, England in 1800. His father, George Cattermole Sr., was a miller, a profession that would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. Milling was a skilled trade, and while it did not provide the wealth of the elite, it would have provided a stable income for the family. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they lived a comfortable, middle-class lifestyle. Cattermole's early access to education is not well-documented, but his later career as an artist and illustrator suggests he may have had some early training or exposure to the arts, which would have been more accessible to middle-class families. His early life housing and living conditions are also not well-documented, but as the son of a miller, it is likely that he lived in a comfortable, if not luxurious, home. There is no evidence to suggest that Cattermole inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "George Cattermole." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, May 2009.

explanation: Anna Atkins was born in Tonbridge, Kent, England in 1799 to a prominent family. Her father, John George Children, was a respected scientist, chemist, and zoologist. He was also a Fellow of the Royal Society, one of the oldest scientific societies in the world, and later served as its Secretary. This suggests that the family had a high social standing and access to resources. Anna's mother, Hester Anne Children, died during her birth, and Anna was raised by her father, who provided her with an unusually scientific education for a woman of her time. This suggests that the family had the means to provide a good education, a privilege often reserved for the elite class. The family's wealth and status would have also provided Anna with a comfortable early life housing and living conditions.
sources: "Anna Atkins: Google Doodle Celebrates 216th Birthday of Botanist who Produced First Photographic Book" by Kashmira Gander, The Independent, March 16, 2015; "Anna Atkins" by Larry J. Schaaf, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, 2004.

explanation: Luke Fildes was born in Liverpool, England in 1843. His father, James Fildes, was a merchant seaman, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. His mother, Mary Fildes, was a political activist and a member of the Chartist movement, which was a working-class movement for political reform in Britain. However, her political activism does not necessarily reflect the family's economic status. After his father's death, Fildes was raised by his mother in London. He was able to attend the Mechanics Institute of Liverpool, which suggests that his family had enough resources to provide him with an education. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation and his access to education, it is reasonable to classify his birth and childhood social class as middle class.
sources: "Sir Samuel Luke Fildes." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Samuel-Luke-Fildes; "Luke Fildes." Tate. https://www.tate.org.uk/art/artists/luke-fildes-176.

explanation: Margaret Gatty was born on 3 June 1809 in Burnham, Essex, England. Her father, the Reverend Alexander John Scott, was a chaplain and confidant to Lord Nelson, a notable figure in the British Navy. This suggests that the family was not of the elite class, as clergy were typically considered part of the middle class during this period. However, they were also not subsistence class, as the position of a chaplain, especially to a figure like Lord Nelson, would have provided a comfortable living. Margaret's mother, Margaretta Sarah Scott, was the daughter of a Royal Navy captain, further suggesting a middle-class background. Margaret Gatty had access to education, which was not common for lower classes in the early 19th century. Her father was her primary educator, teaching her Latin, Greek, and natural history, among other subjects. This level of education suggests a middle-class upbringing, as education was often a privilege of the middle and upper classes during this period.
sources: "Margaret Gatty (1809–1873): Marine Biologist and Writer for Children" by Teresa Cremin, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, May 2009.

explanation: George Macartney, 1st Earl Macartney, was born into the Irish gentry, a social class that was part of the ruling elite in Ireland. His father, George Macartney, was a landowner, which was a sign of wealth and high social standing during this period. His mother, Elizabeth Winder, also came from a well-to-do family. Macartney's family had the financial means to provide him with a good education. He was educated at Trinity College, Dublin, which was one of the most prestigious educational institutions in Ireland at the time. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, given his family's wealth and social standing. As a member of the gentry, Macartney would have inherited certain privileges, such as access to education and opportunities for social advancement.
sources:
1. "Macartney, George, first earl Macartney (1737–1806)", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press.
2. "The Macartney Embassy: The British Mission to China, 1792-1794", by J.L. Cranmer-Byng, published by Manchester University Press.

explanation: Nathaniel Dance-Holland was born into a family of architects, which was a skilled profession during the 18th century in the United Kingdom. His father, George Dance the Elder, was a well-known architect and city surveyor. This suggests that the family had a comfortable income and a certain social standing, characteristic of the middle class. Nathaniel's access to education can also be inferred from his family background. He was able to study at the St. Martin's Lane Academy, a prominent art institution of the time, indicating that his family had the means to support his education. The family's ability to send Nathaniel to Italy for further studies also points to their middle-class status. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they belonged to the elite class, as there is no record of them holding any titles or owning significant wealth.

explanation: Charles Knight was born in Windsor, Berkshire, England in 1791. His father, also named Charles Knight, was a bookseller and printer, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The elder Knight was known for his high-quality work and had a successful business, indicating a level of financial stability and wealth consistent with the middle class. The younger Knight was educated at a private school in Windsor, suggesting that the family had the means to afford a good education for their children. The family lived in a house in Windsor, which further supports their middle-class status. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.

- "Charles Knight." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004.

explanation: James V of Scotland was born into the ruling class of Scotland, as he was the only legitimate son of King James IV of Scotland and his wife, Margaret Tudor. His father was the King of Scotland, a position of significant power and influence, and his mother was the daughter of King Henry VII of England, making her a member of the English nobility. This would have placed James V in the elite class at his birth. The family's wealth would have been substantial, given their royal status. James V would have had access to the best education available at the time, due to his family background. His early life housing and living conditions would have been in royal palaces, far above the standard of the time. As a member of the royal family, he would have inherited significant privileges, including the right to succeed to the throne.
sources: "James V: The Personal Rule, 1528-1542" by Jamie Cameron, "The Kings & Queens of Scotland" by Richard Oram, "The Oxford Companion to British History" edited by John Cannon.

explanation: Frances Anne Kemble was born into a family of actors, which places her in the middle class according to the typology provided. Her father, Charles Kemble, was a well-known actor and her mother, Maria Theresa Kemble, was a successful actress as well. The Kemble family was one of the most important theatrical families in England during the late 18th and early 19th centuries. Although they were not aristocrats, they were not subsistence level either. They had a certain level of wealth and social standing due to their successful careers in the theatre. Frances was educated by her parents and had access to books and other educational resources due to her family's profession. Her early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious.

explanation: Sarah Siddons was born in Brecon, Wales in 1755 to Roger Kemble and Sarah Ward. Her parents were actors and managers of a traveling theater company, a profession that was not highly regarded or well paid at the time. The family was large, with twelve children, which would have further strained their resources. The Kemble family was known for their dedication to the theater, but they were not wealthy or high status. Sarah's education would have been minimal, as her family's nomadic lifestyle and limited resources would not have allowed for formal schooling. Her early life would have been spent in the company of actors and theater hands, living in whatever accommodations were available to a traveling troupe.

explanation: Hannah More was born in 1745 in Stapleton, Bristol, England. She was the fourth of five daughters in her family. Her father, Jacob More, was a schoolmaster in Bristol, which suggests a middle-class background. He was able to provide his daughters with a good education, which was not common for girls at the time, further indicating a certain level of financial stability and social standing. The family was not part of the aristocracy, nor were they laborers or peasants. They lived in a comfortable home and had access to resources, but they were not wealthy.

explanation: William Hunter was born in Long Calderwood, East Kilbride, Scotland in 1718. His father, John Hunter, was a local landowner and successful farmer, which would place the family in the middle class according to the given typology. The family was not part of the nobility or ruling class, but they were also not subsistence laborers or peasants. William Hunter's early access to education was likely due to his family's relative wealth and status. His mother, Agnes Paul, was known to have a keen interest in education, and she ensured that all her children, including William, received a good education. This is evidenced by the fact that William attended the University of Glasgow at a young age, a privilege likely afforded by his family's resources. The family's living conditions would have been comfortable for the time, given their status as landowners and successful farmers.
sources: "William Hunter (1718–1783): anatomist, physician, man-midwife." Journal of Medical Biography, 2007. "William Hunter and the Hunterian Museum in Glasgow, 1807-2007." Edinburgh University Press, 2008.

explanation: Amelia Edwards was born in London in 1831 to parents who were part of the middle class. Her father was an ex-Bank of England employee and her mother was from an Irish family. They were not wealthy, but they were not poor either. They were able to provide Edwards with a good education, which was a privilege not many girls had at that time. Edwards was educated at home by her mother, which suggests that her family had enough resources to afford not sending her to work at a young age. Her father's occupation at the Bank of England suggests a level of financial stability and middle-class status. The family lived in a comfortable home in Westbury, indicating a middle-class lifestyle.
sources: "A Thousand Miles Up the Nile" by Amelia Edwards; "Amelia Edwards: Traveller, Novelist and Egyptologist" by Joan Rees.

explanation: Alexander Mackenzie was born in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis in the Outer Hebrides of Scotland around 1764. His father, Kenneth 'Corc' Mackenzie, was a middle-class merchant and a native of Ross-shire. His mother was Mary MacIver, who also belonged to a middle-class family. Mackenzie's father died when he was young, and his mother moved the family to New York City in the American colonies. After the American Revolutionary War broke out, they returned to Scotland, where Mackenzie received a basic education. The family's ability to move and provide education for their children suggests a middle-class status, as does the occupation of Mackenzie's father as a merchant.
sources: "Alexander Mackenzie (explorer)." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc., n.d. Web. 20 Dec. 2021. ; "Alexander Mackenzie." Dictionary of Canadian Biography. University of Toronto/Université Laval, 2003. Web. 20 Dec. 2021.

explanation: Thomas Arnold was born on June 13, 1795, in West Cowes, Isle of Wight, England. His father, William Arnold, was a customs officer, a profession that would have placed the family in the middle class. His mother, Martha Delafield, came from a similar social background. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. Arnold's parents were able to provide him with a basic education, which was a privilege not available to all children at the time. Arnold was sent to Warminster School in Wiltshire, and later, Winchester College, indicating that the family had enough resources to invest in their son's education. The family lived in a comfortable, though not luxurious, home in West Cowes. Arnold did not inherit any titles or significant wealth, but he did have the advantage of a stable, middle-class upbringing.
sources:

explanation: Sir William Temple, 1st Baronet, was born into a family of significant social standing. His father, Sir John Temple, was the Master of the Rolls in Ireland, a high-ranking judicial office. His mother, Martha Harrison, came from a well-established gentry family. This indicates that Temple was born into the upper echelons of society, with access to wealth, education, and opportunities that would have been unavailable to those of lower social classes. His family's wealth and status would have provided him with a comfortable early life, likely in a large, well-maintained home. His access to education was also a result of his family's status, as he was educated at Bishop Stortford School in Hertfordshire and later at Emmanuel College, Cambridge. These factors all point to a birth and childhood within the elite class.

explanation: Amelia Opie was born Amelia Alderson in Norwich, England in 1769. Her father, James Alderson, was a physician, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The Aldersons were known to be a part of the intellectual and social circles of Norwich, indicating a certain level of social standing and access to education. Amelia was educated at home, which was not uncommon for girls of her time and social class. explanation: Robert Barclay was born into a family of Scottish nobility. His father, Colonel David Barclay, was a wealthy landowner who had served in the Swedish army before inheriting his father's estates. His mother, Katherine Gordon, was also from a noble family. The Barclays were part of the landed gentry, owning significant estates in Scotland, which would have provided them with a substantial income. Robert Barclay's early life would have been one of privilege, with access to education and comfortable living conditions. His family's wealth and social standing would have provided him with many advantages in his early life.
sources: "The Life of Robert Barclay" by Joseph Gurney Bevan, "The Quakers in Great Britain and America: The Religious and Political History of the Society of Friends from the Seventeenth to the Twentieth Century" by Frederick Storrs Turner.

explanation: John Nash was born in Lambeth, south London, in 1752. His father was a Welsh millwright, a skilled craftsman who designs, builds, and repairs mills, which suggests that the family was of the middle class. The millwright profession was a respected trade during the 18th century, often requiring a formal apprenticeship and providing a stable income. This would have allowed Nash's family to maintain a comfortable lifestyle, but they were not part of the elite ruling class or nobility. There is no evidence to suggest that Nash's family was particularly wealthy or that he had access to a high level of education because of his family background. However, Nash did serve an apprenticeship with architect Robert Taylor, suggesting that his family had enough resources to secure this opportunity for him.
sources: "John Nash: A Complete Catalogue" by Michael Mansbridge; "John Nash and the Village Picturesque" by Geoffrey Tyack.

explanation: William Cavendish, 1st Duke of Newcastle, was born into a wealthy aristocratic family. His father, Sir Charles Cavendish, was a nobleman and a Member of Parliament. His mother, Catherine Ogle, was the 8th Baroness Ogle in her own right, which further solidifies the family's high social standing. The Cavendish family was one of the richest and most influential in England at the time of William's birth. They owned large estates, including the Hardwick Hall and Chatsworth House, indicating a high level of wealth and access to resources. William's privileged background would have granted him access to a high-quality education, which was typically reserved for the elite class during this period. His family's status would have also provided him with a comfortable living environment and numerous inherited privileges.
sources:
1. "The Life of William Cavendish, Duke of Newcastle, to which is Added the True Relation of My Birth, Breeding and Life" by Margaret Cavendish, Duchess of Newcastle-upon-Tyne.
2. "Cavendish, William, first duke of Newcastle upon Tyne (1593–1676)" by R. Malcolm Smuts, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. 
3. "The Building of Elizabethan and Jacobean England" by E. A. J. Honigmann.

explanation: Edward Maunde Thompson was born in Jamaica, the son of a clergyman, Reverend Edward Thompson. His father was a missionary for the Church of England, indicating a level of education and social standing associated with the middle class. While the family's wealth is not explicitly documented, the profession of his father suggests they were not subsistence level, but also not part of the elite ruling class. Thompson's access to education was likely due to his father's profession and social standing, as he attended the King's School in Canterbury, a well-regarded institution. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of a clergyman's family. There is no evidence of significant inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Edward Maunde Thompson and the British Museum." The Library, vol. s5-XXVII, no. 2, 1972, pp. 138–157. "Thompson, Sir Edward Maunde." Who's Who: An Annual Biographical Dictionary. 59th ed. London: Adam and Charles Black, 1907.

explanation: William Michael Rossetti was born into a middle-class family in London, England, in 1829. His father, Gabriele Rossetti, was an Italian political refugee who worked as a professor of Italian at King's College London. His mother, Frances Polidori, was the daughter of an Italian exile and a governess. The family was not wealthy, but they were educated and valued intellectual pursuits. William and his siblings, including the famous poet Dante Gabriel Rossetti, were home-schooled by their mother. The family lived in a modest home in London, and while they were not impoverished, they did not have the wealth or social standing of the elite class.
sources: "The Rossettis in Wonderland: A Victorian Family History" by Dinah Roe; "The Pre-Raphaelites: Their Lives in Letters and Diaries" by Jan Marsh; "The Rossetti Family: 1824-1854" by G. H. Fleming.

explanation:
Robert Southwell was born into a wealthy Catholic family of the English gentry. His father, Richard Southwell, was a landowner and his mother, Bridget Copley, was from a prominent Catholic family. The Southwells were part of the Norfolk gentry, owning a considerable amount of land and property. Robert's grandfather, Sir Richard Southwell, was a prominent courtier during the reign of Henry VIII, which indicates the family's high social standing. 

Robert was sent to Douai, France, and then to Rome for his education, which was a privilege only the elite could afford during that time. His family's wealth and status allowed him to receive a high-quality education from the Jesuit College in Rome, which was one of the most prestigious educational institutions of the time. 

His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, given his family's wealth and status. He would have grown up in a large manor house, surrounded by servants and with access to luxuries that were beyond the reach of the average person in the late 1500s.
sources:
- "Robert Southwell." The Catholic Encyclopedia. Vol. 14. New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1912.
- "Robert Southwell: A Saintly Influence." The Tablet, 2016.
- "Robert Southwell, S.J.: Saint, Poet, and Martyr." Studies: An Irish Quarterly Review,

explanation: James Justinian Morier was born to Isaac Morier, a Swiss-born merchant who had settled in England. Isaac Morier was a partner in the trading firm Morier, Howell, and Co., which dealt in commodities such as silk, indigo, and coffee. This suggests that the Morier family was part of the mercantile middle class. James's mother, Esther Morier, was the daughter of a London merchant, further supporting this classification. The family's wealth allowed James to receive a good education, as he was sent to Harrow School, a prestigious boarding school in London. However, there is no evidence that the Moriers were part of the aristocracy or had any inherited titles or privileges, suggesting that they were not part of the elite class.
sources: "James Morier, Esq." (1826). The Gentleman's Magazine, Volume 96, Part 2. p. 569; "Morier, James Justinian" (1894). Dictionary of National Biography. Volume 39. p. 253; "Isaac Morier" (n.d.). Legacies of British Slave-ownership database, University College London.

explanation: Samuel Rogers was born in Newington Green, London, in 1763 to Thomas Rogers and Mary Radford. His father, Thomas Rogers, was a successful banker, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the United Kingdom in the late 1700s. The banking profession was not part of the aristocracy, but it was a skilled occupation that provided a comfortable living. The family's wealth allowed Samuel Rogers to receive a good education, as he was educated at a private school in Hackney, London. This access to education was a result of his family's middle-class status and not due to his own merit. The family's living conditions would have been comfortable but not lavish, typical of the middle class during this period.
sources: "Samuel Rogers." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Samuel-Rogers; "Samuel Rogers." Poetry Foundation. https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/samuel-rogers.

explanation: Mark Catesby was born in Essex, England, to a family of moderate means. His father, John Catesby, was a lawyer and his mother, Elizabeth Jekyll, came from a family of lawyers. This suggests that the family was not part of the elite aristocracy, but rather belonged to the middle class, as the profession of law was typically associated with this social stratum during the late 17th century. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was extremely wealthy or impoverished, which further supports this classification. Catesby's access to education was likely due to his family's middle-class status, as he attended grammar school in Chipping Norton and later studied natural history in London. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his family's profession, it can be inferred that they were likely comfortable but not extravagant. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Mark Catesby: Life and Work" by George F. Frick, "The Curious Mister Catesby: A "Truly Ingenious" Naturalist Explores New Worlds" by E. Charles Nelson and David J. Elliott.

explanation: Jacob Acontius, also known as Jakob Acontius, is a somewhat obscure historical figure, and there is limited information available about his early life and family background. The majority of available sources focus on his later life, particularly his religious writings and his time in Switzerland and England. There is not enough information to definitively classify his social class at birth. It is known that he was a scholar and a writer, but these are achievements from his adulthood and do not provide insight into his family background or childhood circumstances.
sources: The primary sources that mention Acontius, such as his own writings and those of his contemporaries, do not provide detailed information about his early life or family background. Further research may be needed in archival sources or local records from the time and place of his birth.

explanation: John Wilson Croker was born in Galway, Ireland, in 1780. His father, also named John Croker, was a surveyor and a major in the Irish Volunteers, a local militia. This suggests that the family was not part of the elite nobility, but rather belonged to the middle class. The occupation of surveyor would have required a certain level of education and skill, and the position of major in the militia suggests a degree of respect and authority in the community. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy, but they were likely comfortable and had access to resources. John Wilson Croker himself was educated at Trinity College, Dublin, which suggests that his family had the means to provide him with a good education. However, this was not necessarily a result of inherited privilege, but rather a reflection of the family's middle-class status.
sources: "John Wilson Croker, Irish Ideologue" by Robert Portsmouth; "The Life of John Wilson Croker" by Louis J. Jennings; "John Wilson Croker: Conservative Satirist" by Robert Portsmouth.

explanation: Richard Dadd was born in Chatham, Kent, England in 1817. His father, Robert Dadd, was a chemist and druggist, occupations that would have placed the family in the middle class during this period. The family was not of noble lineage or extreme wealth, but they were not impoverished either. Richard Dadd had access to education, as he was admitted to the Royal Academy of Arts at the age of 20, which suggests that his family had the means to support his studies. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's profession, it's likely that they were comfortable for the time. There's no evidence to suggest that Dadd inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "Richard Dadd: The Artist and The Asylum" by Nicholas Tromans; "Richard Dadd: A Chronicle of His Life and Art" by Patricia Allderidge.

explanation: Richard Hooker was born in Heavitree, near Exeter, around 1554. His father was likely a small landowner, which would place the family in the middle class of the time. His uncle, John Hooker, was a prominent Exeter official and historian, suggesting a family with some means and connections. Richard Hooker's education was sponsored by John Jewel, the Bishop of Salisbury, after Jewel recognized Hooker's potential during a visit to Exeter. This sponsorship allowed Hooker to attend Corpus Christi College, Oxford. While this education was due to merit, it was also facilitated by his family's connections, suggesting a certain level of social standing. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Hooker was born into the elite or subsistence classes.
sources: "The Folger Library Edition of the Works of Richard Hooker, Vol. 1: Preface Books I-IV Of the Laws of Ecclesiastical Polity" by W. Speed Hill; "Richard Hooker and the Construction of Christian Community" by Arthur Stephen McGrade.

explanation: Joseph Black was born in Bordeaux, France, in 1728 to a Scottish father, John Black, and an Irish mother, Margaret Gordon. His father was a wine merchant, which was a respectable occupation in the middle class during the 18th century. The family was well-off enough to afford a good education for Joseph, as he was sent to a grammar school in Belfast and later attended the University of Glasgow and the University of Edinburgh, indicating a certain level of financial stability and access to resources typical of the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the elite or aristocracy, nor were they subsistence-level laborers or peasants.
sources: "Joseph Black." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Joseph-Black; "Joseph Black." Science History Institute. https://www.sciencehistory.org/historical-profile/joseph-black.

explanation: Charlotte of Mecklenburg-Strelitz was born into the ruling class, as her father was Duke Charles Louis Frederick of Mecklenburg-Strelitz, and her mother was Princess Elizabeth Albertine of Saxe-Hildburghausen. As a member of a ducal house, she would have been considered part of the nobility, which places her in the elite class. Her family's wealth and status would have been significant at the time of her birth and throughout her childhood. She would have had access to education due to her family background, as it was customary for nobility to receive education. Her early life housing and living conditions would have been of high standard, befitting her status as a member of the nobility. She would have inherited privileges due to her birth, including a high social standing and access to resources.
sources: The primary sources for this information include historical records and documents from the House of Mecklenburg-Strelitz, as well as biographical accounts of Charlotte's life. For example, "The Life of Queen Charlotte" by Olwen Hedley provides detailed information about her early life and family background.

explanation: The early life and family background of Oscar Gustave Rejlander is not well-documented. Born in Sweden around 1813, Rejlander moved to England sometime in the 1830s or 1840s. The occupations and social standing of his parents, as well as the family's wealth and living conditions during his childhood, are not known. It is also unclear what kind of education he received in his early years, although he was known to have studied art and literature in Rome before moving to England. Further research into Swedish records or personal correspondence might provide more insight into his family background.

explanation: Julius Benedict was born in Stuttgart, Germany in 1804. His father was a Jewish banker, which would have placed the family in the middle class during this time period. The family's wealth would have provided Julius with access to education, as he studied music at an early age under notable composers such as Johann Nepomuk Hummel and Ludwig van Beethoven. The family's occupation and wealth would have also provided them with comfortable housing and living conditions. However, as a Jewish family in the early 19th century, they would have faced certain societal disadvantages and prejudices.

explanation: John Harrison was born in Foulby, near Wakefield in West Yorkshire, England in 1693. His father, Henry Harrison, was a carpenter and a builder, which was a skilled trade and would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The Harrison family was not wealthy, but they were not subsistence level either. They had enough resources to provide John with some education, as he was able to read and write, which was not common among the lower classes at the time. The family lived in a house that Henry Harrison had built, which suggests they had a stable living situation. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Longitude: The True Story of a Lone Genius Who Solved the Greatest Scientific Problem of His Time" by Dava Sobel; "John Harrison and the Longitude Problem", National Maritime Museum, Greenwich, London.

explanation: Edward William Cooke was born in London in 1811 to parents who were both involved in the arts. His father, George Cooke, was an engraver and his mother, Mary Cooke, was a line engraver. This suggests that the family was part of the middle class, as both parents were skilled craftspeople. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they were of average means for their time and place. Edward was educated at home by his parents, which suggests that the family had enough resources to provide for his education without needing him to work. The family lived in London, which was a thriving city at the time, suggesting that they had access to decent housing and living conditions. There is no evidence to suggest that Edward inherited any particular privileges or disadvantages due to his family background.
sources: "Edward William Cooke, R.A., F.R.S., F.Z.S., F.S.A., F.G.S." by John Munday, published in 1903; "The Dictionary of National Biography" by Sir Leslie Stephen and Sir Sidney Lee, published in 1885-1900.

explanation: John Foxe was born in Boston, in the county of Lincolnshire, England, around 1516. His family is not known to have been particularly wealthy or influential, suggesting they were not part of the elite. His father died when he was young, and his mother remarried. His stepfather, Richard Melton, was a yeoman, a social class that typically owned their own land and could be considered part of the middle class. Foxe was able to attend Brasenose College, Oxford, from around 1531, suggesting his family had enough resources to provide him with an education. However, it's worth noting that his education was also supported by the college itself, as he became a fellow there in 1535. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but his family's status as yeomen would suggest they were comfortable, if not luxurious. There is no evidence of any significant inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "John Foxe: An Historical Perspective" by David Loades; "John Foxe and the Elizabethan Church" by V. Norskov Olsen; "John Foxe and his Book" by Tom Freeman.

explanation: Thomas Harriot was born in Oxfordshire, England, around 1560. His father was a commoner, and there is no record of any noble or aristocratic lineage in his family. His father was a merchant, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of late 16th-century England. Harriot was able to attend Oxford University, suggesting that his family had enough wealth to afford his education. However, it's important to note that his attendance at university was also due to a scholarship, indicating that while his family was not poor, they were not extremely wealthy either. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's occupation, it's likely that they were comfortable but not luxurious. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Thomas Harriot: A Life in Science" by Robyn Arianrhod; "Thomas Harriot and His World: Mathematics, Exploration, and Natural Philosophy in Early Modern England" by Robert Fox.

explanation: James Joseph Sylvester was born in London, England, in 1814 into a Jewish family. His father, Abraham Joseph Sylvester, was a merchant, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the United Kingdom in the 19th century. The family's Jewish faith also meant they faced certain social restrictions and prejudices, but they were not impoverished. James was able to attend a private school, the Royal Institution School, which suggests the family had some means. However, his access to higher education was initially limited due to religious discrimination, not lack of family resources. His family's merchant status and ability to afford private schooling for James suggest a middle-class background.
sources: "James Joseph Sylvester." Encyclopedia Britannica. "James Joseph Sylvester: Jewish Mathematician in a Victorian World" by Karen Hunger Parshall.

explanation: Marianne North was born into an elite family in the United Kingdom. Her father, Frederick North, was a member of the British Parliament and a landowner, which indicates a high social standing. Her mother, Janet Marjoribanks, came from a family of Scottish nobility. The North family was wealthy, allowing Marianne to live comfortably and receive a good education, which was not common for women during this time period. The family's wealth and status also provided Marianne with the opportunity to travel extensively, a privilege not available to those of lower social classes.
sources:
1. "Marianne North: A Very Intrepid Painter" by Michelle Payne
2. "Marianne North: The Kew Collection" by Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew

explanation: Alfred Edward Chalon was born in Geneva, Switzerland, to a French lawyer named Jean Chalon and his wife, Marie Suzanne. The family moved to England when Alfred was a child. His father's profession as a lawyer indicates that they were likely part of the middle class, as law was a respected profession typically associated with this social stratum. The family's ability to move countries also suggests some level of financial stability, which is another characteristic of the middle class. Alfred and his brother, John James Chalon, both received education in art, which suggests that the family had the resources to provide their children with specialized education, a privilege often associated with the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Chalon family was part of the elite or subsistence classes.
sources: "Alfred Edward Chalon." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; "Alfred Edward Chalon." The British Museum.

explanation: William Henry Giles Kingston was born into a middle-class family. His father, Lucy Henry Kingston, was a merchant involved in the wine trade, which was a typical occupation for the middle class during this period. His mother, Anne Craig, was also from a middle-class background. The family had enough wealth to provide Kingston with a good education, as he was educated at Trinity College, Dublin, which suggests that they were not struggling financially. However, there's no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite or nobility, as there's no record of any titles or significant land ownership. The family lived in comfortable, but not luxurious, circumstances in London and Kingston's early life was typical of a middle-class child of his time.
sources: "William Henry Giles Kingston." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; "The Wine Trade in Britain 1700-1914." Economic History Review, 2007.

explanation: John Ogilby was born in Scotland around 1600. His father was a member of the King's Council of Scotland, which suggests a middle-class background as the council was typically composed of educated professionals, not nobility. However, the family's fortunes declined due to his father's imprisonment for political reasons, and Ogilby was apprenticed to a dancing master, which suggests that the family was not wealthy enough to provide him with a more traditional education. This apprenticeship, however, does indicate a certain level of social standing, as dancing was considered a refined art and was taught to children of the middle class and above.
sources: "John Ogilby and the Taste of His Times" by William Poole; "John Ogilby, Britannia, and the Dissemination of Knowledge in Restoration England" by Robert Mayhew.

explanation: Joseph Highmore was born in London in 1692. His father, Edward Highmore, was a coal merchant, which would place the family within the middle class according to the given typology. Coal merchants were part of the commercial middle class, involved in trade and commerce. There is no evidence to suggest that the Highmore family was impoverished or part of the elite aristocracy. The fact that Joseph Highmore was able to study law at the Middle Temple suggests that his family had enough resources to provide him with a good education, another characteristic of the middle class. However, it should be noted that the family's exact wealth and living conditions during Highmore's childhood are not well-documented.
sources: "Joseph Highmore, 1692–1780, British" by the Yale Center for British Art; "Joseph Highmore of Canterbury" by Jacqueline Riding; "The Dictionary of National Biography" by Sir Leslie Stephen and Sir Sidney Lee.

explanation: Thomas Otway was born in 1652 in Trotton, Sussex, England. His father, Humphrey Otway, was a clergyman, serving as the Rector of Woolbeding, a position that would have placed the family within the middle class of the time. The family would have had a stable income and a certain level of social standing within their community, but they would not have been considered part of the elite or nobility. Otway's access to education was also indicative of his middle-class status. He attended Winchester College, a school that was known for educating the sons of the middle class, and later studied at Christ Church, Oxford, suggesting that his family had the means to support his education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Otway's family was particularly wealthy or that he inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Thomas Otway." The Columbia Encyclopedia, 6th ed., Columbia University Press, 2018; "Thomas Otway." Encyclopædia Britannica, Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc., 2020.

explanation: William Young Ottley was born into a middle-class family. His father, William Ottley, was a successful merchant and a member of the Worshipful Company of Ironmongers, a prominent livery company in London. This suggests that the family had a comfortable income and a respectable social standing, typical of the middle class. The Ottley family's wealth and status would have likely provided William Young Ottley with access to a good education, although specific details about his early schooling are not readily available. The family's residence and living conditions are also not well-documented, but given their middle-class status, it can be inferred that they lived in decent conditions. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "The Dictionary of National Biography" by Sir Leslie Stephen and Sir Sidney Lee; "The Worshipful Company of Ironmongers" by John Nicholl.

explanation: William Bell Scott was born in Edinburgh, Scotland in 1811 to Robert Scott and his wife Elizabeth. His father, Robert Scott, was a reputable engraver and artist, a profession that would have placed the family in the middle class during the early 19th century. The family was not part of the aristocracy, but they were not subsistence level either. The family's middle-class status is further supported by the fact that William and his brothers were educated, with William attending the Royal Academy schools in London. This suggests that the family had enough resources to provide their children with a good education, a privilege not typically available to lower classes at the time. The family's housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given Robert Scott's profession, it is reasonable to assume they lived comfortably.
sources: "William Bell Scott, Poet and Artist: His Life and Work" by W. Minto (1893); "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" by H. C. G. Matthew and Brian Harrison (2004).

explanation:
John Ambrose Fleming was born on November 29, 1849, in Lancaster, Lancashire, England. His father, James Fleming, was a minister of the Congregational church, and his mother, Mary Ann, was a homemaker. The family was not wealthy, but they were not poor either. The occupation of his father as a minister indicates that they belonged to the middle class of the society. The middle class in the UK during the late 1800s typically included professionals, such as ministers, teachers, and merchants. 

Fleming had access to education due to his family background. He attended University College School, London, and later University College London and the Royal College of Science. This level of education was not common among the lower classes during this period, suggesting that his family had the means to support his education. 

The family lived in a comfortable home, appropriate for a middle-class family of the time. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.

explanation: George Baxter was born in 1804 in Lutterworth, Leicestershire, England. His father, John Baxter, was a printer and publisher, a profession that would typically be associated with the middle class during this period. The family was not of noble birth or aristocracy, nor were they laborers or peasants, which rules out the classifications of elite and subsistence. George Baxter's access to education would likely have been due to his family's middle-class status. His father's profession suggests that the family had a reasonable level of wealth, enough to provide for a decent standard of living and education for their children. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were particularly wealthy or that George Baxter inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "George Baxter (Colour Printer)" by C.T. Courtney Lewis (1908), "The Life and Work of George Baxter" by Michael Twyman (2013).

explanation: John Frederick Lewis was born in London in 1805. His father, Frederick Christian Lewis (1779–1856), was an engraver and landscape painter of some repute, which suggests a middle-class background. The profession of engraving was a skilled craft and often associated with the middle class during this period. There is no evidence to suggest that Lewis was born into a family of significant wealth or nobility, nor that he came from a subsistence background. His access to education is not well-documented, but his early training in his father's craft suggests that he had at least some access to education and training, which would be consistent with a middle-class upbringing. His early life housing and living conditions are also not well-documented, but given his father's profession, it is likely that they were at least adequate. There is no evidence of any significant inherited privileges or disadvantages.
