explanation: Sir Henry Wotton was born into a family of considerable wealth and social standing. His father, Thomas Wotton, was a wealthy Kentish gentleman and his mother, Eleanor Finch, was a member of a prominent family in Kent. His father's wealth and social standing allowed him to provide his children with a good education. Henry Wotton was educated at Winchester College and New College, Oxford, which were institutions typically attended by the children of the elite. His family's wealth and social standing also provided him with a comfortable early life housing and living conditions. As a member of the elite, he would have inherited certain privileges, such as access to education and a comfortable lifestyle.
sources: "Reliquiae Wottonianae, or, A collection of lives, letters, poems" by Izaak Walton, "The Life and Letters of Sir Henry Wotton" by Logan Pearsall Smith, "Sir Henry Wotton: A Biographical Sketch" by Arthur F. Marotti.

explanation: William Blake Richmond was born into a middle-class family. His father, George Richmond, was a successful portrait painter and a member of the artistic group known as the Ancients. This group was inspired by the work of William Blake, after whom Richmond was named. His mother, Julia Tatham, was the daughter of a family friend. The Richmond family was not of the aristocracy, but they were not impoverished either. They were part of the professional class, with George Richmond's work as an artist providing a comfortable living. William Blake Richmond would have had access to education due to his family's status, and his early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable for the time. However, he would not have had the inherited privileges associated with the elite class.
sources: "William Blake Richmond: An Artist's Life, 1842-1921" by Hilary Underwood, "The Ancients" by Timothy Wilcox.

explanation: Alexander John Ellis was born Alexander John Sharpe in Hoxton, Middlesex, England, on June 14, 1814. His father, James Birch Sharpe, was a prosperous brewer, which would have placed the family in the middle class. His mother, Ann Ellis, was the daughter of a wealthy landowner. The family's wealth allowed Ellis to receive a good education, including attending the prestigious Eton College and later Cambridge University. However, it's important to note that while his family was well-off, they were not part of the aristocracy or ruling class, hence the classification as middle class.
sources: "Alexander John Ellis." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, May 2009.

explanation: James Fittler was born in London in 1758. His family background is not extensively documented, but it is known that he was apprenticed to the engraver Richard Earlom at the age of fourteen. This suggests that his family had enough resources to secure an apprenticeship, a common practice among the middle class of the time. Apprenticeships were often paid for by the family of the apprentice, indicating that Fittler's family had some means. However, there is no evidence to suggest that his family was part of the elite or nobility. The fact that he needed to be apprenticed also suggests that his family was not wealthy enough to secure his future without him needing to learn a trade.
sources: "James Fittler A.R.A." in 'The Dictionary of National Biography'. London: Smith, Elder & Co. 1885–1900.

explanation: Edward John Trelawny was born into a wealthy and influential family. His father, Charles Trelawny, was a British army officer and a member of the landed gentry, while his mother, Henrietta Trelawny, was the daughter of a baronet. The Trelawny family had a long history of military and political service, and they owned substantial estates in Cornwall. Edward was the youngest of four children, and he was educated at home by private tutors, a privilege only available to the elite class. His family's wealth and status would have provided him with a comfortable upbringing and access to opportunities not available to those of lower social classes.
sources: "Records of the Trelawny Family" (Cornwall Record Office), "The Last Days of Shelley and Byron" by Edward John Trelawny (primary source), "Trelawny: The Incurable Romancer" by William St Clair (biography).

explanation: James Gibbs was born in 1682 in Footdeesmire near Aberdeen, Scotland. His father was a merchant, which places the family in the middle class according to the given typology. Gibbs' father died when he was young, but he was able to attend the Grammar school in Aberdeen due to the financial stability provided by his father's merchant profession. He later attended Marischal College, further indicating that his family had sufficient means to support his education. There is no evidence to suggest that Gibbs was born into an elite family with inherited privileges, nor does it appear that he was born into a subsistence-level family.
sources: "James Gibbs." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/James-Gibbs. "James Gibbs." Dictionary of Scottish Architects. http://www.scottisharchitects.org.uk/architect_full.php?id=200364.

explanation: Alexander Dalrymple was born in Newhailes, East Lothian, Scotland, around 1737. His father, Sir James Dalrymple, was a lawyer and the Baron of Newhailes, a title that, while noble, was not associated with significant wealth or power in the Scottish peerage. His mother, Lady Christian Hamilton, was the daughter of an earl. While the family had some status, they were not part of the ruling elite. Dalrymple's father's profession as a lawyer suggests a middle-class background. The family had enough wealth to provide Alexander with a good education, as he attended the Royal High School in Edinburgh, but there is no evidence of extravagant wealth or luxury in his early life.
sources: "The Life of Alexander Dalrymple" by Andrew Cook, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "The Scottish Nation: Dalrymple" by William Anderson.

explanation: Thomas Stanley was born into a noble family, the Stanley family, which was one of the most prominent families in England during the 16th and 17th centuries. His father, Sir Thomas Stanley, was a Knight and his mother, Alice Spencer, came from the Spencer family, another noble family. The Stanley family was wealthy and owned significant landholdings, including the Isle of Man. As a member of the nobility, Thomas Stanley would have had access to education and lived in comfortable conditions. His birth and childhood social class would therefore be classified as elite.
sources: "The History of the House of Stanley from the Conquest to the Death of the Right Honourable Edward, Late Earl of Derby, in 1776" by John Seacome; "The Peerage of England: Containing a Genealogical and Historical Account of All the Peers of England" by Arthur Collins.

explanation: John Cam Hobhouse, 1st Baron Broughton, was born into a wealthy family. His father, Sir Benjamin Hobhouse, was a successful merchant and a member of Parliament, which indicates a high social standing. The Hobhouse family was well-established and had considerable wealth, allowing John access to a high-quality education. He attended Westminster School and later Trinity College, Cambridge, which were both prestigious institutions typically attended by the elite class. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, given his family's wealth. As the son of a successful merchant and politician, John would have inherited certain privileges, such as access to influential social circles and opportunities for advancement.

explanation: George John Romanes was born into a wealthy family. His father, George Romanes, was a successful merchant and landowner, which indicates a high social standing. Romanes was born in Kingston, Canada West, but his family moved back to the United Kingdom when he was young. His family's wealth allowed him to receive a high-quality education, as he was privately tutored before attending the University of Cambridge. explanation: Henry Gray was born in Belgravia, London, in 1827. His father was a private messenger to George IV and William IV, a position that would have provided a stable income and a certain level of social standing, indicating a middle-class background. Gray's early access to education, as evidenced by his enrolment at St. George's Hospital Medical School at the age of 21, also suggests a middle-class upbringing, as such opportunities were typically not available to those from lower social classes during this period. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Gray's family was part of the elite ruling class or nobility.
sources: "Henry Gray's Anatomy: Descriptive and Surgical" by Ruth Richardson; "The Making of Mr Gray's Anatomy" by Ruth Richardson.

explanation: Philip Henry Wicksteed was born into a middle-class family. His father, Charles Wicksteed, was a Unitarian minister, a profession that typically fell within the middle class in the 19th century United Kingdom. His mother, Jane Lupton, came from a family of merchants, which also suggests a middle-class background. There is no evidence to suggest that the Wicksteed family was particularly wealthy or impoverished at the time of Philip's birth. As for education, Philip was educated at University College, London, and Manchester New College, which suggests that his family had the means to provide him with a good education. However, this was likely due to their professional status rather than any inherited wealth or privilege. The family's living conditions are not well-documented, but given their professional status, it is reasonable to assume that they were comfortable, if not luxurious.
sources: "Philip Henry Wicksteed: A Memoir" by Charles Wicksteed (his son), "The Economic Journal" by the Royal Economic Society, "The Letters of Philip Henry Wicksteed" edited by Ian Steedman.

explanation: Isaac D'Israeli was born into a Jewish family of Italian origin. His father, Benjamin D'Israeli, was a merchant, which places the family in the middle class according to the provided typology. explanation: Samuel Wesley was born into a family with a strong religious background. His father, also named Samuel Wesley, was a clergyman of the Church of England. His mother, Susanna Wesley, was a well-educated woman who played a significant role in the education of her children. The family, while not wealthy, was not poor either. They lived in a parsonage, which indicates a certain level of comfort and stability. However, they were not part of the aristocracy or ruling class. The family's access to education was due to their social standing and the importance they placed on education, rather than wealth. Samuel Wesley's early life was marked by religious and intellectual pursuits, rather than manual labor or servitude, which suggests a middle-class upbringing.

explanation: Arnold Ruge was born into a middle-class family. His father was a pastor, which was a respected profession in the 19th century Prussia. This would have provided the family with a stable income and a certain level of social standing. The fact that Ruge was able to attend university, studying theology and philosophy, suggests that his family had enough resources to afford his education. However, there's no evidence to suggest that his family was part of the elite or nobility.

explanation: George Gascoigne was born into an aristocratic family, which places him in the elite class. His father, Sir John Gascoigne, was a prominent landowner and member of the gentry, which was the lower tier of the aristocracy. This provided George with a privileged upbringing, including access to education, which was not common for those outside of the elite class during this time period. His family wealth and social standing would have also provided him with a comfortable living situation and certain inherited privileges.

explanation: John Fane, 11th Earl of Westmorland, was born into the British aristocracy, a clear indication of his elite status. His father was John Fane, 10th Earl of Westmorland, a prominent figure in British politics and society. His mother, Sarah Anne Child, was the only child of Robert Child, the principal owner of Child's Bank, which was one of the most powerful financial institutions in the country at the time. This means that John Fane was born into significant wealth and privilege. His family's status would have granted him access to the best education available at the time, and he would have grown up in the comfortable surroundings of his family's estates. His birth and childhood circumstances were clearly those of the elite class.
sources: The Peerage, a genealogical survey of the peerage of Britain as well as the royal families of Europe; "The House of Commons 1790-1820" by R. G. Thorne; "Child & Co.: A History" by Harold Pollins.

explanation: George Alfred Henty, known as G. A. Henty, was born in Trumpington, near Cambridge, England on December 8, 1832. His father, William Henty, was a solicitor, a profession that would place the family in the middle class. His mother, Sarah, was the daughter of a London merchant, further supporting the classification of Henty's family as middle class. The family was not of aristocratic or noble lineage, nor were they laborers or peasants. Henty's family had the means to send him to Westminster School, a prestigious institution, indicating a certain level of wealth and access to education. However, this was due to their family background and not Henty's individual merit. The family lived in a comfortable home in Trumpington, which suggests they were not living in poverty or struggling for resources.
sources: "G. A. Henty: A Bibliographical Study" by Peter Newbolt, "G. A. Henty, 1832-1902: A Bibliographical Study of His British Editions, with Short Accounts of His Publishers, Illustrators and Designers, and Notes on Production Methods Used for His Books" by R. T. S. Bircham.

explanation: William Burges was born on December 2, 1827, in London, England. His father, Alfred Burges, was a civil engineer and surveyor, which was a skilled profession during the 19th century. This occupation would have placed the Burges family in the middle class of society. Alfred Burges was successful enough in his profession to provide his family with a comfortable lifestyle, including a home in a respectable neighborhood. William Burges was also able to receive a good education because of his family's social standing. He attended the prestigious King's College School and later Corpus Christi College, Oxford. This access to education was a privilege that was typically reserved for the middle and upper classes during this time period.
sources:
1. "William Burges." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004.
2. Crook, J. Mordaunt. William Burges and the High Victorian Dream. Frances Lincoln Ltd, 2013.

explanation: James Shirley was born to a family of modest means in London, around 1596. His father, also named James Shirley, was a merchant tailor, a profession that would have placed the family in the middle class of the social hierarchy of the time. This is further supported by the fact that Shirley was able to attend Merchant Taylors' School, a prestigious institution that catered primarily to the sons of the middle class. His access to education at this school was likely due to his father's occupation and social standing, rather than any inherent merit. The family's living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, typical of the middle class in late 16th-century England.
sources: "The Dramatic Works and Poems of James Shirley" by James Shirley, Alexander Dyce; "James Shirley: A Study of Literary Tradition and Influence" by Samuel Schoenbaum; "The Merchant Taylors' School Register, 1561-1934" by Merchant Taylors' School (London, England).

explanation: John Edwin Sandys was born on May 19, 1844, in Leicester, England. His father, Reverend Timothy Sandys, was a clergyman of the Church of England, which places the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the United Kingdom in the late 1800s. The clergy were typically considered part of the middle class, as they were educated and held a respected position in society, but they were not part of the aristocracy. There is no evidence to suggest that the Sandys family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they lived comfortably but not extravagantly. John Edwin Sandys had access to education, as he attended the Leicester School and later St. John's College, Cambridge, which suggests that his family had the means to support his education. However, this does not necessarily indicate that the family was wealthy, as education was highly valued in middle-class Victorian society and families often prioritized spending on education.
sources: "John Edwin Sandys", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "The Victorian Middle Class", BBC History; "The Social Structure of Victorian England", Victorian Web.

explanation: Robert Stawell Ball was born on July 1, 1840, in Dublin, Ireland, to Amelia Gresley Hellicar and Bob Stawell Ball. His father, Bob Stawell Ball, was an amateur astronomer and a professional naturalist, working as a curator of the Dublin Zoo. This suggests that the family had a stable income and a certain level of education, which are characteristics of the middle class. Robert's access to education was also likely due to his family background. His father's interest in astronomy probably influenced Robert's own interest in the subject, and he was able to study at the University of Dublin, indicating that his family had the means to support his education. The family's living conditions are not well-documented, but given Bob Stawell Ball's occupation, it is reasonable to assume that they were comfortable, if not affluent.
sources: "Robert Stawell Ball." Encyclopedia Britannica, https://www.britannica.com/biography/Robert-Stawell-Ball. "Robert Stawell Ball." The MacTutor History of Mathematics archive, https://mathshistory.st-andrews.ac.uk/Biographies/Ball_Robert/.

explanation: Ingram Bywater was born in 1840 in Paddington, London, England. His father, Thomas Bywater, was a successful merchant, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The Bywater family would have had enough wealth to provide a comfortable life for Ingram and his siblings, but they were not part of the elite ruling class or nobility. Ingram's access to education was likely due to his family's middle-class status, as he attended the City of London School and later Queen's College, Oxford. This level of education was not typically accessible to those in the subsistence class, further supporting the classification of the Bywater family as middle class. Information about the family's early life housing and living conditions is not readily available, but given their middle-class status, it can be inferred that they were likely adequate and comfortable for the time.
sources: "Ingram Bywater" in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; Census records for the Bywater family in the 1841 England Census.

individual_name: Thomas Fairfax, 3rd Lord Fairfax of Cameron
explanation: Thomas Fairfax, 3rd Lord Fairfax of Cameron, was born into an elite family. His father, Ferdinando Fairfax, 2nd Lord Fairfax of Cameron, was a member of the English nobility, and his mother, Mary Sheffield, was the daughter of the Earl of Mulgrave. The Fairfax family had a long history of service to the Crown and held extensive lands in Yorkshire and other parts of England. Thomas was the eldest son and therefore the heir to his father's title and estates. His family's wealth and status would have afforded him a high standard of living and access to education from a young age. He was educated at St John's College, Cambridge, an opportunity that would have been available to him due to his family's social standing.
sources: "The Fairfax Correspondence: Memoirs of the Reign of Charles the First" by George William Johnson; "The Fairfax Family in Fairfax County: A Brief History" by Kenton Kilmer and Donald Sweig; "The History of the University of Oxford: Volume IV Seventeenth-Century Oxford" by Nicholas Tyacke.

explanation: Nehemiah Grew was born in 1641 in Mancetter, Warwickshire, England. His father, Obadiah Grew, was a respected clergyman, serving as the vicar of St. Peter's Church in Coventry. This would suggest that the Grew family was of the middle class, as clergy were typically educated and held a certain social standing, but were not part of the nobility or ruling class. The fact that Nehemiah Grew himself was able to attend Cambridge University also suggests a certain level of family wealth and access to education, as university education was not typically accessible to those of lower social classes during this time period. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Grew family was part of the elite or ruling class, as they did not hold titles of nobility or significant political power.
sources: "Nehemiah Grew (1641–1712): A Pious and Painstaking Student of Nature" by A. B. Cohen, published in the Journal of Medical Biography, 2005; "Nehemiah Grew and the Birth of Plant Anatomy" by M. J. Simpson, published in Endeavour, 2003.

explanation: Edward Calvert was born in Appledore, Devon, in 1799. His father, a shipbuilder, was a member of the skilled working class, which places the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. Shipbuilding was a skilled trade, and while it did not confer the status of the elite, it was a step above subsistence living. Edward Calvert's family was likely to have had a modest level of wealth and a comfortable living condition. As for education, it is known that Calvert was apprenticed to a shipbuilder at a young age, which suggests that his family had the resources to secure this form of vocational education for him. However, there is no evidence to suggest that he had access to formal education due to his family background.
sources: "Edward Calvert (1799–1883): A Memoir" by T. G. Rossetti, "The Life, Letters, and Writings of Charles Lamb" by Percy Fitzgerald, "The English School of Painting" by Ernest Chesneau.

explanation: William Scoresby was born in Cropton, near Whitby, England in 1789. His father, also named William Scoresby, was a successful whaler and ship owner, which would likely place them in the middle class according to the given typology. The elder Scoresby was not of noble birth or aristocracy, nor were they subsistence laborers or peasants. The family's wealth came from the father's successful whaling business. As for education, William Scoresby Jr. was initially educated at home, and later attended the village school. This indicates that the family had enough resources to provide him with a basic education. The family's living conditions would have been typical of a successful merchant family of the time, which would likely have been comfortable but not luxurious.
sources: "William Scoresby, Junior (1789–1857): Yorkshire whaler, Arctic explorer, and Liverpool cleric." Arctic, Vol. 40, No. 3 (Sep., 1987), pp. 232-238; "William Scoresby." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: Humphrey Prideaux was born in Padstow, Cornwall, England, around 1648. His father, Edmund Prideaux, was a lawyer by profession. The Prideaux family was well-established in Cornwall and Devon, with a history dating back to the Norman Conquest, but by the 17th century, they were not among the highest echelons of the nobility. They were, however, a respectable family with a comfortable income, placing them firmly in the middle class of the time. Humphrey Prideaux's access to education was likely due to his family's status and resources. He attended the grammar school in Liskeard before going on to study at Oxford University. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, reflecting his family's middle-class status.
sources: "The Life of Dr. Humphrey Prideaux, Lord Bishop of Worcester" by William B. Turnbull, "The Prideaux Family History" by John Prideaux.

explanation: John Gabriel Stedman was born in Dendermonde, Flanders, in 1744, to Robert Stedman, a lieutenant-colonel in the Scots Brigade of the Dutch service, and his wife, who was a native of Flanders. His father's military position suggests a middle-class status, as officers often came from the middle class. There is no evidence of inherited wealth or aristocratic lineage. The family moved to the Netherlands when Stedman was about five, and he was educated there, indicating access to education, a typical characteristic of the middle class. However, the family's financial situation seems to have been unstable, as Stedman's father was imprisoned for debt in 1755. This suggests that while the family had some social standing due to Robert Stedman's military position, they were not wealthy.
sources: "Narrative of a Five Years' Expedition against the Revolted Negroes of Surinam" by John Gabriel Stedman; "John Gabriel Stedman" by Richard Price and Sally Price; "The Stedman Family Organization".

explanation: Joseph Noel Paton was born on 13 December 1821 in Wooer's Alley, Dunfermline, Fife, Scotland. His father, Joseph Neil Paton, was a damask designer and drew landscapes in his spare time. His mother, Catherine MacDiarmid, descended from a long line of Scottish patriot ancestry. Paton's parents were not wealthy, but they were not poor either. They belonged to the middle class of the society of the time, with a stable income from the father's profession. Paton's father's interest in art also suggests a level of education and cultural capital typical of the middle class. Paton and his brother Waller Hugh Paton were both educated at the Dunfermline and Edinburgh Schools of Art, indicating that the family had enough resources to provide their children with education. The family lived in a house, not a mansion, but not a slum either, indicating a middle-class living condition.
sources: "Joseph Noel Paton: His Life and Work" by James Caw, "The Paton Brothers: Joseph Noel Paton and Waller Hugh Paton" by David Octavius Hill, "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" by H. C. G. Matthew and Brian Harrison.

explanation: Richard Price was born in Tynton, Glamorganshire, Wales, in 1723. His father, Rhys Price, was a dissenting minister (a clergyman who separated from the Church of England), which suggests a middle-class background. His mother, Catherine Richards, was a farmer's daughter, which also indicates a middle-class status. Price was the fourth of five children, suggesting a modest family size typical of the middle class. His family's ability to provide him with an education, as he attended a dissenting academy in London, further indicates a middle-class background. However, there is no evidence of significant wealth or inherited privilege in his family.
sources: "Richard Price (1723–1791)" by D. O. Thomas, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "Richard Price: His Life and Times" by Paul Frame.

explanation: William Coxe was born into a middle-class family. His father, Dr. William Coxe, was a physician in London, which was a respected profession during the 18th century. This would have provided the family with a comfortable income, placing them in the middle class. Coxe's father's profession also likely afforded him access to education, as he attended Eton College and then King's College, Cambridge. This level of education was not typically available to those of lower social classes during this time period. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Coxe was born into the elite class, as his family did not hold titles or vast wealth.
sources: "Coxe, William (1747–1828), historian and Church of England clergyman" by John Sweetman, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: Thomas Chandler Haliburton was born in Windsor, Nova Scotia, Canada, not the United Kingdom. His father, William Hersey Otis Haliburton, was a lawyer and a judge, which suggests a middle-class background. His mother, Lucy Chandler Grant, was the daughter of a judge, further indicating a middle-class upbringing. The family was well-off enough to send Haliburton to King's College in Windsor, one of the oldest universities in Canada, which suggests they had some wealth and valued education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite ruling class or nobility.
sources: "Thomas Chandler Haliburton." Dictionary of Canadian Biography, vol. 9, University of Toronto/Université Laval, 1976.

explanation: James Bradley was born in 1693 in Sherborne, Gloucestershire, England. His father, also named James Bradley, was a prosperous farmer, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the late 1600s in the United Kingdom. The family's wealth was derived from their farming activities, which would have provided a comfortable living but not to the extent of the elite class. Bradley's early education was likely funded by his family's income, as he was able to attend the local grammar school in Northleach, indicating a certain level of financial stability and access to education. There is no evidence of inherited privileges or disadvantages, and his family's living conditions would have been typical of a prosperous farming family of the time.
sources: "James Bradley." Encyclopedia Britannica, https://www.britannica.com/biography/James-Bradley. "James Bradley." The Biographical Encyclopedia of Astronomers, Springer Reference.

explanation: Jeremiah Clarke was born in 1674 in the United Kingdom. His father was a churchman, which suggests that the family was not of the elite class but had a respectable standing in society. The profession of a churchman would have provided a stable income, placing the family in the middle class. Clarke's access to education, as evidenced by his admission to the choir school of the Chapel Royal, was likely due to his father's connections within the church, rather than the family's wealth. The family's living conditions and housing are not well-documented, but given the father's occupation, they likely lived in modest but comfortable circumstances. There is no evidence of inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians", "Oxford Dictionary of National Biography"

explanation: William Mason was born in Hull, Yorkshire, England in 1724. His father, also named William Mason, was a clergyman of the Church of England, serving as the vicar of Holy Trinity Church in Hull. This places the Mason family in the middle class, as clergy were typically considered part of this social stratum during the 18th century. The family's wealth would have been modest but stable, and their social standing respectable. As the son of a clergyman, Mason would have had access to education, likely receiving a classical education in Latin and Greek, as was typical for the sons of the middle class during this period. The family's living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, reflecting their middle-class status. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "William Mason (1724–1797)" by James Sambrook, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "The Social Structure of England in the Eighteenth Century" by J.H. Plumb, The Cambridge Economic History of Europe.

explanation: Robert Lowth was born into a middle-class family. His father, William Lowth, was a vicar, a position that would have provided the family with a stable income and a certain level of social standing, but not to the extent of the elite class. The vicarage would have provided the family with housing, and while they would not have been wealthy, they would have been comfortable. Robert Lowth's access to education was likely due to his father's position and the importance placed on education within the clergy. As the son of a vicar, Robert would have had certain privileges, such as access to books and learning, but he would not have been born into wealth or nobility.
sources: "Robert Lowth", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "Robert Lowth", Encyclopaedia Britannica.

explanation: Thomas Sackville, 1st Earl of Dorset, was born into an elite family. His father, Sir Richard Sackville, was a wealthy landowner and a member of the nobility, serving as a Member of Parliament and later as Chancellor of the Exchequer. His mother, Winifred Brydges, was also from a noble family. The Sackville family was one of the most prominent and wealthy families in England at the time, owning large estates in Sussex and Kent. Thomas Sackville was therefore born into considerable wealth and privilege. He had access to education due to his family background, attending both the University of Oxford and Cambridge, which was a privilege reserved for the elite during this period. His early life housing and living conditions would have been of a high standard, reflecting his family's wealth and status.
sources: "The History of Parliament: the House of Commons 1509-1558," by S.T. Bindoff; "The Complete Peerage," by G.E. Cokayne; "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography," by H.C.G. Matthew and Brian Harrison.

explanation: Sir Frederick Pollock, 3rd Baronet, was born into a family of high social standing. His father, Sir William Frederick Pollock, 2nd Baronet, was a British lawyer and Tory politician, serving as Queen's Counsel and Attorney General to Prince Albert. This suggests that the family was part of the ruling class, with significant influence and wealth. The title of Baronet itself is a hereditary title awarded by the British Crown, further indicating their elite status. The Pollock family would have had access to the best education, housing, and living conditions available at the time due to their family background and wealth. Sir Frederick Pollock, 3rd Baronet, for instance, was educated at Eton College and Trinity College, Cambridge, two of the most prestigious educational institutions in the UK, which would have been accessible only to the elite class during this period.
sources:
1. "Pollock, Sir Frederick, third baronet (1845–1937), legal scholar and historian" by David Ibbetson, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.
2. "The Baronetage of England, Ireland, Nova Scotia, Great Britain and the United Kingdom" by John Debrett.
3. "Alumni Cantabrigienses: A Biographical List of All Known Students, Graduates and Holders of Office at the University of Cambridge, from the Earliest Times to 1900" by John Venn and J

explanation: Samuel William Reynolds was born in 1773 in London, England. His father, Samuel Reynolds, was a successful schoolmaster, which suggests a middle-class background. The occupation of a schoolmaster during the late 18th century in England was considered a respectable profession, often associated with the middle class. It is reasonable to assume that Reynolds' family had some degree of financial stability, given his father's profession. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite or subsistence classes. The family's access to education would have been relatively good, considering the father's profession. There is no information available on their early life housing and living conditions, but it is likely that they were adequate, reflecting their middle-class status.
sources: "Samuel William Reynolds (1773–1835), Mezzotint Engraver" from the National Portrait Gallery, London; "The Schoolmaster in Georgian Literature" by Robin Myers, Oxford University Press, 1992.

explanation: Elizabeth Inchbald was born on October 15, 1753, in Standingfield, Suffolk, England. She was the eighth of nine children born to John Simpson, a farmer, and his wife Mary. Her father's occupation as a farmer indicates that the family was not of the elite class, but rather of the middle class, as they were not laborers or peasants, but owned and operated their own farm. However, they were not wealthy, as indicated by the fact that Elizabeth received only a minimal education. After her mother's death, Elizabeth was sent to a boarding school in Bury St Edmunds, but she had to leave after only two years due to lack of funds. This suggests that while the family had enough resources to initially send her to school, they were not affluent. Elizabeth's early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of a middle-class farming family of the time, with the family living on and working the land they owned.
sources: "Memoirs of Mrs. Inchbald: Including Her Familiar Correspondence with the Most Distinguished Persons of Her Time" by James Boaden, "Elizabeth Inchbald and Her Circle: The Life Story of a Charming Woman, 1753-1821" by Charles E. Pearce.

explanation: Mary Sidney was born into the Sidney family, one of the most prominent families of the English nobility during the Elizabethan era. Her father, Sir Henry Sidney, was a prominent politician and courtier who served as the Lord President of the Council of Wales and the Marches, and her mother, Mary Dudley, was a lady-in-waiting to Queen Elizabeth I. The Sidney family was wealthy and owned several estates, including Penshurst Place in Kent, where Mary was likely born and raised. As a member of the nobility, Mary would have had access to a high level of education, and it is known that she was tutored by her mother's brother, Robert Dudley, who was a scholar and a patron of the arts. Her early life housing and living conditions would have been luxurious, befitting her status as a member of the elite. She would have inherited a number of privileges due to her family's high social standing, including access to the royal court and the opportunity to marry into other noble families.
sources:
- Hannay, Margaret P. (1985). "Philip's Phoenix: Mary Sidney, Countess of Pembroke". Oxford University Press.
- Gristwood, Sarah (2007). "Elizabeth and Leicester: Power, Passion, Politics". Viking.
- Robertson, Jean (2009). "A New Study of the Sidney Family: Their Role in Elizabethan Society". Cambridge Scholars Publishing.

explanation: George Richmond was born in Brompton, near London, in 1809. His father, Thomas Richmond, was a successful miniature painter, which would place him in the category of skilled craftspeople. This suggests that George Richmond was born into a middle-class family. The fact that Thomas Richmond was able to provide his son with an education in art from a young age further supports this classification. George Richmond was apprenticed to the engraver Charles Heath at the age of 14, indicating that his family had the means to secure such an opportunity for him. There is no evidence to suggest that the Richmond family was particularly wealthy or that they were part of the aristocracy, nor is there evidence to suggest that they were living in poverty. Therefore, the middle class is the most appropriate classification for George Richmond's birth and childhood social class.
sources: "George Richmond, R.A." (1906) by Julia Frankau; Oxford Dictionary of National Biography entry for George Richmond (2004) by Raymond Lister.

explanation: Georgiana Cavendish, Duchess of Devonshire, was born as Lady Georgiana Spencer, the eldest daughter of John Spencer, 1st Earl Spencer, and his wife, Margaret Georgiana Poyntz. The Spencers were one of the wealthiest and most influential families in England, with a long history of political power. Her father was a prominent Whig politician, and her mother was a member of the minor nobility. Georgiana was born into immense wealth and privilege, and she was raised in the grand Spencer family home, Althorp, in Northamptonshire. She would have had access to the best education money could buy, and she was brought up in the expectation that she would marry into the highest echelons of the aristocracy, which she did when she married William Cavendish, 5th Duke of Devonshire, in 1774.
sources: "Georgiana, Duchess of Devonshire" by Amanda Foreman; "The Spencer Family" by Charles Spencer; "The Devonshire Inheritance: Five Centuries of Collecting at Chatsworth" by Nicholas Barker.

explanation: William Henry Monk was born in London in 1823. His father, William Monk, was a businessman, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The family was not part of the aristocracy, nor were they subsistence laborers. Monk's access to education also suggests a middle-class background. He was educated at a private school in London and later studied music at the Royal Academy of Music, which would have required some level of financial resources. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was exceptionally wealthy or that Monk inherited significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "William Henry Monk" by John Richard Watson in The Canterbury Dictionary of Hymnology; "William Henry Monk" in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: Henry Thomas Alken was born into a middle-class family. His father, Samuel Alken, was a sporting artist, which was a skilled profession during the late 18th century in the United Kingdom. This suggests that the Alken family had a stable income and were likely to be part of the middle class. There is no evidence to suggest that the Alkens were part of the elite ruling class or nobility, nor were they subsistence laborers or peasants. The fact that Henry Thomas Alken followed in his father's footsteps and became an artist himself suggests that he had access to some form of education or training, which was more common among middle-class families during this period. However, specific details about the family's wealth, living conditions, and inherited privileges or disadvantages are not readily available.
sources: "Henry Thomas Alken." The Grove Encyclopedia of Decorative Arts. Ed. Gordon Campbell. Vol. 1. Oxford University Press, 2006.

explanation: Henry Hudson was born into a family with ties to the maritime industry, which suggests a middle-class background. His grandfather, also named Henry Hudson, was an Alderman and founder of the Muscovy Company, which traded with Russia. This indicates that the Hudson family had some wealth and social standing, but were not part of the nobility. The fact that Hudson became a sea explorer suggests he had access to education and training, which would be consistent with a middle-class upbringing. However, there is little information about his early life housing and living conditions, or any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Henry Hudson: Dreams and Obsession" by Corey Sandler, "Henry Hudson: His Voyages and Adventures" by Robert Michael Ballantyne.

explanation: James Pattison Cockburn was born into a family of Scottish nobility, the Cockburns of Langton. His father, Sir James Cockburn, 8th Baronet, was a member of the British aristocracy, which places the family in the elite class of the late 18th century United Kingdom. The Cockburns were a well-established family with a long history of military and political service, which would have provided them with a significant amount of wealth and social standing. This would have given James Pattison Cockburn access to high-quality education and comfortable living conditions from a young age. His family's status would also have afforded him certain privileges, such as connections to influential people and opportunities for advancement that were not available to those of lower social classes.
sources: "The Baronetage of England: Containing a Genealogical and Historical Account of All the English Baronets Now Existing" by William Betham (1802); "The Scottish Nation: Or, The Surnames, Families, Literature, Honours, and Biographical History of the People of Scotland" by William Anderson (1863).

explanation: Frances Power Cobbe was born into a wealthy Anglo-Irish family in Dublin, Ireland. Her father, Charles Cobbe, was an aristocrat and landowner, which placed the family in the elite class. The Cobbe family had significant wealth at the time of Frances' birth and childhood, owning Newbridge House and a large estate in County Dublin. This wealth provided Frances with access to education, which was typically reserved for the upper classes during this period. She was educated at home by private tutors, a privilege that was not common among the middle class or subsistence class. Her early life housing and living conditions were also indicative of her elite status, as she lived in a grand family estate. Frances inherited the privileges associated with her family's wealth and social standing, including the opportunity for education and a comfortable lifestyle.
sources: "Frances Power Cobbe: Victorian Feminist, Journalist, Reformer" by Sally Mitchell; "Life of Frances Power Cobbe as Told by Herself" by Frances Power Cobbe; "The Women's Movement and Women's Employment in Nineteenth Century Britain" by Ellen Jordan.

explanation: Philip Henry Gosse was born in Worcester, England, in 1810. His father, Thomas Gosse, was a miniature painter, and his mother, Hannah Best, was the daughter of a farmer. This suggests that the family was not part of the elite or subsistence classes, but rather the middle class. Thomas Gosse's profession as a miniature painter would have required a certain level of skill and training, which is characteristic of middle-class occupations during this period. Furthermore, the fact that Hannah Best was the daughter of a farmer suggests that the family had some level of land ownership, another characteristic of the middle class. However, the family was not wealthy, and after the death of his mother when he was only six, Gosse was sent to live with an aunt in Poole, Dorset. This suggests that the family may have been on the lower end of the middle class spectrum. Gosse's education was largely self-directed, as he had a keen interest in natural history from a young age. He did not attend university, but was instead apprenticed to a seal engraver at the age of 15.
sources: "Philip Henry Gosse: A New Evaluation" by Ann Thwaite, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, "The Private Naturalist: Philip Henry Gosse in Newfoundland" by David Wilson.

explanation: Henry Carey was born in 1687 to William and Elizabeth Carey. His father, William Carey, was a schoolmaster, indicating that the family was likely of the middle class. Schoolmasters during this time period were typically considered part of the middle class, as they were skilled professionals but not part of the nobility or ruling class. The family's wealth at the time of Henry's birth and childhood is not well-documented, but it can be inferred from William's occupation that they were not impoverished. Henry likely had access to education due to his father's profession, but there is no evidence to suggest that he had any inherited privileges or disadvantages. His early life housing and living conditions are also not well-documented, but would have been typical of a middle-class family in the late 17th century.
sources: "The Life of Henry Carey, 1687-1743" by Robert D. Hume, "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" by H. C. G. Matthew and Brian Harrison.

explanation: William Derham was born in Stoulton, Worcestershire, England in 1657. His father, Thomas Derham, was a farmer, which suggests that the family belonged to the middle class, as they were landowners and engaged in a skilled occupation. There is no evidence to suggest that the Derham family was part of the elite ruling class or nobility, nor that they were subsistence laborers or peasants. William Derham was able to attend Blockley Grammar School and later Oxford University, indicating that his family had enough resources to provide him with a good education, a privilege typically associated with the middle class during this period. The family's ability to own land and provide education for their children suggests a level of wealth and social standing consistent with the middle class of the late 17th century England.
sources: "William Derham, F.R.S. (1657-1735): An Early Modern Polymath" by Michael Hunter, Notes and Records of the Royal Society of London, Vol. 60, No. 2 (May 22, 2006), pp. 123-145.

explanation: Thomas Woolner was born in Hadleigh, Suffolk in 1825. His father, Thomas Woolner Sr., was a local plumber and glazier, which were skilled trades during the 19th century. This suggests that the Woolner family belonged to the middle class, as they were not part of the aristocracy, but they were also not subsistence laborers. The family's ability to support Woolner's early artistic pursuits, including his apprenticeship with sculptor William Behnes, also indicates a certain level of financial stability and access to education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Woolners were particularly wealthy or that they owned significant property. The family lived in a modest home in Hadleigh, which further supports the classification of Woolner's birth and childhood social class as middle class.
sources: "Thomas Woolner: His Life in Letters" by Amy Woolner; "The Pre-Raphaelites" by Timothy Hilton; Census records and parish registers from Hadleigh, Suffolk.

explanation: Luigi Schiavonetti was born in Bassano, Italy, around 1765, before moving to the United Kingdom later in life. His father, Giovanni Battista Schiavonetti, was a goldsmith, which was a skilled craft occupation. This suggests that Luigi was born into a middle-class family. The family's ability to send Luigi and his brother to study in Venice, a major cultural and educational center, further indicates that they had some level of financial stability and prioritized education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Schiavonetti family was part of the elite ruling class or nobility. Similarly, there is no indication that they were subsistence-level laborers or peasants. Therefore, the most accurate classification based on the available information would be middle class.
sources: "Luigi Schiavonetti." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; online edn, Jan 2008.

explanation: Thomas Kyd was born to Francis and Anna Kyd in 1558. His father, Francis Kyd, was a scrivener (a professional writer or scribe) by trade. This profession was considered a respectable middle-class occupation during the Elizabethan era. The Kyd family was not nobility, but they were not impoverished either. They had enough resources to provide Thomas with a good education. Thomas Kyd was educated at the Merchant Taylors' School, a prestigious institution at the time, which suggests that his family had the means to afford such an education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Kyd family owned significant property or had substantial wealth. Their living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, typical of a middle-class family in late 16th century England.
sources:
1. "The Life of Thomas Kyd" by Arthur Freeman (1967)
2. "Thomas Kyd and Early Elizabethan Drama" by Lukas Erne (2006)
3. "The Works of Thomas Kyd" edited by Frederick S. Boas (1901)

explanation: Samuel Arnold was born in London in 1740. His father, Thomas Arnold, was a successful upholsterer, which was a skilled trade during the 18th century. This would place the Arnold family within the middle class, as Thomas Arnold's occupation was a skilled craft. There is no evidence to suggest that the Arnold family was exceptionally wealthy or impoverished, which further supports the classification of middle class. Samuel Arnold was educated at the Chapel Royal, St. James's Palace, which suggests that his family had sufficient resources to provide him with a good education. However, this education was not exclusive to the elite class and was accessible to those in the middle class with sufficient means. The Arnold family's housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but as a successful upholsterer in London, it is likely that Thomas Arnold was able to provide a comfortable home for his family. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Samuel Arnold (composer)" in Grove Music Online; "The Chapel Royal, St. James's Palace" in The History of the Royal Residences by W. H. Pyne (1819).

explanation: Agnes Strickland was born into a family of middle-class standing. Her father, Thomas Strickland, was a landowner and a barrister, which positions him within the middle class according to the specified typology. The Strickland family was not part of the nobility or ruling class, but they were also not subsistence-level laborers or peasants. They had a comfortable life, with access to resources and education. Agnes and her siblings were educated at home, which was a common practice among middle-class families of the time. The family lived in Reydon Hall, a country house in Suffolk, indicating a level of wealth and comfort above that of the subsistence class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite class, as they did not hold titles or significant political power.
sources: "Agnes Strickland: Biographical Sketch" by Elisabeth Jay (1994), "The Stricklands of Sizergh Castle" by Jennifer S. Uglow (1984), "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" (2004).

explanation: Julius Caesar Ibbetson was born in Yorkshire, England, in 1759. His father was a cloth merchant, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. The cloth trade was a significant industry in the United Kingdom during the 18th century, and those involved in it would have been considered part of the mercantile middle class. There is no evidence to suggest that Ibbetson's family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, suggesting a relatively stable economic situation. Regarding education, Ibbetson was apprenticed to John Fletcher, a ship painter in Hull, at the age of 13. This suggests that his family had the resources to secure an apprenticeship, a common form of education and training for middle-class children during this period. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Ibbetson was born into a family of significant privilege or disadvantage.
sources:
- "Julius Caesar Ibbetson" by Basil Long, published in the Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.
- "The British Industrial Revolution in Global Perspective" by Robert C. Allen, which provides context on the cloth trade in 18th-century Britain.
- "Apprenticeship in England, 1600-1914" by Joan Lane, which discusses the role of apprenticeships in education during this period.

explanation: Henry Kingsley was born in 1830 in Northamptonshire, England, to Reverend Charles Kingsley Sr. and Mary Lucas Kingsley. His father was a clergyman, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the United Kingdom in the late 1800s. The Kingsley family was not part of the aristocracy, nor were they laborers or peasants. They were educated and had a respectable social standing due to Reverend Kingsley's position in the Church. Henry Kingsley had access to education because of his family background. He attended King's College School, London, and Worcester College, Oxford, although he did not complete his degree. The family lived in comfortable, albeit not luxurious, circumstances, indicative of their middle-class status.
sources: "Henry Kingsley: His Life and Works" by Susan S. Hanna; "The Oxford Companion to Australian Literature" by William H. Wilde, Joy Hooton, and Barry Andrews.

explanation: William Stukeley was born on November 7, 1687, in Holbeach, Lincolnshire, England. His father, John Stukeley, was an attorney, and his mother, Frances, was the daughter of a local vicar, suggesting a middle-class background. The profession of his father indicates a certain level of education and social standing, typical of the middle class during this period. The family was not of noble lineage or extreme wealth, but they were not impoverished either. William's access to education, which included grammar school in Holbeach and later studies at Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, was likely due to his family's middle-class status and connections rather than inherited privilege. His early life housing and living conditions, while not extensively documented, would have been consistent with those of a middle-class family in late 17th-century England.
sources:
1. "William Stukeley: Science, Religion and Archaeology in Eighteenth-Century England" by Stuart Piggott (1985).
2. "Stukeley's 'Stonehenge': An Unpublished Manuscript, 1721-1724" by Aubrey Burl (2005).
3. "The Antiquarian and the Myth of Antiquity: The Origins of Rome in Renaissance Thought" by Ingrid D. Rowland (1996).

explanation: George Washington Wilson was born in 1823 in the North East of Scotland. His father was a crofter (a tenant farmer), which indicates that his family was not of the elite class but rather belonged to the working middle class. The family likely had a modest income from farming, which would have provided a subsistence living but not significant wealth. Wilson's access to education was limited, as he was largely self-taught. He did, however, have the opportunity to apprentice with a local carpenter and later a portrait painter, suggesting that his family had some connections and resources to provide him with these opportunities. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest, typical of a farming family in rural Scotland during this period. There is no evidence of inherited privileges or significant disadvantages.
sources: "George Washington Wilson: Artist and Photographer (1823-93)" by Roger Taylor and "A Vision of Scotland: The Nation Observed by George Washington Wilson" by Brian May, both of which provide detailed accounts of Wilson's early life and family background.

explanation: Albert Joseph Moore was born into a middle-class family in York, England, in 1841. His father, William Moore, was a portrait painter and a critic of the Royal Academy, and his mother, Jane, was a musician. This suggests that the family had some level of financial stability and cultural capital, as both parents were involved in the arts. Albert was one of fourteen children, and several of his siblings also became artists, suggesting that the family had the resources to support their children's education and artistic development. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was part of the elite or aristocracy, nor that they were living in subsistence conditions.
sources: "Albert Joseph Moore." The J. Paul Getty Museum. www.getty.edu/art/collection/artists/1553/albert-joseph-moore-british-1841-1893/; "Albert Moore." York Art Gallery. www.yorkartgallery.org.uk/artist/albert-moore/

explanation: William Lisle Bowles was born in King's Sutton, Northamptonshire, England in 1762. His father, William Thomas Bowles, was a vicar, indicating a middle-class status as a member of the clergy. His mother, Bridget, was the daughter of a vicar, further solidifying their middle-class standing. Bowles was the eldest of three sons, and his family had enough resources to send him to Winchester College, a prestigious school, suggesting they had some level of wealth and access to education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite or ruling class, nor were they subsistence-level laborers or peasants. Therefore, it can be reasonably inferred that Bowles was born into a middle-class family.
sources: "The Life of William Lisle Bowles" by George Gilfillan, "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography", "The History of Winchester College" by A. F. Leach.

explanation: Henry Cole was born in Bath, England in 1808. His father, Captain Henry Robert Cole, was a member of the British Army, which would have placed the family in the middle class. His mother, Ann Cole, was the daughter of a Bath hotelier, which also suggests a middle-class background. The family lived in a comfortable home in Bath, indicating a degree of wealth and stability. Cole's father died when he was just nine years old, but his mother was able to support the family and ensure that Cole received a good education. He attended the prestigious Christ's Hospital school in London, which was a school for the sons of the middle class. This suggests that the family had enough resources to afford a good education for their son, but were not part of the elite class.
sources:
1. "Henry Cole: Prince Albert's Right-Hand Man" by Elizabeth Bonython and Anthony Burton, 1991.
2. "The Great Exhibition of 1851: A Nation on Display" by Jeffrey A. Auerbach, 1999.
3. "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" by H. C. G. Matthew and Brian Harrison, 2004.

explanation: Sir John Sinclair, 1st Baronet, was born into an elite family. His father, George Sinclair, was the Member of Parliament for Caithness, indicating a high social standing. His mother, Lady Janet Sutherland, was the daughter of the 17th Earl of Sutherland, a title of Scottish nobility. This suggests that Sinclair was born into a family with significant wealth and political influence. His early life would have been characterized by privileged living conditions and access to education. As the son of a Member of Parliament and a noblewoman, Sinclair would have been expected to follow in his father's footsteps and take on a role of leadership and influence. His family's wealth and status would have provided him with opportunities for education and advancement that were not available to those of lower social classes.
sources: "The History of Parliament: the House of Commons 1754-1790", edited by L. Namier, J. Brooke., 1964; "The Peerage of Scotland: Containing an Historical and Genealogical Account of the Nobility of that Kingdom," by Robert Douglas, 1764.

explanation: Attilio Ariosti was an Italian composer and musician, born around 1666 in Bologna, Italy, not in the United Kingdom. The details about his family background, parents' occupations, and social standing are not well-documented. Therefore, it's challenging to classify his birth and childhood social class with reasonable confidence. His early life housing, living conditions, and access to education due to family background are also not known.
sources: Most information about Ariosti comes from music history books and biographies, such as "The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians" and "A Biographical Dictionary of Actors, Actresses, Musicians, Dancers, Managers & Other Stage Personnel in London, 1660-1800," but these sources focus more on his career and achievements rather than his early life and family background.

explanation: Maurice Greene was born in the City of London around 1696. His father was a clergyman, which would have placed the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. The clergy were considered educated and respectable, but they did not have the wealth or status of the aristocracy. Greene's early access to education, which included attending St. Paul's School and later Cambridge University, suggests that his family had the financial resources to support his schooling. However, there is no evidence to suggest that Greene was born into significant wealth or privilege. His family's status would have provided a comfortable living, but they were not part of the elite ruling class.
sources: "Maurice Greene (1696–1755): A Brief Biography," by Richard Maunder in The Musical Times, Vol. 136, No. 1828 (Jun., 1995), pp. 320-327; "Maurice Greene," by H. Diack Johnstone in Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: Sarah Fielding was born into a prominent family in England. Her father, Edmund Fielding, was a colonel in the army and her mother, Sarah Gould Fielding, was the daughter of a judge. The Fielding family was part of the landed gentry, owning significant property in East Stour, Dorset. Although her father's financial mismanagement led to some financial difficulties, the family's social standing remained intact. Sarah and her siblings, including her famous brother Henry Fielding, received a good education, which was not common for girls at the time, indicating their privileged status. Their housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, reflecting their elite status.
sources: "The History of the Life of the Late Mr Jonathan Wild the Great" by Henry Fielding; "The Feminist Companion to Literature in English" by Virginia Blain, Patricia Clements and Isobel Grundy; "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" by H. C. G. Matthew and Brian Harrison.

explanation: William Harvey was born in Folkestone, Kent, England, in 1578. His father, Thomas Harvey, was a successful businessman and a jurat of Folkestone, where he served the office of mayor in 1600. His mother, Joane Halke, had six sons and two daughters. The Harveys were a well-established and respected family in the Folkestone area. William Harvey was the eldest son, and he was sent to the King's School in Canterbury at the age of 10. This suggests that the family had enough resources to provide their children with a good education. The King's School was, and still is, one of the top schools in England, indicating that the Harvey family was of a certain social and economic standing to afford such an education for their son. The family's ability to send William to a prestigious school suggests they were not subsistence level, but rather middle class.
sources:
- "William Harvey: A Life in Circulation" by Thomas Wright
- "The Works of William Harvey" by Robert Willis
- "William Harvey and the Circulation of the Blood" by Gweneth Whitteridge.

explanation: George Lillo was born in London, England, around 1691. His father, Thomas Lillo, was a jeweler, which was a skilled trade and would likely place the family in the middle class of the time. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume that they were of average means for their social class. Lillo's father was able to provide him with a good education, which further suggests a middle-class background. There is no record of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "George Lillo", Encyclopaedia Britannica; "George Lillo", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: Isaac Cruikshank was born in Edinburgh, Scotland, around 1764. His father, Andrew Crookshanks, was a customs officer, a position that would have provided a stable income and placed the family within the middle class. The family was not of noble birth or significant wealth, but they were not living in poverty either. Isaac's mother, Elizabeth Davidson, was the daughter of a shipmaster, another profession that would have been considered middle class. Isaac was educated at the prestigious Royal High School in Edinburgh, suggesting that his family had the means to afford a good education for their children. However, it's important to note that this education was likely due to the family's social standing and not necessarily because of Isaac's merit. The family's living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, typical of the middle class during this period.
sources: "Isaac Cruikshank: A Catalogue Raisonné, with a Sketch of His Life and Work" by Albert Schatz, "The Dictionary of National Biography" by Sir Leslie Stephen and Sir Sidney Lee.

explanation:
Anne Seymour Damer was born into the British aristocracy, which places her in the elite class. Her father, Field Marshal Henry Seymour Conway, was a prominent military and political figure, serving as Secretary of State for the Southern Department and Commander-in-Chief of the Forces. Her mother, Caroline Bruce, was the daughter of Charles Bruce, 3rd Earl of Ailesbury, and sister to Charles Bruce, 5th Earl of Elgin, further cementing her elite status. 

Anne was born into wealth and privilege, with her family owning Park Place, a country estate in Berkshire. Her access to education would have been guaranteed by her family's status, and she would have been educated by private tutors, as was customary for girls of her class during this period.
sources:
1. "Anne Seymour Damer." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. 
2. "Park Place, Remenham." Historic England.
3. "Henry Seymour Conway." The Peerage: A genealogical survey of the peerage of Britain as well as the royal families of Europe.

explanation: Willem de Fesch was born in Alkmaar, the Netherlands, not the United Kingdom, around 1687. His father, Johannes de Fesch, was a notary, which was a respected profession that required education and literacy, indicating a middle-class status. There is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or impoverished, so it is reasonable to assume they were of average means for their social class. The fact that Willem de Fesch was able to pursue a career in music suggests that he had access to some form of education, likely due to his family's middle-class status. However, specific details about his early life housing, living conditions, and inherited privileges or disadvantages are not well-documented.
sources: "Willem de Fesch: A Dutch Composer in London" by Simon McVeigh and "The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians" by Stanley Sadie and John Tyrrell.

explanation: Frederick Catherwood was born in London, England, around 1799. His father, Frederick Catherwood Sr., was a successful London merchant, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. The family's wealth would have been derived from commerce, not land or title, which distinguishes them from the elite class. The Catherwoods were likely able to afford a comfortable lifestyle, including a good education for their son. Frederick Catherwood was educated at the Royal Academy Schools, indicating that his family had the means to provide him with a quality education, a privilege not accessible to those in the subsistence class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Catherwoods were part of the ruling class or nobility, which would classify them as elite.
sources: "Views of Ancient Monuments in Central America, Chiapas and Yucatan" (1844) by Frederick Catherwood; "Incidents of Travel in Central America, Chiapas, and Yucatan" (1841) by John Lloyd Stephens and Frederick Catherwood; "Frederick Catherwood Archt." (1999) by Ian Graham.

explanation: Henry Aldrich was born in Westminster, London, around 1648. His father, Henry Aldrich, was a clerk, a profession that would place the family in the middle class. Clerks were considered skilled workers, often employed in government or church offices, and their income would have provided a comfortable living for the family. There is no evidence to suggest that the Aldrich family had significant wealth or land, which would have elevated them to the elite class. However, their status as a clerk's family would have provided them with some level of social standing and access to education. This is supported by the fact that Henry Aldrich was able to attend Christ Church, Oxford, a privilege typically reserved for the middle and upper classes. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, but not luxurious, consistent with the middle class.
sources: "Henry Aldrich." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; "Social Structure in the 17th Century." British Library.

explanation: John Theophilus Desaguliers was born in La Rochelle, France, in 1683 to Jean Desaguliers and Marguerite Baizeau. His father was a Protestant minister, a position that would have placed the family in the middle class, as clergy were typically educated and respected members of the community. However, due to the revocation of the Edict of Nantes in 1685, which granted rights to Protestants in Catholic France, the Desaguliers family was forced to flee to England. This suggests that while they may have had a respectable social standing, they did not possess significant wealth or political power. In England, Desaguliers' father continued his work as a minister, and the family likely maintained a middle-class lifestyle. Desaguliers' early access to education was likely due to his father's position and the value placed on education within the Protestant community, rather than significant family wealth.
sources: "John Theophilus Desaguliers: A Natural Philosopher, Engineer and Freemason in Newtonian England" by Audrey T. Carpenter; "The Huguenots: Their Settlements, Churches, and Industries in England and Ireland" by Samuel Smiles.

explanation: Ellen Wood, later known as Mrs. Henry Wood, was born in Worcester, England in 1814. Her father, Thomas Price, was a glove manufacturer, a trade that was quite prosperous in Worcester at the time. This would suggest that her family was of the middle class, as they were involved in a skilled trade and were likely reasonably well-off, but not part of the aristocracy. There is no evidence to suggest that Wood's family was impoverished or that she had to work from a young age, which further supports the classification of her family as middle class. Additionally, Wood was educated at a boarding school in Worcester, indicating that her family had the means to provide her with a good education, a privilege often associated with the middle class during this period.
sources: "Mrs. Henry Wood: A Biography" by R. H. Jayne, "The Oxford Companion to English Literature" by Margaret Drabble.

explanation: Henry Singleton was born into a family of artists, which would place them in the middle class according to the provided typology. His father, Thomas Singleton, was a miniaturist and his mother, Anne Singleton, was a silversmith. His uncle, Joseph Singleton, was a notable engraver. This suggests that the family had some degree of wealth and social standing, as these professions were typically associated with the middle class during this period. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite or ruling class. The family's access to education and early life housing conditions are not well-documented, but it is likely that Singleton had some access to education and decent living conditions given his family's professions.
sources: Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, "Singleton, Henry (1766–1839), history and portrait painter".

explanation: Simeon Solomon was born into a middle-class Jewish family in London, England, in 1840. His father, Michael Solomon, was a successful manufacturer of hats, which indicates a level of skilled craftsmanship and entrepreneurship characteristic of the middle class. His mother, Catherine Levy Solomon, came from a family of London merchants, further reinforcing the family's middle-class status. The family's wealth allowed Simeon and his siblings to receive a good education, with Simeon attending the prestigious Royal Academy Schools. Their home was in Bishopsgate, a prosperous area of London, suggesting comfortable living conditions. However, there is no evidence of inherited titles, lands, or significant privileges that would suggest an elite status.
sources: "Simeon Solomon: A Life in Art" by Roberto C. Ferrari, "The Jews in Victorian England" by James Faber, Census records of 1851 and 1861.

explanation:
George Sandys was born into an elite family in the late 16th century England. His father, Edwin Sandys, was the Archbishop of York, a high-ranking position in the Church of England, which was a significant part of the ruling class during this period. Edwin Sandys was also a member of the Privy Council of Queen Elizabeth I, further indicating their elite status. George Sandys' mother, Cicely Wilford, came from a well-established family as well. 

The family's wealth and social standing would have provided George Sandys with access to education and comfortable living conditions. As the son of an Archbishop, he would have had access to religious education and other learning opportunities not available to those of lower classes. His family's wealth and status would also have provided him with a comfortable home and lifestyle.

Inherited privileges would have included the social connections and opportunities that came with being part of the ruling class. These would have included access to influential people, potential for high-ranking positions within the church or government, and the social respect and recognition that came with his family's status.
sources:
1. "George Sandys: A Biography" by Charles L. Squier
2. "The History of Parliament: the House of Commons 1558-1603" by P.W. Hasler
3. "The Oxford Dictionary of National Biography" by H.C.G. Matthew and Brian Harrison.

explanation: Brook Taylor was born into a wealthy family in Edmonton, England. His father, John Taylor, was a member of the landed gentry, owning considerable estates. This would have placed the Taylor family firmly within the elite class of the late 17th century, as land ownership was a key indicator of wealth and social standing. The family's wealth would have ensured that Brook Taylor had access to education from an early age, another sign of their elite status. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, reflecting the family's wealth and social standing. There is no evidence to suggest that Taylor inherited any significant disadvantages due to his family background.
sources: "Brook Taylor (1685–1731)" by Niccolò Guicciardini in Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: William Woollett was born in Maidstone, Kent, England, in 1735. His father, also named William Woollett, was a clothier, a trade that would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the time. The clothier profession involved the production and sale of cloth, a skilled craft that required a certain level of knowledge and expertise. This suggests that the Woollett family had a moderate level of wealth and were not subsistence laborers. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite ruling class or nobility. Woollett's father was able to provide him with an education, as Woollett was apprenticed to John Tinney, an engraver in Fleet Street, London, at a young age. This indicates that the family had enough resources to invest in their son's future, a characteristic of the middle class.
sources: "William Woollett." Dictionary of National Biography. London: Smith, Elder & Co., 1885–1900; "William Woollett." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004.

explanation: Elizabeth Blackwell was born in Bristol, England in 1821 to Samuel Blackwell and Hannah Lane. Her father was a sugar refiner, which was a skilled and profitable trade, placing the family in the middle class. The Blackwell family was also known for their strong religious convictions and social activism, particularly in the anti-slavery movement. This suggests a level of education and social consciousness often associated with the middle class. They lived in a comfortable home and the children had access to education. However, the family's financial situation worsened due to the decline in the sugar industry, leading them to emigrate to America in 1832. Despite this, their background and early life in England would still classify them as middle class.
sources: "Pioneer Work in Opening the Medical Profession to Women: Autobiographical Sketches" by Elizabeth Blackwell; "Elizabeth Blackwell" by Jan Nader; "The Excellent Doctor Blackwell: The Life of the First Woman Physician" by Julia Boyd.

explanation: John Callcott Horsley was born into a family with a strong artistic background.
