explanation: David Hume was born in Edinburgh, Scotland in 1711 to Joseph Home and Katherine Falconer Home. His father was a lawyer and minor landowner with a small estate in Berwickshire, which indicates a middle-class status. After his father's death when Hume was still a child, his mother raised him and his siblings. Despite not being wealthy, the family was not impoverished and Hume had access to a good education. He attended the University of Edinburgh at the age of 12, which was not uncommon at the time. This suggests that his family had the means to support his education, further indicating a middle-class background. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, typical of a middle-class family of the time. There is no evidence of significant inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "The Life of David Hume" by Ernest Campbell Mossner; "David Hume: Prophet of the Counter-revolution" by Laurence L. Bongie.

explanation: Joseph Addison was born in Milston, Wiltshire, England, in 1672. His father, Lancelot Addison, was a clergyman and scholar who held the position of Dean of Lichfield, indicating a position of some respect and moderate wealth within the community. This would place the family within the middle class, as clergy were often considered part of this social stratum during the late 17th century. The family's wealth and status would have been sufficient to provide Joseph with a good education, as evidenced by his attendance at Charterhouse School and later at Oxford University. However, these opportunities were likely due to his father's position and connections rather than extreme wealth. The family's living conditions would have been comfortable but not lavish, consistent with their middle-class status.
sources: "Joseph Addison: English essayist and poet." Encyclopaedia Britannica. "The Life of Joseph Addison." The Cambridge History of English and American Literature.

explanation:
John Locke was born in 1632 in Wrington, Somerset, England. His father, also named John Locke, was a country lawyer and clerk to the Justices of the Peace in Chew Magna, who had served as a captain of cavalry for the Parliamentarian forces during the early part of the English Civil War. His mother, Agnes Keene, was a tanner's daughter and reputed to be very beautiful. Both parents were Puritans. 

The Locke family was neither wealthy nor aristocratic, but they were well-to-do, and had the means to invest in their son's education. Locke's father's military service had earned him the favor of Alexander Popham, a local Member of Parliament, who arranged for Locke to receive a quality education. Locke was admitted to Westminster School in London under Popham's patronage. 

Locke's early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, typical of the middle class of the time. He did not inherit any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth.
sources: "John Locke: A Biography" by Maurice Cranston; "John Locke: His American and Carolinian Legacy" by George M. Stephens.

explanation: Thomas Hardy was born on June 2, 1840, in Higher Bockhampton, Dorset, England. His father, also named Thomas, was a stonemason and local builder. His mother, Jemima, was well-read and educated Hardy until he began attending his first school at Bockhampton at the age of eight. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They were able to afford a modest education for Hardy, who attended local schools before being apprenticed to a local architect at the age of 16. The family lived in a rural cottage, which was comfortable but not luxurious. Hardy's family background did not provide him with any significant inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Thomas Hardy: A Biography Revisited" by Michael Millgate; "Thomas Hardy: The Time-Torn Man" by Claire Tomalin.

explanation: Laurence Sterne was born in Clonmel, County Tipperary, Ireland in 1713. His father, Roger Sterne, was an ensign in a British regiment recently returned from Dunkirk, which was disbanded on the day of Sterne's birth. His mother, Agnes Nuttle, was the widow of a military captain. Sterne's father's military career meant that the family moved frequently throughout Britain and Ireland. Despite the instability, Sterne was able to receive an education due to his family's connections. His great-grandfather, Richard Sterne, had been the Archbishop of York, and through this connection, Sterne was admitted to Jesus College, Cambridge in 1733. However, the family was not wealthy and Sterne's father died in debt. Sterne's early life was marked by poverty and hardship, but his family's connections allowed him access to education and a path to upward mobility.
sources: "The Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy, Gentleman" by Laurence Sterne, "Laurence Sterne: A Life" by Ian Campbell Ross, "The Cambridge Companion to Laurence Sterne" edited by Thomas Keymer.

explanation: Thomas Carlyle was born on December 4, 1795, in Ecclefechan, Dumfriesshire, Scotland. His father, James Carlyle, was a stonemason and small farmer, and his mother, Margaret Aitken Carlyle, was a homemaker. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. Carlyle's parents were able to provide him with a basic education, and he was sent to Annan Grammar School at the age of nine. His family's circumstances allowed him to attend the University of Edinburgh at the age of fourteen, which was a privilege not available to those in the subsistence class. His early life housing and living conditions were modest but comfortable for the time and place. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Thomas Carlyle: A Biography" by Fred Kaplan, "The Life of Thomas Carlyle" by Richard Garnett, "Thomas Carlyle" by John Nichol.

explanation:
Robert Burns was born on January 25, 1759, in Alloway, South Ayrshire, Scotland. His parents, William Burnes and Agnes Broun, were tenant farmers, which placed them in the subsistence class. They struggled to maintain their farm and provide for their seven children. Burns' father attempted to improve their circumstances by building a house and trying to acquire a better farm, but his efforts were largely unsuccessful, and the family lived in poverty.

Despite their financial struggles, Burns' parents valued education and made efforts to ensure their children received some form of schooling. Burns' father taught his children reading, writing, arithmetic, geography, and history. Later, Burns was sent to a school in Dalrymple Parish, and then to a school in Kirkoswald, where he studied grammar, French, and Latin. However, these educational opportunities were not a result of the family's wealth or social standing, but rather their values and sacrifices.

Burns' early life housing and living conditions were poor. The family lived in a small house built by his father, and they struggled to make ends meet. Burns began working on the family farm at a young age, which further limited his educational opportunities.
sources:
- "Robert Burns." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Robert-Burns
- "Robert Burns - Life & Work." Robert Burns

explanation: John Dryden was born in Aldwincle, Northamptonshire, England, to Erasmus Dryden and Mary Pickering. His father was a landowner, and his mother was the daughter of a rector, indicating a middle-class background. The Dryden family was not nobility, but they were well-established and respected in their community. They had enough wealth to own land and provide a comfortable life for their family, including access to education. John Dryden was educated at Westminster School and later at Trinity College, Cambridge, which suggests that his family had the financial means to support his education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite ruling class or nobility.
sources:
1. "John Dryden." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/John-Dryden
2. "John Dryden." Poetry Foundation. https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/john-dryden
3. "John Dryden." The British Library. https://www.bl.uk/people/john-dryden
4. "John Dryden." The Literature Network. http://www.online-literature.com/dryden/

explanation:
William Wordsworth was born in Cockermouth, Cumberland, in the Lake District of Northwestern England on April 7, 1770. His father, John Wordsworth, was a legal representative for Sir James Lowther, who was one of the wealthiest landowners in the region. This position provided the Wordsworth family with a comfortable income, placing them firmly within the middle class. The family lived in a large mansion, indicating a level of wealth and comfort above subsistence living. However, they were not part of the elite ruling class or nobility. 

Wordsworth's access to education was also indicative of his middle-class status. He attended Hawkshead Grammar School and later studied at St. John's College in Cambridge, both of which were opportunities afforded to him by his family's financial standing. 

Inherited privileges included a good education and a comfortable upbringing, but the family was not without its disadvantages. Wordsworth's mother died when he was just seven years old, and his father's death five years later led to legal disputes over Sir Lowther's debt to the estate, causing financial instability for the family.
sources:
- "William Wordsworth." Poetry Foundation. https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/william-wordsworth
- "William Wordsworth." Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/William-Wordsworth
- Moorman, Mary. "William Wordsworth: A Biography."

explanation: Edward Bulwer-Lytton was born into a wealthy and influential family. His father, General William Earle Bulwer, was a military officer and his mother, Elizabeth Barbara Lytton, was a member of the Lytton family, who held the Knebworth House in Hertfordshire. The Bulwer-Lytton family was part of the British aristocracy, with a long history of political and social influence. Edward was the youngest of three sons, and after the death of his father when he was just four years old, he inherited the family estates. His mother ensured that he received a high-quality education, first at home and then at prestigious schools like Dr. Hooker's private school, Ealing School, and later at Cambridge University. This level of education was typically only accessible to the elite class during this period. The family's wealth and social standing provided Edward with a privileged upbringing, including living in grand houses and estates.
sources:
- "Edward Bulwer-Lytton." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Edward-Bulwer-Lytton-1st-Baron-Lytton
- "Edward Bulwer-Lytton." The Victorian Web. http://www.victorianweb.org/authors/bulwer/bio.html
- "Edward Bulwer-Lytton." Spartacus Educational. https://spartacus-educational.com/

explanation: Oliver Goldsmith was born in 1728 in Ireland, not the United Kingdom. His father, Charles Goldsmith, was a clergyman of the Church of Ireland, which would place the family in the middle class according to the provided typology. The family was not wealthy, but they were not subsistence-level either. Charles Goldsmith's position as a clergyman would have provided the family with a certain level of social standing and respectability, as well as a stable, if modest, income. Oliver Goldsmith was able to attend Trinity College, Dublin, suggesting that the family had enough resources to provide him with an education. However, it's worth noting that his attendance at Trinity College was not without financial struggle, indicating that the family was not of high wealth. His early life housing would have been modest, in line with the family's middle-class status.
sources: "Oliver Goldsmith: A Biography" by Washington Irving; "The Vicar of Wakefield" by Oliver Goldsmith (semi-autobiographical); "Oliver Goldsmith" by Richard Garnett.

explanation: Henry Purcell was born into a family with a strong connection to music and the arts, which suggests a middle-class background. His father, also named Henry Purcell, was a gentleman of the Chapel Royal, a prestigious position that involved providing music for royal occasions. This indicates that the family had a certain level of social standing and financial stability, but were not part of the ruling elite. After his father's death, Purcell was placed under the care of his uncle, Thomas Purcell, who was also a musician. This suggests that the family had the resources to ensure Purcell's continued upbringing and education in music. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, but not luxurious. There is no evidence to suggest that Purcell inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth.
sources: "Henry Purcell: A Life in Music" by Robert King, "The Life of Henry Purcell" by Maureen Duffy.

explanation: Joshua Reynolds was born in Plympton, Devon, England in 1723. His father, Samuel Reynolds, was a fellow of Balliol College, Oxford, and a master of the Plympton Free Grammar School. This indicates that Reynolds' family had a certain level of education and social standing, which is characteristic of the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite or aristocracy. Reynolds' father's occupation as a schoolmaster suggests that the family was not wealthy, but they were not living in poverty either. The fact that Reynolds was able to receive an education, presumably due to his father's occupation, further supports the classification of his family as middle class.
sources: "Sir Joshua Reynolds", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography; "Sir Joshua Reynolds", Encyclopaedia Britannica.

explanation:
Thomas Hobbes was born in Westport, now part of Malmesbury in Wiltshire, England, in 1588. His father, also named Thomas Hobbes, was a local vicar. His mother's name was Alice Hobbes. The family was not wealthy, but they were not poor either. As the son of a vicar, Hobbes would have been considered middle class. His father's occupation provided a stable, if modest, income and a certain level of social respectability. 

Hobbes' access to education was a direct result of his family background. His uncle, a tradesman with no children of his own, provided for Hobbes' education. He was able to attend a grammar school in Westport and later went on to study at Magdalen Hall, which is now Hertford College, Oxford. This level of education was not common for the lower classes, further suggesting that Hobbes was born into a middle-class family.

Hobbes' early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable. As the vicar's family, they would have lived in the vicarage, a house provided by the church. This would have been a step above the living conditions of the lower classes, but not as luxurious as the homes of the wealthy.
sources: - "Thomas Hobbes." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography

explanation: John Henry Newman was born on February 21, 1801, in London, England. His father, John Newman, was a banker in the City of London. His mother, Jemima Fourdrinier, came from a family of Huguenot paper makers who owned a paper mill in Hampshire. This suggests that the family was of the middle class, as they were involved in skilled professions and business, but were not part of the aristocracy or ruling class. Newman's family was able to afford a private tutor for him and his siblings, indicating a certain level of wealth and access to education. However, the family's fortunes declined due to the financial crisis of 1816 and the bank's subsequent failure, causing Newman to withdraw from school and be tutored at home. This suggests that while the family had some wealth, it was not substantial or secure enough to weather economic downturns.
sources: "John Henry Newman: A Biography" by Ian Ker, Oxford University Press, 2009; "The Life of John Henry, Cardinal Newman: Based on His Private Journals and Correspondence" by Wilfrid Ward, Longmans, Green, and Co., 1912.

explanation:
John Donne was born into a Roman Catholic family in London, England, around 1572. His father, also named John Donne, was a warden of the Ironmongers Company, which was a trade guild for those involved in the iron industry. This suggests that the family was of the middle class, as they were involved in a skilled trade but were not part of the nobility. His mother, Elizabeth Heywood, was the daughter of a playwright and a relative of Sir Thomas More, indicating some level of social standing, but not necessarily wealth. 

Donne's father died when he was very young, leaving the family in a precarious financial situation. However, Donne was still able to receive a good education, attending both Hart Hall, Oxford, and the University of Cambridge, although he did not take a degree at either institution due to his Catholic faith. This suggests that the family had enough resources to provide for his education, a typical characteristic of the middle class.
sources:
1. Bald, R.C. (1970). John Donne: A Life. Oxford University Press.
2. Carey, J. (2008). John Donne: Life, Mind and Art. Faber & Faber.
3. LeComte, Edward. (1985). Grace to a Witty Sinner: A Life of Donne. Walker.

explanation: James McNeill Whistler was born in Lowell, Massachusetts, USA, not the United Kingdom. His father, George Washington Whistler, was a prominent engineer, and his mother, Anna Matilda McNeill, came from a middle-class family. His father's work as a railroad engineer would have provided a comfortable, middle-class lifestyle for the family. Whistler's father was hired by the Russian government to build a railroad, which led to the family moving to Russia when Whistler was nine. This suggests that the family had a certain level of financial stability and social standing. Whistler was able to attend the Imperial Academy of Fine Arts in Saint Petersburg due to his family's status, indicating access to education. The family returned to the United States after the death of Whistler's father, but his mother's inheritance allowed them to maintain their middle-class status.
sources: "James McNeill Whistler: Biography, Paintings & Facts." Encyclopedia Britannica. "James McNeill Whistler." The Art Story. "James McNeill Whistler." National Gallery of Art.

explanation:
Bram Stoker was born on November 8, 1847, in Clontarf, Dublin, Ireland, which is now part of the United Kingdom. His father, Abraham Stoker, was a civil servant, working as a clerk in the civil service, and his mother, Charlotte Mathilda Blake Thornley, was a charity worker and writer. This indicates that the family was not part of the elite ruling class or nobility, but rather part of the middle class. 

The Stoker family was not wealthy, but they were not living in poverty either. They were able to provide for their seven children, of which Bram was the third. The family lived in a semi-detached house, a typical dwelling for middle-class families in the Victorian era.

Bram Stoker's access to education was also indicative of his middle-class background. He attended a private day school, the Metropolitan School of Art in Dublin, from the age of seven. This was not a privilege available to children from subsistence-level families, but was common among the middle class.
sources:
1. "Bram Stoker: A Biography of the Author of Dracula" by Barbara Belford, 1996.
2. "From the Shadow of Dracula: A Life of Bram Stoker" by Paul Murray, 2004.
3. "Bram Stoker's Notes for Dracula: A Facsimile Edition" by Robert Eighteen-Bis

explanation:
Thomas Gainsborough was born in Sudbury, Suffolk, England, in 1727. His father, John Gainsborough, was a weaver and a maker of woolen goods, which was a skilled trade and would have placed the family in the middle class. The family was not wealthy, but they were not poor either. They owned their own home and had enough income to support a large family. Thomas was the youngest of nine children. His mother, Mary Burrough, was also from a middle-class background. Her family were milliners, which was another skilled trade. 

Thomas's parents recognized his artistic talent early on and were able to send him to London to study art when he was just 13 years old. This suggests that the family had enough resources to invest in their son's education and future, which is another indicator of their middle-class status. 

Early life housing and living conditions for the Gainsborough family would have been comfortable but not luxurious. They lived in a house in Sudbury that is now the Gainsborough's House museum. The house is a typical example of a middle-class home of the period, with a workshop for John Gainsborough's business on the ground floor and living quarters above.
sources:
- "Gainsborough's House." Gainsborough's House, www.gainsborough.org.
- "Thomas Gainsborough." Encyclopædia Britannica, www.britannica

explanation: Ben Jonson was born in Westminster, London, around June 11, 1572, the posthumous son of a clergyman who had himself been a bricklayer before studying at Cambridge. His mother then married a bricklayer, which suggests a middle-class background. Jonson's stepfather likely had a stable income, but not one that would place the family in the elite class. Jonson was able to attend a good school, Westminster School, due to the patronage of a wealthy sponsor, not because of his family's wealth. This suggests that while his family was not poor, they were not wealthy enough to afford such an education on their own. His housing and living conditions would have been typical of a middle-class family in late 16th century England, likely comfortable but not luxurious.
sources: "Ben Jonson" by David Riggs (1989), "Ben Jonson: His Life and Work" by Rosalind Miles (1986), "The Cambridge Companion to Ben Jonson" edited by Richard Harp and Stanley Stewart (2000).

explanation: Samuel Johnson was born in Lichfield, Staffordshire, England in 1709. His father, Michael Johnson, was a bookseller and his mother, Sarah Ford, was the daughter of a country gentleman. While his father's business was somewhat successful, it was not enough to elevate the family to the upper class. Johnson's early education was provided by his mother and a nurse, and he later attended Lichfield Grammar School due to his father's connections in the town, indicating a middle-class upbringing. The family lived in a fairly comfortable home above the bookshop, but they were not wealthy. Johnson's father also served as a local magistrate, a position that further suggests a middle-class status. Despite these relatively comfortable circumstances, Johnson's family was plagued by debt, which would have limited their social mobility.
sources: "The Life of Samuel Johnson, LL.D." by James Boswell; "Samuel Johnson: A Biography" by Peter Martin.

explanation: Christopher Marlowe was born in Canterbury, England, around 1564, to John Marlowe and his wife Catherine. His father was a shoemaker, a skilled trade that would have placed the family in the middle class of the time. John Marlowe was also a warden of the Shoemakers' Guild, indicating a level of respect and responsibility within his profession. The family was not wealthy, but they were able to send Christopher to The King's School in Canterbury, a prestigious institution, and later to Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, on a scholarship. This suggests that they had some resources and valued education, typical of the middle class. However, it's important to note that the scholarship was not based on the family's wealth or status, but on Christopher's potential to enter the clergy. The family's housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but as a shoemaker in a city, John Marlowe would have likely had a comfortable, if modest, home.
sources: "Christopher Marlowe: A Renaissance Life" by Constance Brown Kuriyama; "The World of Christopher Marlowe" by David Riggs; Records of the Shoemakers' Guild; The King's School and Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, admission records.

explanation: Herbert Spencer was born in Derby, England in 1820. His father, William George Spencer, was a schoolmaster and a member of the 'Derby Philosophers', a group of individuals with interests in science and philosophy. His mother, Harriet Spencer, came from a relatively prosperous family. The Spencers were not wealthy, but they were not poor either. They were part of the middle class, with a strong emphasis on education and intellectual pursuits. Herbert Spencer was educated at home by his father and uncle, Thomas Spencer, who was a clergyman. This indicates that the family had enough resources to provide a good education for their children, a characteristic of the middle class. The family lived in a comfortable home and Herbert Spencer did not experience the hardships associated with the lower classes during his early life.
sources: "Herbert Spencer: British Social Philosopher." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Herbert-Spencer-British-philosopher. "Herbert Spencer." Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy. https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/spencer/.

explanation: John Bunyan was born in 1628 in Elstow, Bedfordshire, England, to Thomas Bunyan and Margaret Bentley. His father was a brazier or tinker, a profession that involved mending pots and pans, which was considered a low-status occupation. The family was poor and lived in a two-room cottage, which was a common living condition for the lower classes during this period. Bunyan's mother died when he was young, and his father remarried quickly, which was also typical of the subsistence class as remarriage was often a necessity for survival. Bunyan received some basic education, learning to read and write, but this was not due to his family's wealth or status, but rather a common practice in the Church of England at the time. His early life was marked by hardship and poverty, indicative of the subsistence class.
sources: "Grace Abounding to the Chief of Sinners" by John Bunyan; "John Bunyan: His Life, Times and Work" by John Brown; "The World of John Bunyan" by Christopher Hill.

explanation: Thomas Henry Huxley was born in Ealing, which was then a small village in the county of Middlesex. He was the seventh child of George Huxley, a schoolmaster and a mathematics teacher, and Rachel Withers. His father's occupation places the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. However, the family was not wealthy and struggled financially. Despite his father's profession, Huxley's formal schooling was erratic due to the family's financial difficulties. He received some education from his father and his siblings, but it was not consistent. His early life housing and living conditions were modest, reflecting the family's limited means. There were no inherited privileges or significant advantages due to his family background.
sources: "Thomas Henry Huxley: Making the 'Man of Science'" by Paul White, Cambridge University Press; "T.H. Huxley: Man's Place in Nature" by George Levine, University of Chicago Press.

explanation:
Edward Gibbon was born into a wealthy family in Putney, Surrey, England. His father, Edward Gibbon Sr., was a member of Parliament and had a significant fortune. Gibbon's mother, Judith Porten, was the daughter of a merchant, but her marriage to Gibbon Sr. elevated her social status. The Gibbon family was part of the landed gentry, owning considerable estates. 

As a child, Gibbon was often sick, and his family had the means to provide him with private tutors and send him to the best schools, including Westminster School and Magdalen College, Oxford. This access to education was a direct result of his family's wealth and social standing, not his personal merit. 

The Gibbon family lived in a large house in Putney, which was a fashionable area for the wealthy at the time. Gibbon's early life was characterized by comfort and privilege, indicative of his elite social class.
sources:
1. "Edward Gibbon, Esq: A Study in Eighteenth Century Biography" by D.M. Low
2. "The History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire" by Edward Gibbon (Autobiographical elements)
3. "Edward Gibbon and Empire" by Rosamond McKitterick and Roland Quinault
4. "Edward Gibbon: A Reference Guide" by Patricia B. Craddock

explanation: Adam Smith was born in Kirkcaldy, Scotland around 1723. His father, also named Adam Smith, was a lawyer and civil servant who served as the comptroller of the customs at Kirkcaldy, indicating a middle-class status. His mother, Margaret Douglas, came from a substantial landowning family. The family was not part of the nobility or ruling class, but they were not subsistence level either. They had enough wealth to provide Adam with a good education. Smith attended the Burgh School of Kirkcaldy where he studied Latin, mathematics, history, and writing. His early education was funded by his family, indicating they had the means to invest in his future. His living conditions were likely comfortable for the time, given his father's stable occupation and his mother's family wealth.
sources: "Adam Smith: An Enlightened Life" by Nicholas Phillipson; "The Life of Adam Smith" by Ian Simpson Ross.

explanation: Thomas Moore was born in Dublin, Ireland, in 1779. His father, John Moore, was a prosperous grocer and wine merchant, which suggests a middle-class status. His mother, Anastasia Codd, came from a family of Wexford merchants, further supporting the middle-class classification. Moore's family could afford to send him to a good school in Dublin, indicating they had some means. His early education at Samuel Whyte's English Grammar School in Dublin was not a privilege accessible to all, suggesting a level of family wealth and status above subsistence. However, there's no evidence to suggest that his family was part of the elite or nobility.
sources: "Thomas Moore: Ireland's National Poet" by Ronan Kelly, "The Life and Death of Lord Edward Fitzgerald" by Thomas Moore, "The History of Ireland" by Thomas Moore.

explanation:
Wilkie Collins was born on January 8, 1824, in London, England. His father, William Collins, was a well-known landscape painter and a member of the Royal Academy, which suggests a middle-class background. His mother, Harriet Geddes, was the daughter of a tea merchant, which further supports the middle-class classification. The family was not of aristocratic lineage, nor were they struggling for subsistence. 

In terms of education, Collins received a good one, which was typical for children of the middle class during this period. He was first educated at home by his mother and later attended the Maida Hill Academy. He also spent some time studying in Italy and France, which suggests that his family had the means to support his education abroad.

The family lived in a comfortable home in London's Marylebone neighborhood, which was a respectable and affluent area during the 19th century. This suggests that they had a decent amount of wealth and were able to maintain a comfortable lifestyle.
sources:
1. "Wilkie Collins: A Brief Life," by William Baker, The Wilkie Collins Society.
2. "Wilkie Collins: A Life of Sensation," by Andrew Lycett, Hutchinson, 2013.
3. "Wilkie Collins," by Peter Ackroyd, Chatto & Windus, 2012.

explanation: William Ewart Gladstone was born into a wealthy family. His father, Sir John Gladstone, was a successful merchant and a prominent figure in the West Indian trade, owning several sugar plantations. This wealth allowed the family to live comfortably and provided William with a privileged upbringing. He was educated at Eton, one of the most prestigious schools in England, and later at Christ Church, Oxford, both of which were accessible primarily to the upper classes during this period. The family lived in a large estate, Fasque, in Scotland, indicating their high social standing.
sources:
1. "The Grand Old Man: The Life and Times of Gladstone" by Richard Shannon
2. "Gladstone: A Biography" by Roy Jenkins
3. "The Gladstones: A Family Biography 1764–1851" by S. G. Checkland.

explanation: Mary Wollstonecraft was born on April 27, 1759, in Spitalfields, London. Her father, Edward John Wollstonecraft, was a weaver and then later became a farmer, which suggests a middle-class occupation. Her mother, Elizabeth Dixon, hailed from a somewhat prosperous Irish family. The family's financial situation was unstable, and they moved frequently due to her father's mismanagement of money and his violent, abusive behavior. Mary, as the second of seven children, had limited access to formal education, but she did receive some basic education, which was more than many girls of her time, indicating a middle-class background. Her early life housing and living conditions were modest, and she did not inherit any significant privileges or advantages.
sources: "The Life and Death of Mary Wollstonecraft" by Claire Tomalin; "Mary Wollstonecraft: A Revolutionary Life" by Janet Todd.

explanation: Benjamin Disraeli was born on December 21, 1804, in London, England. His father, Isaac D'Israeli, was a literary critic and historian, which would place the family in the middle class according to the provided typology. Isaac D'Israeli was also a member of the London Stock Exchange, indicating a degree of financial stability. The family was of Jewish descent, but Benjamin was baptized into the Church of England at the age of 12, following a dispute between his father and the synagogue. This religious conversion allowed Benjamin access to education and opportunities that were otherwise restricted for Jews in England at the time. The family lived in a comfortable house in Bloomsbury Square, further indicating their middle-class status.
sources:
1. Blake, Robert. "Disraeli, Benjamin, Earl of Beaconsfield (1804–1881), prime minister and novelist." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. 
2. Endelman, Todd M. "The Jews of Georgian England, 1714-1830: Tradition and Change in a Liberal Society." University of Michigan Press, 1999.
3. Weintraub, Stanley. "Disraeli: A Biography." Dutton, 1993.

explanation: John Constable was born in East Bergholt, a village in Suffolk, England, in 1776. His father, Golding Constable, was a wealthy corn merchant and owner of Flatford Mill in East Bergholt. His mother, Ann, was also from a prosperous family. The Constable family was well-to-do, but not part of the aristocracy, placing them firmly in the middle class of the time. John was the second son, and his older brother was intellectually disabled, so it was expected that John would take over his father's business. However, his interest in art was apparent from an early age. He was sent to a boarding school in Lavenham at a young age, indicating that his family had the means to provide him with a good education. His family's wealth and status also allowed him to pursue his interest in art, as he was able to study at the Royal Academy in London, a privilege not afforded to many during this time.
sources: "John Constable: The Man and his Art" by Ronald Parkinson (1998), "John Constable: A Kingdom of his Own" by Anthony Bailey (2007), "John Constable" by Charles Robert Leslie (1843).

explanation: Walter Crane was born in Liverpool, England, in 1845 to Thomas Crane, a portrait painter, and Marie Crane. His father's occupation as a portrait painter indicates that the family belonged to the middle class, as this was a skilled profession. It's likely that Crane's early exposure to his father's work influenced his own artistic development. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the family was particularly wealthy or that Crane had access to a high level of education due to his family background. The family lived in Torquay, then moved to London in 1857, suggesting they had some means but were not of the elite class. Crane's early life was likely comfortable but not luxurious, typical of a middle-class upbringing in the mid-19th century.
sources: "Walter Crane, 1845–1915: Artist, Illustrator and Socialist," by Isobel Spencer (1985); "Walter Crane: The Arts and Crafts, Painting, and Politics, 1875–1890," by Morna O'Neill (2010).

explanation: Edward Burne-Jones was born in Birmingham, England in 1833. His father, Edward Richard Jones, was a frame-maker and carver, which would place him in the category of skilled craftspeople. His mother, Elizabeth Coley Jones, died within six days of his birth, leaving him to be raised by his father and an unsympathetic housekeeper. Despite the loss of his mother, Burne-Jones's father was able to provide for him, suggesting a level of financial stability. As for education, Burne-Jones attended King Edward's School in Birmingham, a grammar school that was likely accessible due to his father's middle-class status. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of the middle class in the mid-19th century England.
sources: "Edward Burne-Jones: Victorian Artist-Dreamer" by Stephen Wildman and John Christian; "The Last Pre-Raphaelite: Edward Burne-Jones and the Victorian Imagination" by Fiona MacCarthy.

explanation: John Gay was born in Barnstaple, Devon, England in 1685. His father was a small landowner and a merchant, which would place the family in the middle class according to the given typology. Unfortunately, his father died when Gay was ten years old, leaving the family in financial difficulties. Despite these hardships, Gay was able to attend the local grammar school, suggesting that the family still had some resources and valued education. However, after the death of his mother, Gay had to be taken in by his uncle, who was also a merchant. This suggests that while the family had some means, they were not wealthy.
sources: "John Gay, English Writer." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/John-Gay-English-writer. "John Gay." Poetry Foundation. https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/john-gay.

explanation: Elizabeth Cleghorn Gaskell was born on September 29, 1810, in Chelsea, London. Her father, William Stevenson, was a Unitarian minister and a civil servant with the Royal Navy. Her mother, Eliza Holland, belonged to a prominent family from the Midlands. Elizabeth's mother died when she was very young, and she was sent to live with her aunt, Hannah Lumb, in Knutsford, Cheshire, which was a town of gentry and tradespeople. Her father's position as a civil servant and her mother's family's prominence suggest a middle-class background. Elizabeth's upbringing in her aunt's house, which was a well-to-do household, also indicates a middle-class upbringing. She received a good education, which was not common for girls at the time, further indicating her middle-class status.
sources: "Elizabeth Gaskell: The Early Years" by John Chapple, "Elizabeth Gaskell: A Habit of Stories" by Jenny Uglow, "The Letters of Mrs. Gaskell" by J.A.V. Chapple and Arthur Pollard.

explanation: George Berkeley was born in County Kilkenny, Ireland, in 1685. His father, William Berkeley, was a customs officer, a position that would have placed the family within the middle class. This is further supported by the fact that George Berkeley was able to attend Kilkenny College, a well-regarded school in Ireland, and later Trinity College, Dublin, indicating that his family had the means to afford a good education. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Berkeley family was part of the elite or nobility, nor were they subsistence-level laborers or peasants.
sources: "George Berkeley." Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy. Stanford University, 2001. Web. 14 Dec. 2013. "George Berkeley." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica Online. Encyclopædia Britannica Inc., 2016. Web. 14 Dec. 2016.

explanation: Ugo Foscolo was born on 6 February 1778 in Zakynthos, an island in Greece. His father, Andrea Foscolo, was a Venetian doctor, and his mother, Diamantina Spathis, was from a well-to-do local Greek family. This suggests that Foscolo was born into a family of some means, but not of the elite ruling class or nobility. His father's profession as a doctor indicates a level of education and skill, placing the family in the middle class. Foscolo's access to education was likely due to his family's status and resources, as his father was a doctor and would have valued education. The family's living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, consistent with a middle-class lifestyle. There is no evidence of inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Ugo Foscolo: An Italian in Regency England" by E. R. Vincent; "Ugo Foscolo's Tragic Vision in Italy and England" by Giovanna Perin.

explanation: Horace Walpole was born into the highest echelons of British society. His father, Sir Robert Walpole, was a prominent politician who served as the first Prime Minister of Great Britain, a position that placed the family among the ruling class. The Walpole family was wealthy, owning a number of estates, including Houghton Hall in Norfolk and Strawberry Hill in Twickenham. Horace's birth into this family would have afforded him a number of privileges, including access to the best education money could buy. He was educated at Eton College and King's College, Cambridge, institutions that were typically reserved for the children of the elite. His early life housing and living conditions would have been luxurious, befitting his family's status.
sources: "Horace Walpole's Letters: Masculinity and Friendship in the Eighteenth Century" by George E. Haggerty, "The Yale Edition of Horace Walpole's Correspondence", "The Prime Minister: The Office and Its Holders since 1945" by Peter Hennessy.

explanation: Algernon Charles Swinburne was born into an aristocratic family, which places him in the Elite class. His father, Admiral Charles Henry Swinburne, was a high-ranking officer in the Royal Navy, and his mother, Lady Jane Henrietta, was the daughter of the 3rd Earl of Ashburnham. This suggests that his family had significant social standing and wealth. Swinburne was born at Grosvenor Place, London, indicating a high standard of living. He was educated at Eton and Balliol College, Oxford, two of the most prestigious educational institutions in the UK, which would have been accessible to him due to his family's wealth and status. His upbringing was thus marked by privilege and access to opportunities that were typically reserved for the elite.
sources:
1. "Algernon Charles Swinburne: A Literary Life" by Jerome McGann.
2. "Algernon Swinburne: The Portrait of a Poet" by Philip Henderson.
3. "The Swinburne Letters" edited by Cecil Y. Lang.

explanation: Anne Brontë was born on January 17, 1820, in Thornton, West Yorkshire, England, to Patrick Brontë and Maria Branwell Brontë. Her father was an Irish Anglican clergyman, which would place the family within the middle class of the time. Patrick Brontë had a stable income, but the family was not wealthy. They lived in a parsonage in Haworth, which was provided as part of Patrick's employment. The family had access to a large collection of books, which suggests a certain level of education and literacy. However, Anne's mother died when she was very young, and her two eldest sisters died in childhood, which suggests that the family may have faced some health and living condition challenges. Despite these hardships, Anne and her surviving siblings (Charlotte, Emily, and Branwell) received a good education, both at home and at various schools, due to their father's occupation and connections.
sources: Barker, Juliet. "The Brontës." St. Martin's Press, 1995; Gérin, Winifred. "Anne Brontë: A Biography." Oxford University Press, 1976.

explanation: Thomas Lawrence was born in Bristol, England in 1769. His father, Thomas Lawrence Sr., was a supervisor of excise, a position that would have placed the family in the middle class. However, his father's unsuccessful ventures as an innkeeper led to financial instability and the family was often in debt. Despite these financial struggles, Lawrence's parents valued education and ensured he had access to books and learning. His mother, Lucy Read, was a talented amateur artist and likely provided him with his first drawing lessons. The family lived in various inns and taverns throughout Lawrence's childhood, reflecting their unstable financial situation but also their middle-class status, as they were not laborers or peasants.
sources: "Sir Thomas Lawrence: A complete catalogue of the oil paintings" by Kenneth Garlick, Angus Macintyre, and Kathryn Cave; "Thomas Lawrence" by Michael Levey.

explanation: Henry Fuseli was born as Johann Heinrich Füssli in Zurich, Switzerland, in 1741. His father, Johann Caspar Füssli, was a portrait painter and writer on art, indicating a skilled profession that would place the family in the middle class. His mother, Elisabetha Depéry, was also from a family of artists. The family was not of noble birth or extreme wealth, but they were not impoverished either. Fuseli's access to education was likely due to his family's middle-class status and their involvement in the arts. He was initially educated by his father and later attended the Caroline college of Zurich, where he studied theology. His early life housing and living conditions are not well-documented, but given his father's profession, it's reasonable to assume they were comfortable but not luxurious.
sources: "Henry Fuseli." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Henry-Fuseli; "Henry Fuseli." The Art Story. https://www.theartstory.org/artist/fuseli-henry/life-and-legacy/; "Henry Fuseli." Tate. https://www.tate.org.uk/art/artists/henry-fuseli-202.

explanation: Emmanuel Swedenborg was born on January 29, 1688, in Stockholm, Sweden, not the United Kingdom. His father, Jesper Swedberg, was a prominent Lutheran bishop, and his mother, Sara Behm, came from a wealthy mining family. Swedenborg's family was part of the Swedish nobility, and his father was ennobled in 1719, after which the family changed their surname to Swedenborg. The family's wealth and status would have provided Swedenborg with access to education and comfortable living conditions. His father's position in the church would have also conferred certain privileges.
sources: "The Life and Mission of Emanuel Swedenborg" by George Trobridge, "Swedenborg: Life and Teaching" by Inge Jonsson, "Emanuel Swedenborg: Visionary Savant in the Age of Reason" by Ernst Benz.

explanation:
James VI and I was born into the highest social class of the late 16th century United Kingdom. His mother was Mary, Queen of Scots, and his father was Henry Stuart, Lord Darnley, both of whom were members of the ruling class. His parents were of noble birth, with Mary being the reigning queen of Scotland at the time of his birth and Henry Stuart being a cousin of Queen Elizabeth I of England. This placed James in the elite class from birth, as he was born into a family of significant wealth and power.

James had access to education from an early age due to his family background. His tutors included some of the most learned men of the time, such as George Buchanan, a distinguished scholar of Latin and Greek. This level of education was not common for the period and was a privilege afforded to him due to his noble birth.

His early life housing and living conditions were also indicative of his elite status. He was born in Edinburgh Castle, a royal residence, and spent his early years in various royal palaces and castles.
sources:
1. "James VI and I" by Roger Lockyer (Cambridge University Press, 1998)
2. "The Cradle King: The Life of James VI and I, the First Monarch of a United Great Britain" by Alan Stewart (St. Martin's Press, 2003)
3. "Mary Queen of Scots" by Antonia Fraser (Weiden

explanation: Eadweard Muybridge was born as Edward James Muggeridge in Kingston upon Thames, England, in 1830. His father, John Muggeridge, was a grain and coal merchant, indicating a middle-class occupation. His mother, Susannah Smith, was a daughter of a ship builder, another middle-class profession. The family lived in a house on the High Street of Kingston upon Thames, suggesting a comfortable living condition. There is no record of Eadweard Muybridge inheriting any significant wealth or privileges, but his family background would have provided him with access to basic education and a decent standard of living.
sources: Kingston Museum and Heritage Service, Kingston upon Thames; "Eadweard Muybridge: The Man Who Made Pictures Move" by Rebecca Solnit.

explanation: Wenceslaus Hollar was born in Prague, Bohemia (now the Czech Republic), not the United Kingdom. His father was a lawyer and a member of the city council, which suggests a middle-class background. The family was not part of the nobility, but they were also not subsistence-level laborers or peasants. Hollar's access to education was likely due to his family's status and resources, as his father would have had the means to provide for his education. However, the family's wealth was significantly reduced during the Bohemian Revolt (1618–1620), part of the larger Thirty Years' War, which would have impacted Hollar's early life living conditions. Despite this, Hollar was able to study in Frankfurt under Matthäus Merian, which suggests that the family still had enough resources to support his education.
sources: "Wenceslaus Hollar and His Views of London and Windsor in the Seventeenth Century" by Arthur M. Hind; "Wenceslaus Hollar: A Bohemian Artist in England" by Richard Godfrey.

explanation: Michael Faraday was born in 1791 in Newington Butts, which was then a part of Surrey and is now a part of South London. His father, James Faraday, was a blacksmith who struggled to maintain steady employment and income. His mother, Margaret Hastwell, was a servant before her marriage. The family lived in poverty, often struggling to meet basic needs. Faraday received only a basic education in a local Sunday school, as his family could not afford a more formal education. He began working at a young age to contribute to the family income, first as a delivery boy and later as an apprentice to a bookbinder. His early life was marked by hardship and a lack of resources, characteristic of the subsistence class.
sources: "Michael Faraday: Sandemanian and Scientist—A Study of Science and Religion in the Nineteenth Century" by Geoffrey Cantor, "Faraday, Maxwell, and the Electromagnetic Field: How Two Men Revolutionized Physics" by Nancy Forbes and Basil Mahon.

explanation: Florence Nightingale was born into a wealthy, upper-class British family. Her father, William Edward Nightingale, was a wealthy landowner who had inherited two estates—one at Lea Hurst, Derbyshire, and another in Hampshire, Embley Park. He was also educated at Cambridge University, indicating a high level of privilege and access to education. Her mother, Frances Nightingale, hailed from a family of merchants and took pride in socializing with people of prominent social standing. Florence and her sister were educated by their father in a variety of subjects including science, history, and philosophy, which was unusual for women of that time and indicative of their elite status. Their family wealth and social standing provided them with comfortable living conditions and access to resources not available to the lower classes.
sources: Bostridge, Mark. "Florence Nightingale: The Making of an Icon." Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 2008. Cook, Edward Tyas. "The Life of Florence Nightingale." Macmillan, 1913.

explanation: Alfred Russel Wallace was born on January 8, 1823, in Llanbadoc, Monmouthshire, Wales. His father, Thomas Vere Wallace, was a solicitor by profession but was not very successful. His mother, Mary Anne Greenell, came from a middle-class family. Wallace's family was of modest means, and they lived in a small cottage. His father's income was not sufficient to maintain the family's middle-class status, and they often struggled financially. Despite these financial difficulties, Wallace was able to receive some education. He attended Hertford Grammar School, but his education was cut short due to the family's financial difficulties. His early education was largely self-taught, and he later worked as a teacher to support himself.
sources: "Alfred Russel Wallace: A Life" by Peter Raby; "Alfred Russel Wallace: Letters and Reminiscences, Vol. 1" by James Marchant.

explanation:
Christina Rossetti was born on December 5, 1830, in London, England, to Gabriele Rossetti and Frances Polidori Rossetti. Her father, Gabriele, was an Italian poet and a political asylum seeker from Naples, and her mother, Frances Polidori, was the sister of Lord Byron's friend and physician, John William Polidori. Gabriele was a Dante scholar, who when in London, held a position as a professor of Italian at King's College from 1831. This indicates that the family had a decent income and a respectable social standing, characteristic of the middle class.

Christina was the youngest of four children in an extraordinarily gifted family. Her oldest brother, Dante Gabriel, became an influential artist and poet. William Michael and Maria Francesca were both writers. The Rossetti family was well educated and highly cultured, suggesting a middle-class background. Christina was educated at home by her mother and father, who shared their interests in literature and the arts with their children. 

The family lived in London, a city known for its cultural and intellectual life, which would have provided the Rossettis with a stimulating environment. However, the family faced financial difficulties after Gabriele's failing health and death in 1854. Despite these challenges, the family maintained their intellectual pursuits, suggesting a strong middle-class value system.
sources: 1. Marsh, Jan. "Christ

explanation: Robert Southey was born on August 12, 1774, in Bristol, England. His father, Robert Southey Sr., was a linen draper, which was a respectable occupation within the middle class during the late 18th century. His mother, Margaret Hill, came from a family of bakers, another middle-class occupation. Southey's family was not wealthy, but they were able to provide him with a decent upbringing. His access to education was facilitated by his aunt, Elizabeth Tyler, who recognized his potential and arranged for him to attend Westminster School, a prestigious institution. This suggests that while his immediate family may not have had the means to provide him with a high-quality education, his extended family had enough resources and connections to do so. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of the middle class at the time, with his family living in a modest home in Bristol.
sources:
- "Robert Southey: A Life" by Mark Storey (Oxford University Press, 1997)
- "The Life and Correspondence of Robert Southey" by Charles Cuthbert Southey (Longman, Brown, Green, and Longmans, 1849)

explanation:
Charles Kingsley was born on June 12, 1819, in Holne, Devon, England. His father, Charles Kingsley Sr., was a clergyman of the Church of England, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the United Kingdom in the late 1800s. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They had a comfortable living, and Kingsley's father's occupation as a clergyman would have provided them with a certain level of respectability and social standing. 

Kingsley's access to education was also a result of his family's middle-class status. His father, being a clergyman, would have valued education and ensured that his children received a good one. Kingsley was educated at home by his mother before attending Bristol and Helston grammar schools. He later attended King's College London and Magdalene College, Cambridge, which would have been possible due to his family's middle-class status.

The family lived in comfortable, if not luxurious, circumstances. They lived in the rectory at Clovelly, Devon, which would have been a decent-sized house with a garden. This suggests that they were not struggling to make ends meet, but they were also not living in the lap of luxury.
sources: - "Charles Kingsley." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Charles-Kings

explanation: Richard Brinsley Sheridan was born in Dublin, Ireland, in 1751 to Thomas Sheridan and Frances Sheridan. His father, Thomas, was an actor, schoolmaster, and theater manager, while his mother, Frances, was a novelist and playwright. This suggests that the family was part of the middle class, as they were involved in skilled professions, but were not part of the ruling class or nobility. The family moved to England when Richard was seven years old, and he was educated at Harrow School, indicating that the family had enough wealth to afford a good education for their children. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were part of the elite class, as they did not hold titles or significant landholdings.
sources:
1. Morwood, James. "Sheridan, Richard Brinsley (1751–1816), playwright and politician." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004.
2. Fraser, Russell. "Sheridan, Richard Brinsley." Encyclopedia Britannica. Encyclopedia Britannica, Inc., 2020.

explanation:
Robert Boyle was born into one of the wealthiest and most influential families in the British Isles. His father, Richard Boyle, was the 1st Earl of Cork and had amassed a significant fortune through land acquisitions and investments. Richard Boyle was a self-made man who rose from a modest background to become one of the richest men in the British Isles. Robert Boyle's mother, Catherine Fenton, was the daughter of Sir Geoffrey Fenton, the Principal Secretary of State for Ireland. 

Robert Boyle was the seventh son and fourteenth child of his parents. He was born at Lismore Castle, in County Waterford, Ireland, indicating a high level of family wealth and status. His family's wealth and status would have provided him with access to education and other opportunities not available to those of lower social classes. 

In terms of education, Boyle was tutored at home and then sent to Eton College, an elite boarding school in England. After Eton, he traveled abroad with a private tutor, a privilege only available to the elite. 

Inherited privileges included his father's title, wealth, and extensive land holdings, which would have provided him with a comfortable lifestyle and opportunities for advancement.
sources:
1. Hunter, Michael. "Robert Boyle (1627–91): Scrupulosity and Science". Woodbridge: The Boydell Press, 2000.
2. Principe, Lawrence M. "The Aspiring Adept:

explanation:
Matthew Arnold was born into a middle-class family. His father, Thomas Arnold, was a renowned educator and historian, serving as the headmaster of Rugby School from 1828 to 1841. His mother, Mary Penrose, was the daughter of a local clergyman. The Arnold family was not part of the aristocracy, but they were well-respected and had a comfortable lifestyle due to Thomas Arnold's professional success. 

Matthew Arnold's access to education was a direct result of his family background. His father's position as headmaster at Rugby School allowed him to receive a high-quality education from an early age. This was not a privilege that was common among the lower classes during this period in British history.

The Arnold family's living conditions were also indicative of their middle-class status. They lived in a comfortable home provided by Rugby School, which would have been well beyond the means of a subsistence-level family.
sources:
1. "Matthew Arnold (1822–1888)." Poetry Foundation. https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/matthew-arnold
2. "Thomas Arnold." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Thomas-Arnold
3. "Matthew Arnold." Victorian Web. http://www.victorianweb.org/authors/arnold/arnoldbio.html

explanation: Edmund Spenser was born in London around 1552 to a family of modest means. His parents, John and Elizabeth Spenser, were not of noble lineage or substantial wealth. His father was a clothmaker, a trade that would have placed the family in the middle class of the time. Despite their limited means, they were able to provide Spenser with an education. He attended the Merchant Taylors’ School, a prestigious institution that was often attended by boys of the middle class. His attendance at this school was likely due to his family's connections rather than their wealth. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of a middle-class family in London during the 16th century. There is no evidence to suggest that he inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth.
sources: "Edmund Spenser: An Essay on Renaissance Poetry" by Robert Ellrodt; "Edmund Spenser: A Life" by Andrew Hadfield; "The Cambridge Companion to Spenser" edited by Andrew Hadfield.

explanation: Sir Walter Raleigh was born into a well-connected and influential family. His father, Walter Raleigh Sr., was a country gentleman and landowner, and his mother, Catherine Champernowne, was the niece of Kat Ashley, Queen Elizabeth's governess. This connection to the royal court would have placed the Raleigh family in the upper echelons of society. Raleigh's family was Protestant, which was the dominant religion in England at the time, further solidifying their social standing. Raleigh's early education was likely provided by private tutors, a privilege afforded only to the elite. His family's wealth and connections would have provided him with a comfortable childhood and access to opportunities not available to those of lower social classes.
sources: "Sir Walter Raleigh." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica, inc., 2021. Web. 10 Dec. 2021. ; "Walter Raleigh." English History. English History, 2021. Web. 10 Dec. 2021.

explanation: John Frederick William Herschel was born into a family of considerable standing and wealth. His father, Sir William Herschel, was a prominent astronomer who discovered the planet Uranus, and his mother, Mary Baldwin Herschel, came from a well-off family. Sir William Herschel was also a musician and composer of some repute, and he was appointed as the King's Astronomer by King George III, a position that came with a salary and a house, indicating a high social standing. The Herschel family lived in a large house in Slough, England, which suggests a comfortable living situation. John Herschel's access to education was also indicative of his elite status. He was educated at home by private tutors before attending Eton College, one of the most prestigious schools in England, and later St John's College, Cambridge. This level of education was typically only accessible to the elite class during this period.
sources: "The Herschel Family Papers" (Royal Astronomical Society), "John Herschel" (Encyclopedia Britannica), "The Herschel Chronicle: the Life-story of William Herschel and his Sister, Caroline Herschel" (Constance Anne Lubbock).

explanation: Samuel Pepys was born in London in 1633 to John Pepys, a tailor, and Margaret Pepys, the daughter of a Whitechapel butcher. His father's occupation as a tailor would place the family in the middle class, as tailoring was a skilled craft. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. Pepys was the fifth of eleven children, but because many of his siblings died in infancy, he became the oldest and received the benefits of being the eldest son. This included access to education, as his family's status and resources allowed him to attend Huntingdon Grammar School and later St. Paul's School in London. His father's connections also helped him to secure a position as a household servant to a cousin, who was a wealthy merchant and influential member of the gentry. This allowed Pepys to attend Cambridge University. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of a middle-class family in 17th-century England.
sources: "Samuel Pepys: The Unequalled Self" by Claire Tomalin; "The Diary of Samuel Pepys" by Samuel Pepys; "Samuel Pepys and His World" by Geoffrey Trease.

explanation: John Everett Millais was born in Southampton, England, in 1829 to John William Millais and Emily Mary Millais. His father was a man of French descent and was a prosperous gentleman from Jersey, one of the Channel Islands, who had a business in selling luxury goods. His mother, Emily Mary, was from an old and respected family in the south of England. The family was well-off but not part of the aristocracy. Millais had access to education because of his family background. He was sent to school in London and later attended the Royal Academy Schools, which suggests that his family had the means to afford a good education for their children. The family lived in a comfortable home in Jersey and later in London, indicating a middle-class lifestyle. Millais did not inherit any titles or significant wealth, but he did inherit the advantages of a comfortable upbringing and a good education.
sources: Millais, J.G. (1899). The Life and Letters of Sir John Everett Millais, President of the Royal Academy. London: Methuen & Co.

explanation: W. S. Gilbert, full name William Schwenck Gilbert, was born in London in 1836 to William Gilbert and Anne Gilbert. His father was a naval surgeon who later turned novelist and his mother was a former singer. This suggests that his family was part of the middle class, as his father had a professional occupation and his mother was involved in the arts. Furthermore, Gilbert's education at the Great Ealing School and later at King's College London indicates that his family had the financial means to provide him with a good education, a characteristic of the middle class. However, there is no evidence to suggest that his family was part of the elite or ruling class, as they did not hold titles or significant wealth.
sources:
1. Ainger, Michael (2002). Gilbert and Sullivan–A Dual Biography. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
2. Stedman, Jane W. (1996). W. S. Gilbert, A Classic Victorian & His Theatre. Oxford University Press.

explanation:
Thomas Babington Macaulay was born on October 25, 1800, in Rothley Temple, Leicestershire, England. His father, Zachary Macaulay, was a Scottish Highlander who became a colonial governor and abolitionist. Zachary's work as a colonial governor and his involvement in the abolitionist movement suggest a level of education and social standing that would place him in the middle class. His mother, Selina Mills, was the daughter of a Bristol bookseller, which also suggests a middle-class background. 

The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. Macaulay's father's work provided a stable income, and they were able to afford a comfortable lifestyle. Macaulay's early education was largely provided by his mother, and he later attended a private school in London. This access to education, particularly private education, suggests a middle-class upbringing.

Macaulay's early life housing and living conditions were comfortable but not luxurious. The family lived in a house in Rothley Temple, which was a respectable but not overly grand residence. There is no evidence to suggest that Macaulay inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources:
1. "Thomas Babington Macaulay." Encyclopædia Britannica. https://www.britannica.com/biography/Thomas-Babington-Macaulay-Baron-Macaulay
2. "Thomas

explanation: Arthur Sullivan was born in Lambeth, London, in 1842. His father, Thomas Sullivan, was a military bandmaster and later a music teacher, which places the family in the middle class according to the given typology. His mother, Mary Clementina Sullivan, was of Irish descent. The family was not wealthy, but they were not living in poverty either. Arthur Sullivan's father's occupation allowed him to have access to music education from an early age, which was a privilege not available to all children at that time. The family lived in a modest house in London, which further supports their middle-class status.
sources: "Arthur Sullivan — A Musical Reappraisal" by Derek B. Scott, "Arthur Sullivan: A Victorian Musician" by Arthur Jacobs, and census records from the time.

explanation: Julia Margaret Cameron was born to a family of high social standing in British India. Her father, James Pattle, was an official with the East India Company, a powerful entity that effectively ruled large parts of India during the 19th century. Her mother, Adeline de l'Etang, was a French aristocrat. The Pattle family was known for their wealth and influence, which would have afforded Julia a privileged upbringing. She was one of seven sisters, all of whom were known for their beauty and their advantageous marriages. Julia's access to education would have been guaranteed by her family's status, and she would have grown up in comfortable housing conditions.
sources: "Julia Margaret Cameron: The Complete Photographs" by Julian Cox and Colin Ford; "Julia Margaret Cameron's Women" by Sylvia Wolf; "Victorian Photographs of Famous Men & Fair Women" by Julia Margaret Cameron and Virginia Woolf.

explanation:
Samuel Butler was born on December 4, 1835, in Langar, near Bingham, Nottinghamshire, England. His father, Reverend Thomas Butler, was the vicar of Langar and his mother, Fanny Worsley, was the daughter of a clergyman. This suggests that the family was of a respectable social standing, typical of the middle class in the 19th century England. The family was not of the elite class, as they were not aristocrats or nobility, but they were also not subsistence class, as they were not laborers or peasants. 

Butler's access to education was also indicative of his middle-class background. He was educated at home by his parents until he was twelve, which was a common practice among middle-class families during this period. He then attended Shrewsbury School, a public school in Shrewsbury, Shropshire. His family's ability to afford such education suggests that they were financially stable.

In terms of early life housing and living conditions, Butler lived in the vicarage in Langar, which was likely a comfortable home. As the son of a clergyman, he would have had certain privileges, such as a stable home and access to education, but he would not have had the extensive privileges of the elite class.
sources: 1. "Samuel Butler." Encyclopædia Britannica. Encyclopædia Britannica,

explanation: Robert Hooke was born in 1635 in Freshwater, a village on the Isle of Wight, England. His father, John Hooke, was a curate of the local church, which would place the family in the middle class according to the typology provided. The family was not wealthy, but they were not poor either. Upon his father's death in 1648, Hooke inherited a sum of forty pounds, which was a significant amount of money at the time, suggesting a comfortable, if not affluent, upbringing. This inheritance allowed Hooke to move to London to study, indicating that his family had the means to support his education. Hooke's early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of a middle-class family of the period.
sources: "Robert Hooke: Tercentennial Studies" by Michael Cooper and Michael Hunter; "The Curious Life of Robert Hooke: The Man Who Measured London" by Lisa Jardine.

explanation: William Henry Fox Talbot was born into an elite family. His father, William Davenport Talbot, was a member of the British aristocracy, and his mother, Lady Elisabeth Fox Strangways, was the daughter of the 2nd Earl of Ilchester. The Talbot family was wealthy and held significant land, including Lacock Abbey, which was passed down to Talbot after his father's death. His mother's family also held significant wealth and land. Talbot's early education was provided by private tutors, a privilege afforded to him by his family's wealth and social standing. His family's wealth and social standing also provided him with a comfortable living environment and access to resources that were not available to those of lower social classes.
sources: "The Pencil of Nature" by William Henry Fox Talbot; "William Henry Fox Talbot: Pioneer of Photography and Man of Science" by H. J. P. Arnold; "Lacock Abbey" by National Trust.

explanation: Albert, Prince Consort, was born into the House of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, a German ducal house that was part of the European nobility. His father was Ernest I, Duke of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha, and his mother was Princess Louise of Saxe-Gotha-Altenburg. The family was wealthy and had significant political influence in the region. Albert was born in Schloss Rosenau, a ducal summer residence, indicating a high standard of living. He had access to education from a young age due to his family's status, receiving private tutoring and later attending the University of Bonn. His upbringing was characterized by inherited privileges due to his noble birth.
sources: "The Life of His Royal Highness the Prince Consort" by Sir Theodore Martin; "Queen Victoria" by Lytton Strachey; "Albert: Uncrowned King" by Stanley Weintraub.

explanation: Benjamin West was born in Springfield, Pennsylvania, in the British American colonies, not the United Kingdom. His parents were innkeepers, a profession that would place them in the middle class according to the typology provided. His father, John West, also served as a provincial judge, further solidifying their middle-class status. West showed artistic talent from a young age, and his family encouraged his abilities, suggesting they had the means to support his interests. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they were particularly wealthy or had access to significant resources. West's education was largely informal, learned from local artists and Native Americans, rather than through formal schooling, which was not uncommon for the time and place. His family's inn would have provided a comfortable, if not luxurious, living environment.
sources: "Benjamin West." Encyclopedia of World Biography, 2nd ed., vol. 17, Gale, 1998. "Benjamin West." Oxford Dictionary of Art and Artists, Oxford University Press, 2018.

explanation: David Garrick was born into a middle-class family in Hereford, England. His father, Peter Garrick, was a captain in the English army, a profession that would have provided a stable, if not affluent, income. His mother, Arabella Clough, was the daughter of a vicar, further suggesting a middle-class background. Garrick's family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They had enough resources to send Garrick to the King Edward VI School in Lichfield, where he received a solid education. This access to education suggests a certain level of financial stability and social standing. Garrick's early life housing and living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of a middle-class family in the 18th century. There is no evidence to suggest that Garrick inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "David Garrick, 1717–1779: A Theatrical Life" by Marc Baer, "The Plays of David Garrick" by Harry William Pedicord and Fredrick Louis Bergmann.

explanation: Frederick Marryat was born into a family of the British elite. His father, Joseph Marryat, was a member of Parliament and a merchant who made a significant fortune in the West Indies trade, which would place the family within the wealthy class of the time. Frederick's mother, Charlotte von Geyer, was of Huguenot descent, a group known for their high social standing in British society. The family's wealth allowed Frederick to receive a high-quality education, as he was sent to a boarding school in Putney. The family lived in a large house in Hampshire, indicating a high standard of living. Therefore, based on his parents' occupations and social standing, family wealth, access to education, and early life housing and living conditions, Frederick Marryat can be classified as being from the elite class.
sources: "The Life and Works of Frederick Marryat" by David Hannay, "Captain Marryat: Seaman, Writer, and Adventurer" by Florence Marryat.

explanation: Edmund Burke was born in Dublin, Ireland, around 1729. His father, Richard Burke, was a successful attorney who had married into the Nagle family, a Catholic gentry family from County Cork. His mother, Mary Nagle, was a Catholic, while his father was a Protestant. This mixed religious background would have placed the family in a somewhat precarious social position in Ireland at the time, but their professional and gentry status would have provided a degree of stability and comfort. Burke's father's profession as a lawyer indicates a middle-class background, as does the family's ability to send Burke to a Quaker boarding school in Ballitore, County Kildare, and later to Trinity College, Dublin. These educational opportunities suggest a level of family wealth and social standing above that of the subsistence class.
sources: "Edmund Burke: A Life in Caricature" by Nicholas K. Robinson; "Edmund Burke and the Natural Law" by Peter J. Stanlis.

explanation:
James Clerk Maxwell was born into a family of comfortable means. His father, John Clerk Maxwell, was a lawyer and his mother, Frances Cay, was from a well-off family. The Maxwells were an old Scottish family that had been landowners for centuries, and James' father had inherited a substantial estate, "Glenlair," where James was born and raised. This estate provided the family with a significant income. 

James' early education was provided by his mother until her death when he was eight years old. Following this, he had a tutor, and later attended the prestigious Edinburgh Academy, indicating that his family had the means to afford a high-quality education. 

His family's wealth and social standing would have provided him with many advantages and opportunities not available to those of lower social classes. His upbringing on a rural estate would have been comfortable, with access to resources and opportunities for learning and development.
sources:
1. Mahon, Basil (2003). The Man Who Changed Everything – the Life of James Clerk Maxwell. Hoboken, NJ: Wiley. 
2. Tolstoy, Ivan (1982). James Clerk Maxwell: A Biography. Chicago: University of Chicago Press. 
3. Campbell, Lewis; Garnett, William (1882). The Life of James Clerk Maxwell. London: Macmillan and Co.

explanation: William Beckford was born into a wealthy and influential family. His father, also named William Beckford, was a politician and a sugar plantation owner, making him one of the wealthiest men in England at the time. The elder Beckford's wealth was so vast that he was often referred to as "Alderman Beckford" or "the uncrowned king of Jamaica." This wealth and influence would have provided young William with a privileged upbringing, including access to high-quality education and comfortable living conditions. His mother, Maria Hamilton, was also from a wealthy family, being the daughter of the Hon. George Hamilton. Therefore, based on his parents' occupations and social standing, family wealth at the time of his birth and childhood, access to education because of family background, early life housing and living conditions, and inherited privileges, William Beckford would be classified as part of the elite class.
sources:
1. "William Beckford of Fonthill." The History of Parliament: the House of Commons 1754-1790, ed. L. Namier, J. Brooke., 1964.
