Vertue's father's status as a refugee may have impacted the family's wealth and social standing, but there is no evidence to suggest they lived in poverty. Vertue was apprenticed to a goldsmith at a young age, which suggests he had access to some form of education and training, again indicative of a middle-class background.
sources: Walpole, Horace. "Anecdotes of Painting in England: With Some Account of the Principal Artists." London: Shakespeare Press, 1828. Vertue, George. "Notebooks." London: Walpole Society, 1930-47.

explanation: Hubert von Herkomer was born in Waal, Bavaria, but his family moved to the United Kingdom when he was very young. His father, Lorenz Herkomer, was a wood-carver and piano maker, which suggests a skilled craft occupation, typical of the middle class during the late 1800s. His mother was a music teacher, another profession associated with the middle class. The family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. They had enough resources to move to another country and establish a new life. Hubert's father's profession suggests that they had a home and workshop, and Hubert himself was able to attend school in Southampton, indicating that the family had at least some access to education. However, there is no evidence of inherited privileges or significant wealth.
sources: "Hubert von Herkomer: A Study and a Biography" by A. L. Baldry, "The Dictionary of National Biography" by Sir Leslie Stephen and Sir Sidney Lee.

explanation: David Cox was born in Deritend, an industrial area of Birmingham, England, in 1783. His father was a blacksmith and his mother was a domestic servant. The blacksmith trade was a skilled craft, which would place the family in the middle class according to the given typology. However, it should be noted that the family likely lived modestly, as blacksmithing was not a particularly high-paying occupation. There is no evidence to suggest that the family had significant wealth or that Cox had access to education due to his family background. His early life housing and living conditions would have been typical of a working-class family in an industrial area during this period. There is no evidence to suggest that Cox had any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "David Cox 1783–1859." Tate. https://www.tate.org.uk/art/artists/david-cox-114; "David Cox." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. https://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-6551.

explanation: Thomas Mayne Reid was born in 1818 in Ballyroney, a small village in County Down, Northern Ireland. His father, Thomas Reid, was a Presbyterian minister, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the United Kingdom in the 19th century. Ministers were considered educated professionals, a characteristic of the middle class. The family was not wealthy, but they were not in poverty either. Reid's access to education was likely due to his father's profession and status in the community. He was educated at the Royal Belfast Academical Institution, where his father was a board member. This suggests a level of social standing and access to resources typical of the middle class. Information about Reid's early life housing and living conditions is scarce, but as the son of a minister, it is likely that he lived in modest but comfortable circumstances. There is no evidence of inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Thomas Mayne Reid: A Biography" by C. J. Reid; "The Royal Belfast Academical Institution: A History" by W. A. Green.

explanation: Francis Herbert Bradley was born on January 30, 1846, in Clapham, Surrey, England. He was the fourth of eight children born to Charles Bradley, an evangelical preacher, and Emma Linton, the daughter of a prosperous merchant. His father was a vicar of Glasbury, Radnorshire, and later a rector of St. James's, Bury St. Edmunds, Suffolk. The family was not part of the aristocracy or ruling class, but they were not subsistence level either. They were part of the middle class, with Charles Bradley's occupation as a clergyman and Emma Linton's family's merchant background. F.H. Bradley's access to education was also indicative of his middle-class status. He attended Cheltenham College and later University College, Oxford, which would have been unlikely had he been from a subsistence-level family. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable but not luxurious, typical of a middle-class family during that time.
sources:
1. W. J. Mander, "Bradley, Francis Herbert (1846–1924)", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography, Oxford University Press, 2004.
2. Candlish, Stewart. "Francis Herbert Bradley." Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy, Stanford University, 2004.

explanation: James Duffield Harding was born in Deptford, near London, around 1798. His father, Thomas Harding, was a drawing master and artist, which suggests a middle-class background. The profession of a drawing master was a respected one, often associated with the middle class, as it required a certain level of education and skill. There is no evidence to suggest that the Harding family was either part of the elite aristocracy or the subsistence class. The fact that James Duffield Harding himself was able to receive education in art from an early age indicates that his family had the means to provide him with this opportunity, which further supports the classification of his family as middle class. Information about the family's specific wealth, housing conditions, or inherited privileges or disadvantages is not readily available.
sources: "James Duffield Harding" by Wilfred Ball, published in 1902; "The Dictionary of British Watercolour Artists up to 1920" by H.L. Mallalieu, published in 1986.

explanation: George Inness was born in Newburgh, New York, USA, not the United Kingdom. His father, John William Inness, was a farmer before becoming a grocer. This suggests that the family was not part of the elite class, as they were not aristocrats or part of the ruling class. However, they were also not subsistence level, as John William Inness was able to transition from farming to owning a grocery business. George Inness's early access to education is unclear, but his early interest in art was encouraged by his family, suggesting they had the resources to support his interests. His family's ability to own a business and support his interests suggests they were part of the middle class.
sources: "George Inness: An American Landscape Painter" by Nicolai Cikovsky Jr., "George Inness and the Science of Landscape" by Rachael Ziady DeLue.

explanation: Charles James Fox was born into an elite family. His father, Henry Fox, was a prominent politician who served as the Secretary of State for the Southern Department from 1755 to 1756 and later became the 1st Baron Holland. His mother, Lady Caroline Lennox, was the daughter of the 2nd Duke of Richmond, making her a member of the British nobility. The Fox family was wealthy and influential, providing Charles with a privileged upbringing. He was educated at Eton College and Hertford College, Oxford, two prestigious institutions that were typically attended by the children of the elite. His early life housing and living conditions were likely luxurious, given his family's wealth and status.
sources: "The History of Parliament: the House of Commons 1754-1790," by Sir Lewis Namier, John Brooke; "Charles James Fox: a man for the people" by Loren Dudley Reid.

explanation: John Napier was born into the Scottish nobility, a part of the ruling class in the United Kingdom during the late 1500s. His father, Sir Archibald Napier, was a wealthy landowner and an influential member of the Scottish court, serving as the Master of the Mint and later as the Secretary of State. His mother, Janet Bothwell, was also from a noble family, being the daughter of a prominent judge and the sister of a bishop. This high social standing of his parents would have provided John Napier with a privileged upbringing, including access to education and comfortable living conditions. The Napiers were one of the most prominent families in Scotland, owning extensive estates and having strong connections with the royal court. Therefore, John Napier was born into wealth and privilege, which classifies him as part of the elite.
sources: "John Napier: Logarithm John" by Eves, Howard (1990); "John Napier and the Invention of Logarithms, 1614" by Tomash, Erwin (1970); "The History of the Royal Family of Scotland" by Fraser, William (1859).

explanation: Carl Friedrich Abel was born in Köthen, Germany, not the United Kingdom, around 1723. His father, Christian Ferdinand Abel, was a renowned musician at the court of Prince Leopold of Anhalt-Köthen, suggesting a middle-class background. The family likely had a moderate level of wealth and social standing due to Christian Ferdinand Abel's position. Carl Friedrich Abel's access to education was likely influenced by his father's occupation, as he was able to study music at the Thomasschule in Leipzig, a prestigious institution at the time. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable, reflecting his middle-class status. However, there is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Carl Friedrich Abel: Symphonist" by W. Dean Sutcliffe, "The Late Baroque Era" by George J. Buelow, "The Court Musicians in German Rulers' Courts in the 16th-18th Centuries" by Hans Joachim Marx.

explanation: William Camden was born in London in 1551 to Sampson Camden, a painter-stainer. The Painter-Stainers were one of the Livery Companies of the City of London, indicating that Sampson Camden was a skilled craftsman, a profession typical of the middle class during this period. Furthermore, William Camden was able to attend Christ's Hospital and St. Paul's School due to his father's connections, suggesting that the family had some degree of wealth and social standing. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Camden family was part of the elite ruling class or nobility. Therefore, it is reasonable to classify William Camden's birth and childhood social class as middle class.
sources: "William Camden", Encyclopaedia Britannica; "The Painter-Stainers Company", The Worshipful Company of Painter-Stainers; "William Camden", Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation:
James Murray was born in the town of Denholm, Scotland. His father, Thomas Murray, was a tailor by trade, a profession that would have placed the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the United Kingdom in the late 1800s. Tailoring was a skilled craft, and while it did not provide the wealth of the elite, it would have provided a comfortable living for the family. Murray's mother, Jane, was a housewife, which was common for women of the middle class during this time period. 

Murray's access to education was also indicative of his middle-class status. He was educated at local schools until the age of 14, which suggests that his family had the means to provide him with an education, a privilege not afforded to those in the subsistence class. 

The family's living conditions would have been modest but comfortable, typical of a middle-class family. They would have lived in a house in the town, rather than in the countryside or in the slums of a city, further indicating their middle-class status.
sources:
1. "James Murray (lexicographer)." Wikipedia. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Murray_(lexicographer)
2. "The Social Structure of Victorian England." Victorian Web. http://www.victorianweb.org/history/sochistov.html
3. "Victorian Occupations: Life and Labor in the Victorian Period as Seen

explanation: Robert Burton was born in 1577 in Lindley, Leicestershire, England. His father, Ralph Burton, was a farmer and landowner, which would place the family in the middle class according to the social structure of the late 1500s in the United Kingdom. The family's wealth was derived from their land and farming, which was a common source of income for the middle class during this period. Burton's access to education was also a result of his family's social standing. He attended both Oxford and Cambridge, which were typically reserved for the elite and upper middle classes. His early life housing and living conditions would have been comfortable but not lavish, typical of the middle class. There is no evidence of any inherited privileges or disadvantages.
sources: "Robert Burton and the Transformative Powers of Melancholy," by Mary Ann Lund (2007); "The Anatomy of Melancholy," by Robert Burton (1621); "Robert Burton: A Life," by William E. Stafford (1981).

explanation: John Cleland was born to Lucy DuPass and William Cleland. His father, William Cleland, was an officer and a civil servant, serving as a British diplomat in Smyrna and later as an agent for the Duke of Kent. This suggests that the family was not of the elite aristocratic class, but rather of the middle class, as civil service was a common occupation for middle-class individuals during this time period. The family's ability to provide Cleland with a good education, including attendance at the prestigious Westminster School, further supports this classification. However, it should be noted that the family fell into financial difficulties later in Cleland's life, which may have impacted his circumstances during his late adolescence and early adulthood.
sources: "John Cleland: A Biography" by Hal Gladfelder, "The Life and Times of John Cleland" by Simon Winchester.

explanation: John Crome was born in Norwich, England in 1768. His father, John Crome Sr., was a weaver by trade, which was a skilled craft occupation. This suggests that the family was not wealthy, but had a stable income and were likely part of the middle class. Crome's mother, Phoebe Berney, came from a family of farmers, another occupation that would typically be associated with the middle class during this time period. There is no evidence to suggest that Crome had access to formal education due to his family background. However, he did apprentice with a local sign painter, Francis Whisler, which suggests that his family had enough resources to secure this opportunity for him. His early life housing and living conditions would have been modest, but adequate for a family of their social standing. There is no evidence to suggest that Crome inherited any significant privileges or disadvantages due to his birth circumstances.
sources: "John Crome." Oxford Dictionary of National Biography. Oxford University Press, 2004; Moore, Andrew W. "John Crome." The Burlington Magazine, vol. 132, no. 1045, 1990, pp. 267–269. JSTOR.

explanation: William Cobbett was born in Farnham, Surrey, England in 1763. His father, George Cobbett, was a farmer and publican, and his mother, Anne Vincent, was the daughter of a day laborer. Cobbett was the third of four children. His family was not wealthy and lived in a small cottage. His parents were unable to provide him with a formal education, so he taught himself to read and write. His early life was marked by hard work on the family farm, and at the age of 14, he left home to work as a gardener's boy. His family background and early life circumstances suggest that he was born into the subsistence class, as his family had minimal resources and his parents were laborers.
sources: "The Life and Adventures of William Cobbett" by Richard Ingrams; "Rural Rides" by William Cobbett; "William Cobbett: The Politics of Style" by Leonora Nattrass.

explanation: Roderick Murchison was born into a wealthy and influential family. His father, Kenneth Murchison, was a military man who served as a Colonel in the British Army. The Murchison family owned the Tarradale House, a large estate in the Scottish Highlands, indicating significant wealth. This wealth and status would have provided Roderick with a privileged upbringing, including access to quality education. He was educated at the Royal Military College, Great Marlow, which was typically attended by children from elite families. This suggests that Murchison was born into the upper echelons of society, specifically the aristocracy.
sources:
1. "Siluria: The History of the Oldest Known Rocks Containing Organic Remains, with a Brief Sketch of the Distribution of Gold Over the Earth" by Sir Roderick Impey Murchison.
2. "Roderick Murchison: A Life of a Geologist" by Michael Collie and John Diemer.
3. "The Highland Clearances" by Eric Richards.

explanation: Thomas Wyatt was born into a wealthy and noble family. His father, Sir Henry Wyatt, was a trusted advisor to both King Henry VII and King Henry VIII, which placed the family in the upper echelons of society. This privileged position would have provided Thomas with access to education and a comfortable upbringing. The Wyatt family was also known to own Allington Castle and Boxley Abbey in Kent, indicating significant wealth and property ownership. Thomas Wyatt's early life would have been characterized by the privileges and advantages associated with the elite class of the time.
sources: "Sir Thomas Wyatt: Courtier Poet" by Greg Walker, "The Life of Sir Thomas Wyatt" by D. M. Loades, "The Early Life of Sir Thomas Wyatt" by Patricia Thomson.

explanation: Thomas Percy was born into a noble family, the Percy family, one of the oldest and most powerful aristocratic families in England. His father, Hugh Percy, was the 2nd Earl of Northumberland, a title that was passed down through generations of the Percy family. This indicates that Thomas Percy was born into the elite class of society. His family's wealth and status would have provided him with a comfortable upbringing and access to education. The Percy family was known for their large estates and castles, suggesting that Thomas Percy's early life housing and living conditions were of a high standard. As a member of the aristocracy, Thomas Percy would have inherited certain privileges, such as social connections and opportunities for advancement.
sources: "The History of the Percy Family." Northumberland Archives. "The Peerage of England: Containing a Genealogical and Historical Account of All the Peers of England." Collins, Arthur. 1779.

explanation: George Crabbe was born in Aldeburgh, Suffolk, England in 1754. His father, also named George Crabbe, was a salt master, a position that would have placed the family in the middle class. The senior Crabbe was also a minor customs officer, further solidifying the family's middle-class status. The Crabbe family was not wealthy, but they were not impoverished either. George Crabbe's mother, Mary Butcher Crabbe, came from a family of local farmers, another occupation that would have placed them in the middle class. George Crabbe was able to attend a local school due to his family's status, indicating that they had some means. However, his education was not extensive, as he was apprenticed to a doctor at the age of 14, a common practice for middle-class families at the time.
sources: "George Crabbe: An English Life 1754-1832" by Neil Powell; "The Life of George Crabbe" by his son (1834); "George Crabbe" by Thomas Edward Kebbel (1907).

explanation: Daniel Maclise was born in Cork, Ireland, in 1806. His father, Alexander McLish (later Maclise), was a tanner by trade, which was a skilled craft occupation. This places the family in the middle class according to the given typology. The family was not wealthy, but they were not subsistence-level either. Daniel's father was able to send him to the Cork Society School, which indicates a certain level of financial stability and prioritization of education. However, there is no evidence of inherited privileges or significant wealth. The family lived in a modest house in Cork, further supporting their middle-class status.
sources: "Daniel Maclise, 1806-1870: Romancing the Past" by Nancy Weston (1991), "Daniel Maclise: A Biography" by William Bates (1896)

individual_name: Willem van de Velde the Younger
explanation: Willem van de Velde the Younger was born into a family of artists, which would place them in the middle class according to the specified typology. His father, Willem van de Velde the Elder, was a well-known marine painter who had a significant influence on his son's early education and career. The family was not of noble birth or extreme wealth, but they were not subsistence level either. They were skilled craftspeople, a characteristic of the middle class. The family had enough resources to provide Willem with an education in the arts, suggesting a level of financial stability. However, there is no evidence to suggest that they lived in luxury or had significant inherited privileges.
sources: "Willem van de Velde, the Younger | Dutch artist | Britannica", "Willem van de Velde the Younger - National Maritime Museum", "Willem van de Velde the Younger - The Leiden Collection".

explanation: James Clark Ross was born in London, England in 1800. His father, John Ross, was a merchant, which places the family in the middle class according to the specified typology. The Ross family was not part of the aristocracy, but they were also not subsistence-level laborers or peasants. James Clark Ross's uncle, Sir John Ross, was a naval officer and explorer, suggesting that the family had some level of access to education and opportunities beyond what would be available to the lower classes. However, there is no evidence to suggest that the Ross family was particularly wealthy or that James Clark Ross grew up in luxurious circumstances. His family's status as merchants and his uncle's position in the navy suggest a middle-class background.
sources: "Ross, Sir James Clark (1800–1862), polar explorer" by Clive Holland, Oxford Dictionary of National Biography.

explanation: Isaac Watts was born in Southampton, England in 1674. His father, also named Isaac Watts, was a Dissenter from the Anglican Church and on at least one occasion was jailed for his nonconformity. The elder Watts served as a deacon and later an elder of the Above Bar Congregational Church in Southampton. Watts' mother, Sarah, was of Huguenot lineage. His parents were not wealthy, but they were not poor either. They belonged to the middle class, and their religious beliefs likely provided a strong community and network of support. Isaac Watts was able to receive an education, which was not common for all children during this time period. He was taught at home by his father, and later attended the Free School of Southampton, where he learned Latin, Greek, and Hebrew. His access to education suggests a certain level of family resources and social standing.
sources: "Isaac Watts: His Life and Thought" by Graham Beynon, "The Life of Isaac Watts" by Thomas Wright, and "Isaac Watts Remembered" by David Guy Fountain.
